    97. 97
      Bibi, I.; Icenhower, J.; Niazi, N. K.; Naz, T.; Shahid, M.; Bashir, S. Clay minerals: Structure, chemistry, and significance in contaminated environments and geological CO2 sequestration. Environmental materials and waste 2016, 543â 567,  DOI: 10.1016/B978-0-12-803837-6.00021-4
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      97
      Clay minerals: structure, chemistry, and significance in contaminated environments and geological CO2 Sequestration
      Bibi, I.; Icenhower, J.; Niazi, N. K.; Naz, T.; Shahid, M.; Bashir, S.
      Environmental Materials and Waste (2016), (), 543-567CODEN: 69ULZP ISSN:. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. In this chapter, we will mainly focus on the four major groups of clay minerals (kandite, illite, smectite, and vermiculite) and discuss the chem. and structural differences between and within the groups; Fe-Al oxide minerals will not be a focus of this review. Clay minerals are crucially important industrial minerals; they have been in use as raw materials for hundreds of industrial and some environmental applications owing to their abundance, availability, and inexpensive nature. For example, clay minerals have been used in agricultural applications, engineering and construction applications, environmental remediation, geol., pharmaceuticals, food processing, and many other industrial applications (Detellier and Schoonheydt, 2014; Ismadji et al., 2015). This review will summarize the types, structural chem., and characteristics of clay minerals; elucidate their role as cleaning agents in various environmental settings (immobilization of hazardous heavy metals and org. contaminants, eg, dyes, antibiotics, in water and wastewater); highlight their significance in natural and engineered environments (eg, clay barriers) and in leaching/dissoln. of elements; and describe the fundamentally important, although partially investigated, role of clay minerals for sequestration of carbon dioxide (COi) at geol. carbon sequestration (GCS) sites.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      open URL

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      98
      Effects of montmorillonite-zinc oxide hybrid on performance, diarrhea, intestinal permeability and morphology of weanling pigs
      Hu, C. H.; Gu, L. Y.; Luan, Z. S.; Song, J.; Zhu, K.
      Animal Feed Science and Technology (2012), 177 (1-2), 108-115CODEN: AFSTDH; ISSN:0377-8401. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Effects of montmorillonite-zinc oxide hybrid (MMT-ZnO) on performance, diarrhea, intestinal permeability and morphol. were investigated. A total of 180 piglets (Duroc Ã Landrace Ã Yorkshire, av. initial wt. of 7.2 Â± 0.3 kg weaned at 27 Â± 1 d age) were randomly allotted to five groups for two weeks, each of which has six pens with six pigs per pen. The dietary treatments were: (1) basal control diet, 100 mg/kg of supplemental Zn as ZnSO4; (2) basal diet + 2.0 g/kg montmorillonite (MMT), equiv. to the MMT in the MMT-ZnO treatment; (3) basal diet + 500 mg/kg of Zn as ZnO; (4) basal diet + 500 mg/kg of Zn as MMT-ZnO; (5) basal diet + 2000 mg/kg of Zn as ZnO. The results showed that supplemental 500 mg/kg of Zn from MMT-ZnO or 2000 mg/kg of Zn from ZnO improved (P<0.05) av. daily gain and daily feed intake, decreased (P<0.05) fecal scores at 7 and 14 d postweaning, reduced (P<0.05) plasma d-lactate and diamine oxidase activity, improved (P<0.05) villus height and the villus height:crypt depth ratio at the jejunal mucosa as compared with the control, MMT or 500 mg/kg of Zn from ZnO. Pigs fed with 500 mg/kg of Zn as MMT-ZnO had lower (P<0.05) plasma levels of d-lactate than those fed with 2000 mg/kg of Zn as ZnO. Pigs fed with 500 mg/kg of Zn as MMT-ZnO had lower (P<0.05) no. of intestinal Clostridium and Escherichia coli than those fed with the control, MMT or 500 mg/kg of Zn as ZnO. Supplementation with 2000 mg/kg of Zn as ZnO reduced (P<0.05) the no. of Clostridium in proximal colon as compared with the control while had no (P>0.05) influence on intestinal E. coli. Supplemental MMT or 500 mg/kg of Zn from ZnO had no (P>0.05) effect on growth performance, intestinal microflora, permeability and morphol. as compared to the control group. The results indicated that dietary addn. of 500 mg/kg of Zn from MMT-ZnO was comparable to 2000 mg/kg of Zn from ZnO while more effective than MMT or 500 mg/kg of Zn from ZnO for enhancing growth performance, alleviating diarrhea, as well as improving intestinal microflora, mucosal barrier integrity and morphol. of weaned pigs.

      open URL

      Garg, N.; Skibsted, J. Thermal activation of a pure montmorillonite clay and its reactivity in cementitious systems. J. Phys. Chem. C 2014, 118 (21), 11464â 11477,  DOI: 10.1021/jp502529d
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      100
      Thermal Activation of a Pure Montmorillonite Clay and Its Reactivity in Cementitious Systems
      Garg, Nishant; Skibsted, Joergen
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2014), 118 (21), 11464-11477CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Clay minerals are potential candidates as raw materials for new supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) that can partly replace Portland cement and thereby significantly reduce CO2 emissions assocd. with cement prodn. We present the characterization of the complex, disordered structure of a pure montmorillonite clay heated at various temps. (110-1100 Â°C), by solid-state 27Al and 29Si MAS NMR methods. The SiO4 tetrahedra and AlO6 octahedral sites become progressively more distorted, exhibit a significant degree of disorder upon dehydroxylation (600-800 Â°C), and do not lead to the formation of any metastable phase. At high temps. (1000-1100 Â°C), the layer structure of the clay breaks down, forming stable cryst. phases. The chem. reactivity, measured as the degree of dissoln./pptn. in an alk. soln., is found to be proportional to the degree of disorder/dehydroxylation. The max. reactivity as a function of the heating temp. is achieved at 800 Â°C prior to the formation of inert, condensed Q4-type phases in the material. At max. reactivity the calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) phase contains silicate chains with the highest aluminum incorporation, leading to blended cements contg. a C-S-H phase with longer chain lengths. Most importantly, by exploiting the differential spin-lattice relaxation behavior of the 29Si spins, evidence of multiple sites and components in both the naturally occurring and heated montmorillonite is being reported for the first time.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      open URL

      Gualtieri, A. F.; Ferrari, S.; Leoni, M.; Grathoff, G.; Hugo, R.; Shatnawi, M.; Paglia, G.; Billinge, S. Structural characterization of the clay mineral Illite-1M. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2008, 41 (2), 402â 415,  DOI: 10.1107/S0021889808004202

      103
      Structural characterization of the clay mineral illite-1M
      Gualtieri, Alessandro F.; Ferrari, Simone; Leoni, Matteo; Grathoff, Georg; Hugo, Richard; Shatnawi, Mouath; Paglia, Gianluca; Billinge, Simon
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2008), 41 (2), 402-415CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (International Union of Crystallography)
      This work reports the structural characterization of illite-1M from northern Hungary, with the first attempt to refine the structure model and locate the interlayer water mol. Structural characterization was accomplished using state-of-the-art anal. methods available for clays. The results illustrate the status of techniques for clay structure detn., as well as providing a structural model for illite. The chem. formula for the illite-1M under investigation can be written as K0.78Ca0.02Na0.02(Mg0.34Al1.69FeIII0.02)[Si3.35Al0.65]O10(OH)2Â·nH2O. Structure simulations with WILDFIRE yielded a model with 30% of cis-vacant layers and an expandability percentage of 10%. The value of the percentage of expandability was confirmed with NEWMOD, with which the best simulation was obtained with 90% of di-octahedral mica with K (80% site population) in the interlayer region and 10% of expandable layers. The best structure simulation obtained with DIFFaX was also obtained with a population of K atoms of 80%, six cells along c (in agreement with the results of a transmission electron microscopy study) and an av. dimension of the particles in the ab plane of 300 nm. Besides the detn. of the basic structure unit (the results are consistent with those obtained with the local information provided by a fit of the pair distribution function data) and the model of disorder, refinement with DIFFaX+ allowed the calcn. of a possible position for the interlayer water mol. Although phys. sound, both the obsd. tetrahedral layer corrugation and the location of the water mol. need further exptl. evidence, because the final fit of the obsd. pattern is still imperfect. The reasons for this misfit are discussed.

      Determination of the cation exchange capacity of clays by surface tension measurements

In order to make the method suitable for an accurate anal. of the CEC of the clays in drilling fluids or in soils, some parameters affecting the CEC detn. (e.g. the presence of CM-cellulose, mixing time and measurement device) have been investigated.

      Low, P. F.; Anderson, D. M. Osmotic pressure equations for determining thermodynamic properties of soil water. Soil Science 1958, 86 (5), 251â 253,  DOI: 10.1097/00010694-195811000-00004
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      109
      Osmotic pressure equations for determining thermodynamic properties of soil water
      Low, Philip F.; Anderson, Duwayne M.
      Soil Science (1958), 86 (), 251-3CODEN: SOSCAK; ISSN:0038-075X.
      Equations are derived which relate the partial molar free energy, entropy, and heat content of soil water to the soil osmotic pressure and its temp. coeff. To calc. the values of the thermodynamic properties, the osmotic pressure and temp. coeff. must be detd. under the specified conditions. If the soil is free of dissolved salts, the necessary data can be obtained with a tensiometer or pressure membrane in the appropriate moisture range. These data can also be obtained by using a swelling-pressure app. such as that of Bolt and Miller (C.A. 49, 15366a) or Hemwall and Low (C.A. 51, 4614e). If free salts are present, anion or cation exchange membranes may be used to restrict salt diffusion through the membranes.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG1MXps1ehtw%253D%253D&md5=17616be2448b801cc29a2ffd58e3d189

    110. 110
      Amorim, C.; Lopes, R.; Barroso, R.; Queiroz, J.; Alves, D.; Perez, C.; Schelin, H. Effect of clayâwater interactions on clay swelling by X-ray diffraction. Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment 2007, 580 (1), 768â 770,  DOI: 10.1016/j.nima.2007.05.103
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      110
      Effect of clay-water interactions on clay swelling by X-ray diffraction
      Amorim, C. L. G.; Lopes, R. T.; Barroso, R. C.; Queiroz, J. C.; Alves, D. B.; Perez, C. A.; Schelin, H. R.
      Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors, and Associated Equipment (2007), 580 (1), 768-770CODEN: NIMAER; ISSN:0168-9002. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Clay swelling is a very common phenomenon obsd. in sedimentary rocks and soils. It is one of the major causes for permeability redn. in hydrocarbon reservoirs. The aim of this work is to characterize the swelling behavior of bentonite and of two clays from Brazilian petroleum-bearing basins. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to quantify the swelling characteristics of these clays in contact with salt solns., as in a reservoir. The measurement of interplanar spacing of the swollen clay was measured 24 h after the prepn. of the paste. Their diffractograms displayed well-defined peaks at low angles, even for (001) d-spacing values â¥ 50 Ã. Two types of mechanisms for clay swelling were identified: cryst. swelling (limited d-spacing increase) and osmosis-induced swelling (large d-spacing values). The crit. salt concn. (CSC) value, i.e., the salt concn. at which clay changes from cryst. to osmotic swelling, was obtained. The method used in this work allows one to det. the compatibility between reservoir clays and foreign fluids and to avoid the osmotic swelling conditions that can cause permeability redn. in natural hydrocarbon reservoirs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXpvVeqt78%253D&md5=8e9caf49ca966996d782ffeadaa2b861
      open URL
    111. 111
      Wilson, M.; Wilson, L. Clay mineralogy and shale instability: an alternative conceptual analysis. Clay Minerals 2014, 49 (2), 127â 145,  DOI: 10.1180/claymin.2014.049.2.01
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      111
      Clay mineralogy and shale instability: an alternative conceptual analysis
      Wilson, M. J.; Wilson, L.
      Clay Minerals (2014), 49 (2), 127-145, 19 pp.CODEN: CLMIAF; ISSN:0009-8558. (Mineralogical Society)
      A review. The instability of shales in drilled formations leads to serious operational problems with major economic consequences for petroleum exploration and prodn. It is generally agreed that the nature of the clay minerals in shale formations is a primary causative factor leading to their instability, although the exact mechanism involved is more debateable. Currently, the principal cause of shale instability is considered to be vol. expansion following the osmotic swelling of Nasmectite. However, illitic and kaolinitic shales may also be unstable, so that interlayer expansion cannot therefore be considered as a universal causative mechanism of shale instability. This review considers alternative scenarios of shale instability where the major clay minerals are smectite, illite, mixed-layer illite-smectite (I/S) and kaolinite resp. The influence of interacting factors that relate to shale clay mineralogy such as texture, structure and fabric are discussed, as are the pore size distribution and the nature of water in clays and shales and how these change with increasing depth of burial. It is found from the literature that the thickness of the diffuse double layer (DDL) of the aq. solns. assocd. with the charged external surfaces of clay minerals is probably of the same order or even thicker than the sizes of a significant proportion of the pores found in shales. In these circumstances, overlap of the DDLs assocd. with exposed outer surfaces of clay minerals on opposing sides of micropores (<2 nm in diam.) and mesopores (2-50 nm in diam.) in a lithostatically compressed shale would bring about electrostatic repulsion and lead to increased pore/ hydration pressure in smectitic, illitic and even kaolinitic shales. This pressure would be inhibited by the use of more concd. K-based fluids which effectively shrink the thickness of the DDL towards the clay mineral surfaces in the pore walls. The use of sol. polymers would also encapsulate these clay mineral surfaces and so inhibit their hydration. In this scenario, the locus of action with respect to shale instability and its inhibition is moved from the interlamellar space of the smectitic clays to the charged external surfaces of the various clay minerals bounding the walls of the shale pores.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhs1ektrvI&md5=182a3cae8aae85a8cfe03e8ad5790b18
      open URL
    112. 112
      Yuan, W.; Li, X.; Pan, Z.; Connell, L. D.; Li, S.; He, J. Experimental investigation of interactions between water and a lower Silurian Chinese shale. Energy Fuels 2014, 28 (8), 4925â 4933,  DOI: 10.1021/ef500915k
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      112
      Experimental Investigation of Interactions between Water and a Lower Silurian Chinese Shale
      Yuan, Weina; Li, Xiao; Pan, Zhejun; Connell, Luke D.; Li, Shouding; He, Jianming
      Energy & Fuels (2014), 28 (8), 4925-4933CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
      Hydraulic fracturing and well drilling bring water into shale reservoirs. The water interacts with the shale, which can destabilize the wellbore and impact the rate of gas prodn. from the reservoir. Although wellbore instability has been extensively studied, the effect on gas prodn. requires further work. In this work, the interactions of water with shale from China's Sichuan Basin were studied from macroscopic and microscopic perspectives. The visual information provided by studying shale at the microscopic scale helps in understanding the effects of water-shale interactions on gas prodn. We first studied the shale's wettability and water adsorption capacity and then investigated its water adsorption characteristics, swelling strain, and Young's modulus with different water contents. Field-emission SEM was also used to observe the storage of water in the shale matrix and the interaction of shale minerals with water. Our exptl. data show that the adsorption capacity of the shale is low, although it is overall hydrophilic. The adsorption data indicated that diffusion may be the main mechanism for water adsorption by the sample under our exptl. conditions. Capillary pressure may also help transport water into the matrix. The shale sample exhibited free swelling and its Young's modulus decreased after uptake of water, which may be attributed to hydration of clay minerals in the shale sample. Microscopic observations showed that some water remained in the sample's pores even when the water vapor pressure was much lower than the satn. pressure. This suggests that the residual water may be difficult to remove from the reservoir and that hydraulic fluid would have a greater influence on smaller pores than on larger pores.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFGms7nM&md5=fcea13adac3bbce596b3ad4aa4e106bf
      open URL

    114. 114
      Madsen, F. T.; MÃ¼ller-Vonmoos, M. The swelling behaviour of clays. Appl. Clay Sci. 1989, 4 (2), 143â 156,  DOI: 10.1016/0169-1317(89)90005-7
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      114
      The swelling behavior of clays
      Madsen, Fritz T.; Mueller-Vonmoos, Max
      Applied Clay Science (1989), 4 (2), 143-56CODEN: ACLSER; ISSN:0169-1317.
      In swelling clays, 2 types of swelling are obsd. The 1st, innercryst. swelling, is caused by the hydration of the exchangeable cations of the dry clay. The 2nd, osmotic swelling, results from the large difference in the ion concns. close to the clay surfaces and in the pore water. The stepwise nature of the innercryst. swelling can also be seen in the water vapor adsorption isotherm. The swelling stress can be calcd. from the isotherm. The measurement of osmotic swelling in the lab. is discussed. The swelling behavior of clay rocks depends on the type and quantity of clay minerals encountered, their surface charge, the valence of the cations in the double layer. The swelling properties of the rock can be estd. from its characteristic values. An example for such a calcn. is given.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXlsFyqtro%253D&md5=cdbbbfc8df1a040bac460e7a71fe7d6d
      open URL

      Kraehenbuehl, F.; Stoeckli, H. F.; Brunner, F.; Kahr, G.; MÃ¼ller-Vonmoos, M. Study of the water-bentonite system by vapour adsorption, immersion calorimetry and X-ray techniques: I.       Study of the water-bentonite system by vapor adsorption, immersion calorimetry, and x-ray techniques: I. Micropore volumes and internal surface areas, following Dubinin's theory
      Kraehenbuehl, F.; Stoeckli, H. F.; Brunner, F.; Kahr, G.; Mueller-Vonmoos, M.
      Clay Minerals (1987), 22 (1), 1-9CODEN: CLMIAF; ISSN:0009-8558.
      The adsorption and desorption of water, the layer spacing of the montmorillonite with increasing water content, and the heat of immersion with water were measured for a Na-bentonite and 2 Ca-bentonites. The bentonite-water system is treated in terms of a micropore-filling process. Uptake of water occurs in discrete stages as the montmorillonite structure expands; the internal surface was calcd. from these discrete stages of water adsorption.

      Abbott, A. P.; Boothby, D.; Capper, G.; Davies, D. L.; Rasheed, R. K. Deep eutectic solvents formed between choline chloride and carboxylic acids: versatile alternatives to ionic liquids. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126 (29), 9142â 9147,  DOI: 10.1021/ja048266j
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      117
      Deep Eutectic Solvents Formed between Choline Chloride and Carboxylic Acids: Versatile Alternatives to Ionic Liquids
      Abbott, Andrew P.; Boothby, David; Capper, Glen; Davies, David L.; Rasheed, Raymond K.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (29), 9142-9147CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES) can be formed between a variety of quaternary ammonium salts and carboxylic acids. The phys. properties are significantly affected by the structure of the carboxylic acid but the phase behavior of the mixts. can be simply modeled by taking account of the mole fraction of carboxylic acid in the mixt. The phys. properties such as viscosity, cond., and surface tension of these DES are similar to ambient temp. ionic liqs. and insight into the cause of these properties is gained using hole-theory. It is shown that the cond. and viscosity of these liqs. is controlled by ion mobility and the availability of voids of suitable dimensions, and this is consistent with the fluidity of other ionic liqs. and molten salts. The DES are also shown to be good solvents for metal oxides, which could have potential application for metal extn.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXlt1Gns70%253D&md5=5eba50624615fcd43af5afb2b11c0808
      open URL

      El Achkar, T.; Greige-Gerges, H.; Fourmentin, S. Basics and properties of deep eutectic solvents: a review. Environmental Chemistry Letters 2021, 19 (4), 3397â 3408,  DOI: 10.1007/s10311-021-01225-8
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      118
      Basics and properties of deep eutectic solvents: a review
      El Achkar, Tracy; Greige-Gerges, Helene; Fourmentin, Sophie
      Environmental Chemistry Letters (2021), 19 (4), 3397-3408CODEN: ECLNBJ; ISSN:1610-3653. (Springer)
      A review. Deep eutectic solvents have emerged in green chem. only seventeen years ago and yet resulted in a plethora of publications covering various research areas and diverse fields of application. Deep eutectic solvents appear as promising alternatives to conventional org. solvents due to their straightforward prepn. using highly accessible and natural compds. They display also high tunability. Here we present the classification and prepn. methods of deep eutectic solvents. We detail their physicochem. properties such as phase behavior, d., viscosity, ionic cond., surface tension, and polarity. Properties are controlled by the choice of the forming compds., molar ratio, temp., and water content.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXpt1Wru70%253D&md5=ee186b56f00701871396b41d044814b3

      Zeng, Q.; Wang, Y.; Huang, Y.; Ding, X.; Chen, J.; Xu, K. Deep eutectic solvents as novel extraction media for protein partitioning. Analyst 2014, 139 (10), 2565â 2573,  DOI: 10.1039/c3an02235h
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      119
      Deep eutectic solvents as novel extraction media for protein partitioning
      Zeng, Qun; Wang, Yuzhi; Huang, Yanhua; Ding, Xueqin; Chen, Jing; Xu, Kaijia
      Analyst (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 139 (10), 2565-2573CODEN: ANALAO; ISSN:0003-2654. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Four kinds of green deep eutectic solvent (DES) were synthesized, including choline chloride (ChCl)-urea, tetramethylammonium chloride (TMACl)-urea, tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPMBr)-urea and ChCl-methylurea. An aq. two-phase system (ATPS) based ChCl-urea DES was studied for the first time for the extn. of bovine serum albumin (BSA). Single factor expts. proved that the extn. efficiency of BSA was influenced by the mass of the DES, concn. of K2HPO4 soln., sepn. time and extn. temp. The optimum conditions were detd. through an orthogonal expt. with the four factors described above. The results showed that under the optimum conditions, the av. extn. efficiency could reach up to 99.94%, 99.72%, 100.05% and 100.05% (each measured three times). The relative std. deviations (RSD) of extn. efficiencies in precision, repeatability and stability expts. were 0.5533% (n = 5), 0.8306% (n = 5) and 0.9829% (n = 5), resp. UV-vis and FT-IR spectra confirmed that there were no chem. interactions between BSA and the DES in the extn. process, and the CD spectra proved that the conformation of BSA did not change after extn. The cond., DLS and TEM were combined to investigate the microstructure of the top phase and the possible mechanism for the extn. The results showed that hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonding interactions and the salting-out effect played important roles in the transfer process, and the aggregation and surrounding phenomenon were the main driving forces for the sepn. All of these results proved that ionic liq. (IL)-based ATPSs could potentially be substituted with DES-based ATPSs to offer new possibilities in the extn. of proteins.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXmtFShu7g%253D&md5=141dadb7910e79cf2eddd94654cbf5eb

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      120
      Emerging applications of (micro) extraction phase from hydrophilic to hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents: opportunities and trends
      Tang, Weiyang; An, Yena; Row, Kyung Ho
      TrAC, Trends in Analytical Chemistry (2021), 136 (), 116187CODEN: TTAEDJ; ISSN:0165-9936. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) are compds. composed of a hydrogen bond donor and a hydrogen bond acceptor that remain liq. at room temp. DESs are non-volatile, have high thermal stability, and can dissolve many org. and inorg. compds. easily. As emerging green solvents, DESs have attracted considerable attention and are expected to replace traditional org. solvents as an alternative. This review briefly discusses the development of DESs in anal. chem. and introduces the developments of the extn. process. By studying the development process of DESs from hydrophilic to hydrophobic, this paper summarizes the development status of their resp. types in the corresponding extn. field with particular attention on various DESs-based (micro) extn. procedures. Some interesting features and applications are summarized.

      Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F.; Hashim, M.; AlNashef, I. Using deep eutectic solvents based on methyl triphenyl phosphunium bromide for the removal of glycerol from palm-oil-based biodiesel. Energy Fuels 2011, 25 (6), 2671â 2678,  DOI: 10.1021/ef2004943
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      121
      Using Deep Eutectic Solvents Based on Methyl Triphenyl Phosphonium Bromide for the Removal of Glycerol from Palm-Oil-Based Biodiesel
      Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; Al Nashef, I. M.
      Energy & Fuels (2011), 25 (6), 2671-2678CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
      Biodiesel is a remarkable alternative to the decreasing resources for fossil fuels. One of the crit. steps in producing biodiesel is its purifn. from the byproduct glycerol. The content of glycerol permissible must pass the EN 14214 and ASTM D6751 international biodiesel stds. In this work, Me tri-Ph phosphonium bromide as salt and three different hydrogen-bond donors, namely, glycerol, ethylene glycol, and triethylene glycol, were selected to synthesize three deep eutectic solvents (DESs). These DESs were employed as the solvent for the removal of glycerol from palm-oil-based biodiesel. The effects of DES type on the removal of free glycerol, bound glycerol, and total glycerol were investigated. The results revealed that the ethylene glycol DESs and triethylene glycol DESs were successful in removing all free glycerol from the palm-oil-based biodiesel. All tested DESs were able to reduce the content of monoglycerides (MGs) and diglycerides (DGs). Moreover, all used DESs had the tendency to reduce the DGs more effectively than removing MGs. The max. removal efficiency of MGs and DGs was attained by triethylene-glycol-based DESs at a molar ratio of 3:1 (DES8:biodiesel) and 0.75:1 (DES8:biodiesel), with 37.9 and 53.4% removal, resp. The total glycerol was reduced below the ASTM stds. using all tested DESs. The DES:biodiesel molar ratios of 3:1 for DES4 and 3:1 for DES8 were found to be the most effective solvents for reducing total glycerol content, with 40 and 50% removal efficiency, resp.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmsVeqsLk%253D&md5=3af4e845c93323d1bb18e3f93dcfe1af

      GutiÃ©rrez, M. C.; Ferrer, M. L.; Mateo, C. R.; del Monte, F. Freeze-drying of aqueous solutions of deep eutectic solvents: a suitable approach to deep eutectic suspensions of self-assembled structures. Langmuir 2009, 25 (10), 5509â 5515,  DOI: 10.1021/la900552b
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      122
      Freeze-Drying of Aqueous Solutions of Deep Eutectic Solvents: A Suitable Approach to Deep Eutectic Suspensions of Self-Assembled Structures
      Gutierrez, Maria C.; Ferrer, Maria L.; Mateo, C. Reyes; del Monte, Francisco
      Langmuir (2009), 25 (10), 5509-5515CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      This work describes how the prepn. of deep eutectic solvents (DES) in its pure state can be accomplished through a simple approach based on the freeze-drying of aq. solns. of the individual counterparts of DES. DES in its pure state obtained via freeze-drying are studied by 1H NMR, which reveals the formation of halide ion-hydrogen-bond-donor supramol. complexes (characteristic of DES), and by cryo-etch-SEM, which provides insight about the capability of aq. solns. of DES to be segregated in DES and ice upon freezing. The paper also explores the suitability of the freeze-drying approach to incorporate org. self-assemblies (in particular, liposomes of â¼200 nm) in DES with full preservation of their self-assembled structure. This is not a trivial issue given that amphiphilic mols. tend to be readily dissolved (hence, disassembled) in DES. The strategy proposed in this work is based on the freeze-drying of aq. solns. contg. the individual counterparts of DES and the preformed liposomes (also known as large unilamellar vesicles or LUV). The simplicity of the method should also make it suitable for the incorporation of different self-assembled structures (such other types of vesicles and micelles) in DES in its pure state.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVyku74%253D&md5=249c110c97cf07f2f7d9cf934031c1f9

      Dai, Y.; van Spronsen, J.; Witkamp, G.-J.; Verpoorte, R.; Choi, Y. H. Natural deep eutectic solvents as new potential media for green technology. Analytica chimica acta 2013, 766, 61â 68,  DOI: 10.1016/j.aca.2012.12.019
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      123
      Natural deep eutectic solvents as new potential media for green technology
      Dai, Yuntao; van Spronsen, Jaap; Witkamp, Geert-Jan; Verpoorte, Robert; Choi, Young Hae
      Analytica Chimica Acta (2013), 766 (), 61-68CODEN: ACACAM; ISSN:0003-2670. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Developing new green solvents is one of the key subjects in Green Chem. Ionic liqs. (ILs) and deep eutectic solvents, thus, have been paid great attention to replace current harsh org. solvents and have been applied to many chem. processing such as extn. and synthesis. However, current ionic liqs. and deep eutectic solvents have still limitations to be applied to a real chem. industry due to toxicity against human and environment and high cost of ILs and solid state of most deep eutectic solvents at room temp. Recently we discovered that many plant abundant primary metabolites changed their state from solid to liq. when they were mixed in proper ratio. This finding made us hypothesize that natural deep eutectic solvents (NADES) play a role as alternative media to water in living organisms and tested a wide range of natural products, which resulted in discovery of over 100 NADES from nature. In order to prove deep eutectic feature the interaction between the mols. was investigated by NMR spectroscopy. All the tested NADES show clear hydrogen bonding between components. As next step phys. properties of NADES such as water activity, d., viscosity, polarity and thermal properties were measured as well as the effect of water on the phys. properties. In the last stage the novel NADES were applied to the solubilization of wide range of biomols. such as non-water sol. bioactive natural products, gluten, starch, and DNA. In most cases the soly. of the biomols. evaluated in this study was greatly higher than water. Based on the results the novel NADES may be expected as potential green solvents at room temp. in diverse fields of chem.

      Santana, A. P.; Mora-Vargas, J. A.; Guimaraes, T. G.; Amaral, C. D.; Oliveira, A.; Gonzalez, M. H. Sustainable synthesis of natural deep eutectic solvents (NADES) by different methods. J. Mol. Liq. 2019, 293, 111452,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2019.111452

      Sustainable synthesis of natural deep eutectic solvents (NADES) by different methods
      Santana, Ana P. R.; Mora-Vargas, Jorge A.; Guimaraes, Taciana G. S.; Amaral, Clarice D. B.; Oliveira, Andrea; Gonzalez, Mario H.
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2019), 293 (), 111452CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Natural deep eutectic solvents (NADES) based on malic acid-citric acid-water (MA-CA), xylitol-citric acid-water (Xyl-CA) and xylitol-malic acid-water (Xyl-MA) were prepd. according to three different methods: controlled heating and stirring, ultrasound-assisted synthesis (UAS), and microwave-assisted synthesis (MAS), in each case employing a 1:1:10 M ratio. The NADES were characterized by IR spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR), which indicated the formation of intermol. interactions such as hydrogen bonds between the precursors, irresp. of the synthesis method. Thermogravimetric anal. (TGA) was used to obtain the thermal decompn. profiles of the synthesized solvents, which evidenced interactions between the precursors and decompn. temps. higher than 150Â°C. Detn. of the phys. properties showed no significant differences of viscosity and d. among the NADES produced using the different synthesis methods, at a 95% confidence level. Hence, all the methods used for the synthesis of NADES resulted in solvents with similar physicochem. characteristics. The syntheses assisted by ultrasound and microwaves were faster and efficient, while advantages of the stirring and heating method included the use of simpler equipment and the ability to produce larger vols. of solvents.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsFGgsrrL&md5=223c1d32a7139b93b2b71f212183cb29

    125. 125
      Kaur, S.; Kumari, M.; Kashyap, H. K. Microstructure of deep eutectic solvents: Current understanding and challenges. J. Phys. Chem. B 2020, 124 (47), 10601â 10616,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcb.0c07934
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      125
      Microstructure of Deep Eutectic Solvents: Current Understanding and Challenges
      Kaur, Supreet; Kumari, Monika; Kashyap, Hemant K.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2020), 124 (47), 10601-10616CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. In the past decade, researchers have put forth a lot of efforts to conceive a precise structural arrangement and properties of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) that provide designer pathways in order to broaden the application domain of these solvents. However, these contributions are limited to a few exptl. and computational techniques. In this review, we have encompassed exptl. techniques employed to establish the structure-property relationship of bulk DESs along with recent growth witnessed in this domain from a computational perspective. The nanostructuring plays an important role in various task specific applications of DESs. These solvents are found to exhibit unique heterogeneity at nanolength scales, the origin of which is unique and primarily depends on the constituent species involved. The hygroscopic nature of some DESs makes it crucial to explore the structural anatomy of hydrated DESs. Hence, this opens another subdomain to explore the impact of hydration on the bulk microscopic structure of DES and to know whether the nature is destructuring or structuring with respect to the neat solvents. This review highlights the recent successes attained in developing a thorough bulk microstructural understanding of neat and hydrated DESs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXit1eqsbnI&md5=6724f56c66a1af5a90a38282335ee356
      open URL

      Kareem, M. A.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M. Phosphonium-based ionic liquids analogues and their physical properties. Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data 2010, 55 (11), 4632â 4637,  DOI: 10.1021/je100104v

      Phosphonium-Based Ionic Liquids Analogues and Their Physical Properties
      Kareem, Mukhtar A.; Mjalli, Farouq S.; Hashim, Mohd. Ali; AlNashef, Inas M.
      Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data (2010), 55 (11), 4632-4637CODEN: JCEAAX; ISSN:0021-9568. (American Chemical Society)
      New ionic liqs. analogs, i.e., deep eutectic solvents (DESs), have been successfully synthesized. These DESs have been synthesized by the reaction of phosphonium-based salts with different hydrogen bond donors. Many of these DESs have melting temps. lower than 100 Â°C. Preliminary lab. results showed that these DESs can be used in different applications, for example, electrochem. processes, sepn. of sugars, and so forth. Melting temp., d., viscosity, pH, cond., and dissolved oxygen content of the novel phosphonium-based DESs were measured as a function of temp. The type of the salt and hydrogen bond donor and the mole ratio of both compds. have a paramount effect on the studied properties.

    128. 128
      Sitze, M. S.; Schreiter, E. R.; Patterson, E. V.; Freeman, R. G. Ionic liquids based on FeCl3 and FeCl2. Raman scattering and ab initio calculations. Inorg. Chem. 2001, 40 (10), 2298â 2304,  DOI: 10.1021/ic001042r
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      128
      Ionic Liquids Based on FeCl3 and FeCl2. Raman Scattering and ab Initio Calculations
      Sitze, Melissa S.; Schreiter, Eric R.; Patterson, Eric V.; Freeman, R. Griffith
      Inorganic Chemistry (2001), 40 (10), 2298-2304CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors prepd. ionic liqs. by mixing either FeCl2 or FeCl3 with 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BMIC). Iron(II) chloride forms ionic liqs. from a mole ratio of 1 FeCl2/3 Î¼BIC to almost 1 FeCl2/1 Î¼BIC. Both Raman scattering and ab initio calcns. indicate that FeCl42- is the predominant Fe-contg. species in these liqs. Iron(III) chloride forms ionic liqs. from a mole ratio of 1 FeCl3/1.9 Î¼BIC to 1.7 FeCl3/1 Î¼BIC. When BMIC is in excess, Raman scattering indicates FeCl4-. When FeCl3 is in excess, Fe2Cl7- begins to appear and the amt. of Fe2Cl7- increases with increasing amts. of FeCl3. Ionic liqs. were also prepd. from a mixt. of FeCl2 and FeCl3 and are discussed. Finally, the authors used both Hartree-Fock and d. functional theory methods to compute the optimized structures and vibrational spectra for these species. An anal. of the results using an all-electron basis set, 6-31G*, as well as two different effective core potential basis sets, LANL2DZ and CEP-31G is presented.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXitlagsrY%253D&md5=c1581d720678d2a2f028397cd660cf76
      open URL
    129. 129
      Moura, L.; Moufawad, T.; Ferreira, M.; Bricout, H.; Tilloy, S.; Monflier, E.; Costa Gomes, M. F.; Landy, D.; Fourmentin, S. Deep eutectic solvents as green absorbents of volatile organic pollutants. Environmental Chemistry Letters 2017, 15 (4), 747â 753,  DOI: 10.1007/s10311-017-0654-y
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      129
      Deep eutectic solvents as green absorbents of volatile organic pollutants
      Moura, Leila; Moufawad, Tarek; Ferreira, Michel; Bricout, Herve; Tilloy, Sebastien; Monflier, Eric; Costa Gomes, Margarida F.; Landy, David; Fourmentin, Sophie
      Environmental Chemistry Letters (2017), 15 (4), 747-753CODEN: ECLNBJ; ISSN:1610-3653. (Springer)
      Volatile org. compds. are a major source of air pollutants. Absorption is an effective soln. to treat polluted air loaded with volatile org. compds., but most actual absorbents are often toxic and non-biodegradable. Here, we tested eutectic solvent mixts. for the absorption of volatile org. compds. for the first time. The affinity of solvent mixts. for toluene, acetaldehyde and dichloromethane was detd. by measuring vapor-liq. partition coeffs. and liq. phase absorption capacities. Results show that the vapor-liq. partition coeffs. vary, at 30Â°C, from close to zero for acetaldehyde in the mixts. choline chloride:urea, choline chloride:glycerol and tetrabutylphosphonium bromide:glycerol to 0.124 for dichloromethane in the choline chloride:urea eutectic mixt. These values are similar or even superior to those published for ionic liqs. and org. solvents. Solvents based on choline chloride, a food additive, and urea, can solubilize up to 500 times more volatile org. compds. compare to water. Moreover, deep eutectic solvents are easier to prep. and more biodegradable than ionic liqs., which are also toxic. Deep eutectic solvents are more biodegradable than silicone oils, which are also expensive. Furthermore, in terms of recycling, the absorption capacities of the tested solvents remained unchanged during five absorption-desorption cycles. These findings are patented.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtlyntb3E&md5=fc10af715553abe836d36fe70206896f
      open URL

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Biodegradable ionic liquids. Part II. Effect of the anion and toxicology
      Garcia, M. Teresa; Gathergood, Nicholas; Scammells, Peter J.
      Green Chemistry (2005), 7 (1), 9-14CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Although ionic liqs. are generally referred to in a 'green' context, little is known about their degrdn. in the environment. Part I of this series focused on the biodegradability of the commonly used dialkylimidazolium ionic liqs. and the effect of the imidazolium cation on biodegradability. We now report the influence of the anion on biodegradability. Preliminary investigations into the toxicol. of ionic liqs. are also described.

      Design and preparation of room-temperature ionic liquids containing biodegradable side chains
      Gathergood, Nicholas; Scammells, Peter J.
      Australian Journal of Chemistry (2002), 55 (9), 557-560CODEN: AJCHAS; ISSN:0004-9425. (CSIRO Publishing)
      Novel room-temp. ionic liqs. with potential sites of enzymic hydrolysis have been prepd. and tested for biodegradable properties. Compds. thus prepd. included 1-(2-methoxy-2-oxoethyl)-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide, 1-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide (I), 1-methyl-3-(2-oxo-2-propoxyethyl)-1H-imidazolium bromide, 1-[2-(butylamino)-2-oxoethyl]-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide, 1-[2-(butylmethylamino)-2-oxoethyl]-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide, and 1-[2-(diethylamino)-2-oxoethyl]-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide and the corresponding tetrafluoroborate, hexafluorophosphate congeners, 1,1,1-trifluoro-N-[(trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl]methanesulfonamide salts and cyanocyanamide salts. I and 1-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-3-methyl-1H-Imidazolium tetrafluoroborate (II) were evaluated in an aerobic aq. medium inoculated with wastewater microorganisms and the evolution of CO2 was measured (Sturm test). II was on the border of pass level for biodegradability, while I degraded more slowly.

      Gathergood, N.; Garcia, M. T.; Scammells, P. J. Biodegradable ionic liquids: Part I. Concept, preliminary targets and evaluation. Green Chem. 2004, 6 (3), 166â 175,  DOI: 10.1039/b315270g
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      132
      Biodegradable ionic liquids: Part I. Concept, preliminary targets and evaluation
      Gathergood, Nicholas; Garcia, M. Teresa; Scammells, Peter J.
      Green Chemistry (2004), 6 (3), 166-175CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The design, prepn. and evaluation of biodegradable ionic liqs. contg. ester or amide groups in the alkyl side chain are presented. Factors improving the biodegrdn. of surfactants were successfully applied to ionic liqs. These novel ionic liqs. can be prepd. from readily available starting materials in high yield. The introduction of a group susceptible to enzymic hydrolysis greatly improves the biodegrdn. (OECD 301D 'Closed Bottle Test') compared with the commonly used dialkylimidazolium ionic liqs., bmimBF4 and bmimPF6. For the 3-methyl-1-(alkyloxycarbonylmethyl)imidazolium bromide series, the greatest biodegrdn. was obsd. for I (R = n-Bu, n-Pentyl, n-Hexyl, n-Octyl). The corresponding amide analogs proved to be poorly biodegradable.

This research has identified the first ILs which can be classified as readily biodegradable' under aerobic conditions.

Biocompatible deep eutectic solvents based on choline chloride: characterization and application to the extraction of rutin from Sophora japonica. ACS Sustainable Chem.       [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Biocompatible Deep Eutectic Solvents Based on Choline Chloride: Characterization and Application to the Extraction of Rutin from Sophora japonica
      Zhao, Bing-Yi; Xu, Pei; Yang, Fu-Xi; Wu, Hong; Zong, Min-Hua; Lou, Wen-Yong
      ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2015), 3 (11), 2746-2755CODEN: ASCECG; ISSN:2168-0485. (American Chemical Society)
      The development of novel green solvents has been one of the hottest subjects in green chem. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have logically and naturally emerged in the search for more biocompatible and biodegradable solvents. In this study, some basic phys. properties, including viscosity, cond., and d., of 20 DESs prepd. from choline chloride and various hydrogen-bond donors were investigated systematically. In addn., the biocompatibility of the tested DESs was qual. and quant. evaluated using two Gram-pos. (Staphylococcus aureus and Listeria monocytogenes) and two Gram-neg. (Escherichia coli and Salmonella enteritidis) bacteria. A closed bottle test was used to assess the biodegradability of these DESs. The results demonstrated that these choline chloride-based DESs were excellent solvents with extremely low toxicity and favorable biodegradability. Finally, DESs were used to ext. a flavonoid (rutin) from the flower buds of Sophora japonica. An extn. efficiency of 194.17 Â± 2.31 mgÂ·g-1 was achieved using choline chloride/triethylene glycol contg. 20% water. The excellent properties of DESs indicate their potential as promising green solvents for the extn. of rutin with favorable prospects for wide use in the field of green technol.

      Solubility of Metal Oxides in Deep Eutectic Solvents Based on Choline Chloride
      Abbott, Andrew P.; Capper, Glen; Davies, David L.; McKenzie, Katy J.; Obi, Stephen U.
      Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data (2006), 51 (4), 1280-1282CODEN: JCEAAX; ISSN:0021-9568. (American Chemical Society)
      The soly. of 17 commonly available metal oxides in the elemental mass series Ti through Zn have been detd. in three ionic liqs. based on choline chloride. The hydrogen bond donors used were urea, malonic acid, and ethylene glycol. The results obtained are compared with aq. solns. of HCl and NaCl. Some correlation is obsd. between the soly. in the deep eutectic solvents and that in aq. solns. but some significant exceptions offer an opportunity for novel extractive metallurgical processes.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XmtFGls7o%253D&md5=17e0c2653e46c7dc283319d63138ee63

    139. 139
      Martins, M. A.; Pinho, S. P.; Coutinho, J. A. Insights into the nature of eutectic and deep eutectic mixtures. J. Solution Chem. 2019, 48 (7), 962â 982,  DOI: 10.1007/s10953-018-0793-1
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      139
      Insights into the Nature of Eutectic and Deep Eutectic Mixtures
      Martins, Monia A. R.; Pinho, Simao P.; Coutinho, Joao A. P.
      Journal of Solution Chemistry (2019), 48 (7), 962-982CODEN: JSLCAG; ISSN:0095-9782. (Springer)
      A review. A stricter definition of a deep eutectic solvent (DES) is urgent, so that it may become a sound basis for further developments in this field. This communication aims at contributing to deepening the understanding of eutectic and deep eutectic mixts. concerning their definition, thermodn. nature and modeling. The glut of literature on DES applications should be followed by a similar effort to address the fundamental questions on their nature. This hopefully would contribute to correct some widespread misconceptions, and help to establish a stringent definition of what a DES is. DES are eutectic mixts. for which the eutectic point temp. should be lower to that of an ideal liq. mixt. To identify and characterize them, their phase diagrams should be known, in order to compare the real temp. depression to that predicted if ideality is assumed, and to define compn. ranges for which they are in the liq. state at operating temps. It is also shown that hydrogen bonding between the DES components should not be used to define or characterize a DES, since this would describe many ideal mixts. The future of deep eutectic solvents is quite promising, and we expect that this work will contribute to the efficient design and selection of the best DES for a given application, and to model properties and phase equil. without which the process design is impractical.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      open URL

      Florindo, C.; Branco, L. C.; Marrucho, I. M. Quest for green-solvent design: from hydrophilic to hydrophobic (deep) eutectic solvents. ChemSusChem 2019, 12 (8), 1549â 1559,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201900147
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      142
      Quest for Green-Solvent Design: From Hydrophilic to Hydrophobic (Deep) Eutectic Solvents
      Florindo, Catarina; Branco, Luis C.; Marrucho, Isabel M.
      ChemSusChem (2019), 12 (8), 1549-1559CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) consist of a mixt. of â¥2 solid components, which gives rise to a lower m.p. compared to the starting materials. Until recently only hydrophilic DESs were available, and despite their revolutionary role in the alternative-solvents field, important issues in chem., and chem. engineering (such as H2O-related problems and the replacement of toxic volatile org. compds.) could not be tackled. Hydrophobic (deep)-here in parenthesis due to the different depths of the eutectic m.ps.-eutectic solvents are a subclass of DESs where both components are hydrophobic. The low toxicity, high biodegradability, and straightforward prepn. without further purifn. steps of naturally occurring low-cost compds. are among the key advantages. Although research on hydrophobic DESs is scarce (the 1st report was only published in 2015), some interesting features and applications were reported and deserve to be evaluated and comparisons established. This Minireview is divided into 2 parts: The 1st part provides a brief general introduction to DESs and the 2nd part discusses the nomenclature using solid-liq. phase diagram anal., chem. stability, thermophys. properties comparison, and finally the most important emerging fields of application.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmvVCmu78%253D&md5=290aead0c8918010593b42628c359ef7
      open URL

      Shahbaz, K.; Baroutian, S.; Mjalli, F.; Hashim, M.; AlNashef, I. Densities of ammonium and phosphonium based deep eutectic solvents: Prediction using artificial intelligence and group contribution techniques. Thermochim. Acta 2012, 527, 59â 66,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tca.2011.10.010
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      143
      Densities of ammonium and phosphonium based deep eutectic solvents: Prediction using artificial intelligence and group contribution techniques
      Shahbaz, K.; Baroutian, S.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M.
      Thermochimica Acta (2012), 527 (), 59-66CODEN: THACAS; ISSN:0040-6031. (Elsevier B.V.)
      As applications of deep eutectic solvents are growing fast as green alternatives, prediction of phys. properties data for such systems becomes a necessity for engineering application designs and new process developments. In this study, densities of three classes of deep eutectic solvents, based on a phosphonium and two ammonium salts, were measured. Two predictive models based on artificial intelligence and group contribution methods were proposed for accurate estn. and evaluation of deep eutectic solvent densities. A feed forward back propagation neural network with 9 hidden neurons was successfully developed and trained with the measured d. data. The group contribution method applied the modified Lydersen-Joback-Reid, Lee-Kesler and the modified Rackett equations. The comparison of the predicted densities with those obtained by measurement confirmed the reliability of the neural network and the group contribution method with av. abs. errors of 0.14 and 2.03%, resp. Comparison of the model performances indicated a better predictability of the developed neural network over the group contribution method.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      open URL

      Abbott, A. P.; Barron, J. C.; Ryder, K. S.; Wilson, D. Eutectic-based ionic liquids with metal-containing anions and cations. ChemistryâA European Journal 2007, 13 (22), 6495â 6501,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200601738
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      144
      Eutectic-based ionic liquids with metal-containing anions and cations
      Abbott, Andrew P.; Barron, John C.; Ryder, Karl S.; Wilson, David
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (22), 6495-6501CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Eutectic mixts. of zinc chloride and donor mols. such as urea and acetamide are described and it is proposed that these constitute a new class of ionic liqs. FAB-MS anal. shows that the liqs. are made up of metal-contg. anions and cations in which the donor is coordinated to the cation. Data on the viscosity, cond., d., phase behavior and surface tension are presented and these are shown to be significantly different to other related ionic liqs. that incorporate quaternary ammonium salts. The cond. and viscosity are comparable with other ionic liqs. and the data fit well to the Hole theory model recently proposed.

      Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F.; Hashim, M.; AlNashef, I. Prediction of deep eutectic solvents densities at different temperatures. Thermochimica acta 2011, 515 (1â2), 67â 72,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tca.2010.12.022
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      145
      Prediction of deep eutectic solvents densities at different temperatures
      Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M.
      Thermochimica Acta (2011), 515 (1-2), 67-72CODEN: THACAS; ISSN:0040-6031. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Predicting densities of nonconventional solvents like deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as a function of temp. is of considerable importance in the development and design of new processes utilizing these solvents. Because of the nature of bonding existing between the salt and the hydrogen bond donor, conventional methods result in very large deviations. In this study, the d. of DESs based on three different salts was estd. using empirical method. Nine different salts:hydrogen bond donor combinations were selected to test this method. The densities of all DESs were measured at a temp. range (298.15-368.1 K). The crit. properties of salt and hydrogen bond donor were estd. using the Modified Lydersen-Joback-Reid method, while that of the mixt. were calcd. using Lee-Kesler equation. The Rackett equation modified by Spencer and Danner was employed to predict the DES d. The values of measured and predicted densities were compared and the av. of abs. relative error percentage (ARPE) for all DESs was found to be 1.9%. The effect of salt to HBD molar ratio on ARPE in predicted DESs densities was also investigated.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXitFaqtLw%253D&md5=43da381f40b75fa9da8b11614d018d83
      open URL
    146. 146
      Delgado-Mellado, N.; Larriba, M.; Navarro, P.; Rigual, V.; Ayuso, M.; GarcÃ­a, J.; RodrÃ­guez, F. Thermal stability of choline chloride deep eutectic solvents by TGA/FTIR-ATR analysis. J. Mol. Liq. 2018, 260, 37â 43,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2018.03.076
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      146
      Thermal stability of choline chloride deep eutectic solvents by TGA/FTIR-ATR analysis
      Delgado-Mellado, Noemi; Larriba, Marcos; Navarro, Pablo; Rigual, Victoria; Ayuso, Miguel; Garcia, Julian; Rodriguez, Francisco
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2018), 260 (), 37-43CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) based on the cation choline have been proposed to date for a variety of applications due to their remarkable physicochem. properties. The thermal stability is one of the first properties of DESs that needs to be known since it limits the max. operating temp. for which these solvents are useful in many applications. In this work, the thermal stability of eight different choline chloride-based DESs formed using levulinic acid, malonic acid, glycerol, ethylene glycol, phenylacetic acid, phenylpropionic acid, urea, and glucose as hydrogen bond donors (HBDs) has been studied using isothermal and dynamic thermogravimetric anal./Fourier transform IR-attenuated total reflectance spectroscopy (TGA/FTIR-ATR) techniques. Isothermal and dynamic FTIR-ATR were carried out to confirm the formation and to show the structural changes with temp. of the DESs, resp. The onset decompn. temps. of the DESs were obtained from dynamic TGA. However, the max. operating temps. detd. by isothermal TGA in long-term scenarios have demonstrated to be significantly lower than the onset decompn. temps. for every DES studied. The thermal stability and the b.p. of HBDs have a crucial impact on the max. operating temp. of DESs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXlvFKru70%253D&md5=b040a3ee1600695eb8614c21ff42128a
      open URL
    147. 147
      Geiculescu, O.; DesMarteau, D.; Creager, S.; Haik, O.; Hirshberg, D.; Shilina, Y.; Zinigrad, E.; Levi, M.; Aurbach, D.; Halalay, I. Novel binary deep eutectic electrolytes for rechargeable Li-ion batteries based on mixtures of alkyl sulfonamides and lithium perfluoroalkylsulfonimide salts. J.       [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      147
      Novel binary deep eutectic electrolytes for rechargeable Li-ion batteries based on mixtures of alkyl sulfonamides and lithium perfluoroalkylsulfonimide salts
      Geiculescu, O. E.; Des Marteau, D. D.; Creager, S. E.; Haik, O.; Hirshberg, D.; Shilina, Y.; Zinigrad, E.; Levi, M. D.; Aurbach, D.; Halalay, I. C.
      Journal of Power Sources (2016), 307 (), 519-525CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Ionic liqs. (IL's) were proposed for use in Li-ion batteries (LIBs), in order to mitigate some of the well-known drawbacks of LiPF6/mixed org. carbonates solns. However, their large cations seriously decrease lithium transference nos. and block lithium insertion sites at electrode-electrolyte interfaces, leading to poor LIB rate performance. Deep eutectic electrolytes (DEEs) (which share some of the advantages of ILs but possess only one cation, Li+), were then proposed, in order to overcome the difficulties assocd. with ILs. We report herein on the prepn., thermal properties (melting, crystn., and glass transition temps.), transport properties (specific cond. and viscosity) and thermal stability of binary DEEs based on mixts. of lithium bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide or lithium bis(fluoro)sulfonimide salts with an alkyl sulfonamide solvent. Promise for LIB applications is demonstrated by chronoamperometry on Al current collectors, and cycling behavior of neg. and pos. electrodes. Residual current densities of 12 and 45 nA/cm2 were obsd. at 5 V vs. Li/Li+ on aluminum, 1.5 and 16 nA/cm2 at 4.5 V vs. Li/Li+, resp. for LiFSI and LiTFSI based DEEs. Capacities of 220, 130, and 175 mAh/g were obsd. at low (C/13 or C/10) rates, resp. for petroleum coke, LiMn1/3Ni1/3Co1/3O2 (a.k.a. NMC 111) and LiAl0.05Co0.15Ni0.8O2 (a.k.a. NCA).
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XovFektQ%253D%253D&md5=a5e066ccecaa3c658f14c2acfeed0239

      Bio-inspired choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents as electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries
      Millia, Luca; Dall'Asta, Valentina; Ferrara, Chiara; Berbenni, Vittorio; Quartarone, Eliana; Perna, Filippo Maria; Capriati, Vito; Mustarelli, Piercarlo
      Solid State Ionics (2018), 323 (), 44-48CODEN: SSIOD3; ISSN:0167-2738. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The safety issues of lithium-ion batteries require the substitution of volatile and flammable org. components of the electrolyte. In this context, deep eutectic solvents (DESs) represent an interesting alternative to conventional ionic liqs. as green solvents to dissolve common lithium salts. This paper explores two eutectics: i. ethylene glycol/choline chloride (EG/ChCl, 3:1 mol/mol), and ii. L-(+)-lactic acid/choline chloride (LA/ChCl, 2:1 mol/mol). The lithium salts added in both cases were LiN(CF3SO2)2 and LiPF6, both in concn. of either 0.5 M or 1 M. They still retain their liq. properties despite the addn. of relatively high molar contents (up to 1.0 M) of lithium salts. The 0.5 M LiPF6/EG:ChCl electrolyte, in particular, displays ionic cond. of 7.95 mS cm-1 at room temp., and is thus very promising as a green and cheap electrolyte.

      Tripathy, S. N.; Wojnarowska, Z.; Knapik, J.; Shirota, H.; Biswas, R.; Paluch, M. Glass transition dynamics and conductivity scaling in ionic deep eutectic solvents: The case of (acetamide+ lithium nitrate/sodium thiocyanate) melts. J. Chem. Phys. 2015, 142 (18), 184504,  DOI: 10.1063/1.4919946
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      149
      Glass transition dynamics and conductivity scaling in ionic deep eutectic solvents: The case of (acetamide + lithium nitrate/sodium thiocyanate) melts
      Tripathy, Satya N.; Wojnarowska, Zaneta; Knapik, Justyna; Shirota, Hideaki; Biswas, Ranjit; Paluch, Marian
      Journal of Chemical Physics (2015), 142 (18), 184504/1-184504/10CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
      A detailed study on the mol. dynamics of ionic deep eutectic solvents (acetamide + lithium nitrate/sodium thiocyanate) is reported. The study was carried out employing dielec. relaxation spectroscopy covering seven decades in frequency (10-1-106 Hz) and in a wide temp. range from 373 K down to 173 K, accessing the dynamic observables both in liq. and glassy state. The dielec. response of the ionic system was presented in the dynamic window of modulus formalism to understand the cond. relaxation and its possible connection to the origin of localized motion. Two secondary relaxation processes appear below glass transition temp. The findings provide suitable interpretation on the nature of secondary Johari-Goldstein process describing the ion translation and orientation of dipoles in a combined approach using Ngai's coupling model. A nearly const. loss feature is witnessed at shorter times/lower temps. The authors also discuss the a.c. cond. scaling behavior using Summerfield approach and random free energy barrier model which establish the time-temp. superposition principle. These exptl. observations have fundamental importance on theor. elucidation of the cond. relaxation and glass transition phenomena in molten ionic conductors. (c) 2015 American Institute of Physics.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXotlajsr0%253D&md5=2bf3b9d6373dca3ab1ab712851e22487
      open URL

      Surface Tension of DL-Menthol:Octanoic Acid Eutectic Mixtures
      Nunes, Ricardo J.; Saramago, Benilde; Marrucho, Isabel M.
      Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data (2019), 64 (11), 4915-4923CODEN: JCEAAX; ISSN:0021-9568. (American Chemical Society)
      Although they have been known since the early 2000s, it was not until recent years that deep eutectic solvents and eutectic mixts. began to be systematically studied as cheaper and more environmentally friendly alternative solvents. The introduction of hydrophobic, all-natural, neutral eutectic mixts. affords new applications, which need accurate measurements of thermophys. properties. In this work, the surface tension of DL-menthol:octanoic acid eutectic mixts. was studied over the whole range of compn. from 298.15 to 333.15 K. The effects of compn. and water on the surface tension are accessed and discussed. Densities and viscosities were also measured from 293.15 to 353.15 K at atm. pressure.

      Glycerol-based deep eutectic solvents: Physical properties
      AlOmar, Mohamed Khalid; Hayyan, Maan; Alsaadi, Mohammed Abdulhakim; Akib, Shatirah; Hayyan, Adeeb; Hashim, Mohd Ali
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2016), 215 (), 98-103CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have been used in many industrial applications. DES is a mixt. of a salt and a hydrogen bond donor (HBD). In this study, 70 DESs were synthesized successfully based on glycerol (Gly) as the HBD with different phosphonium and ammonium salts, namely Me tri-Ph phosphonium bromide (MTPB), benzyl tri-Ph phosphonium chloride (BTPC), allyl tri-Ph phosphonium bromide (ATPB), choline chloride (ChCl), N,N-diethylethanolammonium chloride (DAC), and tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (TBAB). The DESs were prepd. using different molar ratios of the HBD to the salts. The f.p. of each DES was detd. using Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC). The phys. properties of these DESs, including d., viscosity, cond., and surface tension, were investigated as functions of temp. In addn., the functional groups were analyzed utilizing Fourier transform IR (FTIR) spectroscopy. It is worth noting that these systems have a wide variety of phys. properties, which implies that these DESs would be suitable for diverse applications.

      Abbott, A. P.; Barron, J. C.; Frisch, G.; Gurman, S.; Ryder, K. S.; Silva, A. F. Double layer effects on metal nucleation in deep eutectic solvents. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2011, 13 (21), 10224â 10231,  DOI: 10.1039/c0cp02244f
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Double layer effects on metal nucleation in deep eutectic solvents
      Abbott, Andrew P.; Barron, John C.; Frisch, Gero; Gurman, Stephen; Ryder, Karl S.; Fernando Silva, A.
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2011), 13 (21), 10224-10231CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The electrodeposition of Zn was studied in two deep eutectic solvents. Unlike the metals studied to date in these liqs., Zn electrodeposition is not mass transport limited and the morphol. of the deposit differs in the two liqs. Changing the concn. of solute affects the phys. properties of the liq. to different extents although this is found to not effect the morphol. of the metal deposited. EXAFS was used to show that the speciation of Zn was the same in both liqs. Double layer capacitance studies showed differences between the two liqs. and these probably are due to the adsorption of a species on the electrode which probably is chloride. The differences in Zn morphol. is attributed to blocking of certain crystal faces leading to deposition of small platelet shaped crystals in the glycol based liq.

      Chen, W.; Bai, X.; Xue, Z.; Mou, H.; Chen, J.; Liu, Z.; Mu, T. The formation and physicochemical properties of PEGylated deep eutectic solvents. New J. Chem. 2019, 43 (22), 8804â 8810,  DOI: 10.1039/C9NJ02196E

      The formation and physicochemical properties of PEGylated deep eutectic solvents
      Chen, Wenjun; Bai, Xiyue; Xue, Zhimin; Mou, Hongyu; Chen, Jiangang; Liu, Zhaotie; Mu, Tiancheng
      New Journal of Chemistry (2019), 43 (22), 8804-8810CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have attracted considerable attention due to their unique properties. In recent years, novel deep eutectic solvents based on polyethylene glycol (PEG) have been proposed, which are called PEGylated DESs. Owing to their excellent properties, PEGylated DESs have been applied in many fields, such as extn., biomass dissoln. and material prepn. For better application of PEGylated DESs in various fields, the solid understanding of their fundamental properties is indispensable. In this work, nine PEGylated DESs based on carboxylic acids, amides and ammonium salts were prepd. and characterized by FTIR, 1H NMR and DSC anal. The physicochem. properties including pH values, polarity, d., viscosity, cond., and thermal stability were investigated. Walden plot anal. was also conducted in order to evaluate the ionicity of the PEGylated DESs. The nature of the components plays a vital role in the properties of the PEG based DESs. There is a neg. correlation between the pH values and polarity of the PEGylated DESs, which can be applied to infer the polarity via pH measurement. The d. and viscosity gradually decrease with increasing temp. due to thermal expansion. Except for the ammonium salt based DESs, the PEGylated DESs exhibit a "poor ionic" nature and have a negligible cond. owing to the lack of ionic species. According to the above research, PEGylated DESs with specific properties could be elaborately designed via choosing appropriate components, thus facilitating their application.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      154
      Glycerol eutectics as sustainable solvent systems
      Abbott, Andrew P.; Harris, Robert C.; Ryder, Karl S.; D'Agostino, Carmine; Gladden, Lynn F.; Mantle, Mick D.
      Green Chemistry (2011), 13 (1), 82-90CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      In this work the use of glycerol as a hydrogen bond donor in Deep Eutectic Solvents is studied. The phys. properties of choline chloride mixts. with glycerol are quantified and it is shown that eutectic mixts. can circumvent some of the difficulties of using glycerol as a solvent viz. high viscosity and high m.p. The solvent properties are characterized using polarity parameters and the values are similar to other ionic liqs. although it is shown that this procedure is a poor method of characterizing Lewis basicity. The application of these liqs. to the esterification of glycerol is used as a demonstration of the ability to tune a reaction with the quaternary ammonium halide acting as a quasi-protecting group. The liqs. represent a sustainable way of prepg. non-toxic, tuneable solvent systems.

      Deep Eutectic Solvents: Physicochemical Properties and Gas Separation Applications
      Garcia, Gregorio; Aparicio, Santiago; Ullah, Ruh; Atilhan, Mert
      Energy & Fuels (2015), 29 (4), 2616-2644CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Sustainable technologies applied to energy-related applications should develop a pivotal role in the next decades. In particular, carbon dioxide capture from flue gases emitted by fossil-fueled power plants should play a pivotal role in controlling and reducing the greenhouse effect. Therefore, the development of new materials for carbon capture purposes has merged as central research line, for which many alternatives were proposed. Ionic liqs. (ILs) have emerged as one of the most promising choices for carbon capture, but in spite of their promising properties, some serious drawbacks have also appeared. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have recently been considered as alternatives to ILs that maintain most of their relevant properties, such as task-specific character, and at the same time avoid some of their problems, mainly from economic and environmental viewpoints. DES prodn. from low-cost and natural sources, together with their almost null toxicity and total biodegradability, makes these solvents a suitable platform for developing gas sepn. agents within the green chem. framework. Therefore, because of the promising characteristics of DESs as CO2 absorbents and in general as gas sepg. agents, the state of the art on physicochem. properties of DESs in relation to their influence on gas sepn. mechanisms and on the studies of gas soly. in DESs are discussed. The objective of this review work is to analyze the current knowledge on gas sepn. using DESs, comparing the capturing abilities and properties of DESs with those of ILs, inferring the weaknesses and strengths of DESs, and proposing future research directions on this subject.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjsVWrs74%253D&md5=895a9e93f09fb4d88b2294a1817a5909
      open URL

      Fruit sugar-based deep eutectic solvents and their physical properties

The suggested DESs have many desirable characteristics, e.g. they have low vapor pressure, inflammable, biodegradable, and made from renewable resources.       Solvatochromic Dyes as Solvent Polarity Indicators
      Reichardt, Christian
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (1994), 94 (8), 2319-58CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665.
      This review with 345 refs. compiles pos. and neg. solvatochromic compds. which have been used to establish empirical scales of solvent polarity by means of UV/visible/near-IR spectroscopic measurements in soln. with particular emphasis on the ET(30) scale derived from neg. solvatochromic pyridinium N-phenolate betaine dyes. A discussion is presented on the concept of solvent polarity and how empirical parameters of solvent polarity can be derived and understood in the framework of linear free-energy relationships.

      Pandey, A.; Rai, R.; Pal, M.; Pandey, S. How polar are choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents?. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2014, 16 (4), 1559â 1568,  DOI: 10.1039/C3CP53456A
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      158
      How polar are choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents?
      Pandey, Ashish; Rai, Rewa; Pal, Mahi; Pandey, Siddharth
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (4), 1559-1568CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Developing and characterizing green solvents with low toxicity and cost is one of the most important issues in chem. Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs), in this regard, have shown tremendous promise. Compared to popular org. solvents, DESs possess negligible VOCs and are non-flammable. Compared to ionic liqs., which share many characteristics but are ionic compds. and not ionic mixts., DESs are cheaper to make, much less toxic and mostly biodegradable. An est. of the polarity assocd. with DESs is essential if they are to be used as green alternatives to common org. solvents in industries and academia. As no one phys. parameter can satisfactorily represent solute-solvent interactions within a medium, polarity of DESs is assessed through solvatochromic optical spectroscopic responses of several UV-vis absorbance and mol. fluorescence probes. Information on the local microenvironment (i.e., the cybotactic region) that surrounds several solvatochromic probes [betaine dye, pyrene, pyrene-1-carboxaldehyde, 1-anilino-8-naphthalene sulfonate (ANS), p-toluidinyl-6-naphthalene sulfonate (TNS), 6-propionyl-2-(dimethylaminonaphthalene) (PRODAN), coumarin-153, and Nile Red] for four common and popular DESs formed from choline chloride combined with 1,2-ethanediol, glycerol, urea, and malonic acid, resp., in 1 : 2 molar ratios termed ethaline, glyceline, reline, and maline is obtained and used to assess the effective polarity afforded by each of these DESs. The four DESs as indicated by these probe responses are found to be fairly dipolar in nature. Absorbance probe betaine dye and fluorescence probes ANS, TNS, PRODAN, coumarin-153, and Nile Red, whose solvatochromic responses are based on photoinduced charge-transfer, imply ethaline and glyceline, DESs formed using alc.-based H-bond donors, to be relatively more dipolar in nature as compared to reline and maline. The pyrene polarity scale, which is based on polarity-induced changes in vibronic bands, indicates reline, the DES composed of urea as the hydrogen bond donor, to be significantly more dipolar than the other three DESs. Response of pyrene-1-carboxaldehyde, a polarity probe based on inversion of n-Ï* and Ï-Ï* states, hints at maline to be the most dipolar of the four DESs. The mol. structure of the H-bond donor in a DES clearly controls the dipolarity afforded by the DES. H-bonding and other specific solute-solvent interactions are found to play an important role in solvatochromic probe behavior for the four DESs. The cybotactic region of a probe dissolved in a DES affords information on the polarity of the DES towards solutes of similar nature and functionality.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFCrtr7I&md5=aa15792e0d3b62c0102c1dc52bbfc9de
      open URL
