      Pandey, A.; Pandey, S. Solvatochromic probe behavior within choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents: effect of temperature and water. J. Phys. Chem. B 2014, 118 (50), 14652â 14661,  DOI: 10.1021/jp510420h
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      159
      Solvatochromic Probe Behavior within Choline Chloride-Based Deep Eutectic Solvents: Effect of Temperature and Water
      Pandey, Ashish; Pandey, Siddharth
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2014), 118 (50), 14652-14661CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have shown potential as promising environmentally friendly alternatives to conventional solvents. Many common and popular DESs are obtained by simply mixing a salt and a H-bond donor. Properties of such a DES depend on its constituents. Change in temp. and addn. of water, a benign cosolvent, can change the physicochem. properties of DESs. The effect of changing temp. and addn. of water on solvatochromic probe behavior within three DESs formed from choline chloride combined with 1,2-ethanediol, glycerol, and urea, resp., in 1:2 mol ratios termed ethaline, glyceline, and reline is presented. Increase in temp. results in reduced H-bond donating acidity of the DESs. Dipolarity/polarizability and H-bond accepting basicity do not change with changing temp. of the DESs. The response of the fluorescence probe pyrene also indicates a decrease in the polarity of the DESs as temp. is increased. Addn. of water to DES results in increased dipolarity/polarizability and a decrease in H-bond accepting basicity. Except for pyrene, solvatochromic probes exhibit responses close to those predicted from ideal-additive behavior with slight preferential solvation by DES within the aq. mixts. Pyrene response reveals significant preferential solvation by DES and/or the presence of solvent-solvent interactions, esp. within aq. mixts. of ethaline and glyceline, the DESs constituted of H-bond donors with hydroxyl functionalities. FTIR absorbance and Raman spectroscopic measurements of aq. DES mixts. support the outcomes from solvatochromic probe responses. Aq. mixts. of ethaline and glyceline possess relatively more interspecies H-bonds as compared to aq. mixts. of reline, where interstitial accommodation of water within the reline mol. network appears to dominate.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFOjsrrP&md5=1b1f2cfd49c97d6c6f5332e970ae28ca
      open URL
    160. 160
      Ma, Y.; Wang, Q.; Zhu, T. Comparison of hydrophilic and hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for pretreatment determination of sulfonamides from aqueous environments. Analytical Methods 2019, 11 (46), 5901â 5909,  DOI: 10.1039/C9AY02244A
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      160
      Comparison of hydrophilic and hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for pretreatment determination of sulfonamides from aqueous environments
      Ma, Yuxin; Wang, Qi; Zhu, Tao
      Analytical Methods (2019), 11 (46), 5901-5909CODEN: AMNEGX; ISSN:1759-9679. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Seven hydrophilic and hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (DESs) were prepd. The phys. properties, water soly., viscosity, d. and f.p. of DESs were detd. The characterization of DESs was performed by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The extn. efficiencies accomplished by two distinct approaches, namely, dispersive liq.-liq. microextn. (DLLM) with hydrophobic DESs and the aq. two-phase system (ATPSs) with hydrophilic DESs were compared. ATPSs based on hydrophilic DES were used to ext. sulfonamides, revealing good extn. efficiency. The optimum extn. conditions were the concn. of K2HPO4 being 0.2 g mL-1 and the vol. of DES being 200Î¼L. Under these conditions, the satisfactory recoveries of the proposed method investigated ranged from 87.7 to 95.6% with the relative std. deviation (RSD) of 0.9-3.1% (n = 3). The linear range was 0.10-50.0Î¼g mL-1 for the four sulfonamides. The limits of detection were in the range from 0.003 to 0.006Î¼g mL-1 and the limits of quantification were in the range from 0.010 to 0.020Î¼g mL-1. The results indicated that the proposed method was successfully applied for monitoring sulfonamides in water samples.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F. S.; Vakili-Nezhaad, G.; AlNashef, I. M.; Asadov, A.; Farid, M. M. Thermogravimetric measurement of deep eutectic solvents vapor pressure. J. Mol. Liq. 2016, 222, 61â 66,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2016.06.106
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      161
      Thermogravimetric measurement of deep eutectic solvents vapor pressure
      Shahbaz, Kaveh; Mjalli, Farouq S.; Vakili-Nezhaad, Gholamreza; AlNashef, Inas M.; Asadov, Alec; Farid, Mohammed M.
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2016), 222 (), 61-66CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Knowledge of volatility of solvents in general and ionic liqs. analogs in particular is crucial for thermodn. modeling and proper solvent selection. In this study, the vapor pressure of a selected set of ionic liqs. analogs known as deep eutectic solvents (DES) was investigated by thermogravimetric anal. (TGA). The exptl. measurements were conducted for the practical temp. range of 343.15 to 393.15 K. In general, measurements revealed that DESs have low but detectable vapor pressure. Compared to some common ionic liqs., DESs have higher vapor pressure. It is interesting to know that the vapor pressure-temp. relationship of DESs is more complex than that of mol. liqs. as well as that of most ionic liqs. The conventional Antoine model was not able to explain the variation of vapor pressure with temp. However, the vapor pressure was found to exhibit a noticeable trend with the DES crit. temp. which was estd. theor. The Wagner vapor pressure model was able to predict the vapor pressure with an av. %AAD of 2.89%.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtFynsb7I&md5=b8bd6b67a1c8ae06d08ff3fa5e15f1f1
      open URL

      Vapor pressure of aqueous choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents (ethaline, glyceline, maline and reline) at 30-70 Â°C
      Wu, Sheng-Hong; Caparanga, Alvin R.; Leron, Rhoda B.; Li, Meng-Hui
      Thermochimica Acta (2012), 544 (), 1-5CODEN: THACAS; ISSN:0040-6031. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A new set of vapor pressure data for the aq. solns. of ethaline, glyceline, maline, and reline at different temps. (30, 40, 50, 60, and 70 Â°C) and concns. (20, 40, 60, and 80 wt%) are presented. The data successfully fit the classic Antoine equation, for the temp.-dependence of the vapor pressure, and a Volger-Tamman-Fulcher-type equation, for the concn.-dependence of the vapor pressure. The % AADs for the exptl. and calcd. data were all less than 0.5%.

      Dwamena, A. K. Recent advances in hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for extraction. Separations 2019, 6 (1), 9,  DOI: 10.3390/separations6010009

      163
      Recent advances in hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for extraction
      Dwamena, Amos K.
      Separations (2019), 6 (1), 9CODEN: SEPAF2 ISSN:. (MDPI AG)
      A review. In the over 1,800 articles published since their inception in 2001, most deep eutectic solvents (DES) synthesized have been hydrophilic. The low cost, low toxicity, and bioavailability of DES make the solvent 'green' and sustainable for diverse applications. Conversely, the hydrophilicity of DES limits their practical application to only polar compds., which is a major drawback of the solvent. For the past three years, hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (HDES) have emerged as an alternative extractive media capable of extg. non-polar org. and inorg. mols. from aq. environments. Due to the infancy of HDES, for the first time, this mini-review summarizes the recent developmental advances in HDES synthesis, applications, challenges, and future perspectives of the solvent. In the future, it is believed HDES will replace the majority of toxic org. solvents used for anal. purposes.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsFOjsL%252FN&md5=37655ef4b5ecd16eabc1622a9dcce1df

      Passos, H.; Tavares, D. J.; Ferreira, A. M.; Freire, M. G.; Coutinho, J. A. Are aqueous biphasic systems composed of deep eutectic solvents ternary or quaternary systems?. ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2016, 4 (5), 2881â 2886,  DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.6b00485
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      164
      Are Aqueous Biphasic Systems Composed of Deep Eutectic Solvents Ternary or Quaternary Systems?
      Passos, Helena; Tavares, Daniel J. P.; Ferreira, Ana M.; Freire, Mara G.; Coutinho, Joao A. P.
      ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2016), 4 (5), 2881-2886CODEN: ASCECG; ISSN:2168-0485. (American Chemical Society)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DES) have emerged in the past few years as a new class of solvents with promising applications in several fields. In the present work, the application of DES (formed by binary mixts. of cholinium chloride and carboxylic acids or urea) as phase-forming components of aq. biphasic systems (ABS) is investigated. The mechanisms assocd. with the phases demixing of ABS composed of DES, as well as the DES stability in aq. solns., are investigated to address the crit. question whether DES-based ABS are in fact ternary or quaternary mixts. The DES integrity is destroyed in ABS by the disruption of the hydrogen-bonding interactions of the complex (a result of the isolated components preferential solvation by water), and as confirmed by a nonstoichiometric partition of the DES components between the coexisting phases. As a result, there are no "real" DES-based ABS; instead, there is the formation of ABS composed of four components, where the carboxylic acid used as the hydrogen-bond donor species seems to act as an additive. Finally, these ABS have an outstanding potential to be used in extn. processes, as it is here demonstrated with the complete sepn. of two dyes. However, the volatile nature of short chain carboxylic acids and the nonstoichiometric partition of the DES components in ABS make the development of recovery and recycling steps more difficult to accomplish.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xls1KisbY%253D&md5=6a1c4e540c1c2ca0053cd3b4b0c19a78
      open URL

      Development of hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for extraction of pesticides from aqueous environments
      Florindo, C.; Branco, L. C.; Marrucho, I. M.
      Fluid Phase Equilibria (2017), 448 (), 135-142CODEN: FPEQDT; ISSN:0378-3812. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Wastewater treatment plants do not properly address the removal of emerging micropollutants, such as pesticides, and thus these compds. contaminate water sources of public drinking water systems. In this context, this work focuses on the development of hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (DESs), as cheap extractants for the removal of four neonicotinoids, Imidacloprid, Acetamiprid, Nitenpyram and Thiamethoxam, from dild. aq. solns. In particular, two different families of DESs, one based on natural neutral ingredients (DL-Menthol and natural org. acids) and the other based on quaternary ammonium salts and org. acids were prepd. and their water stability carefully studied through 1H NMR. Only the chem. stable DESs were selected to be used as solvents in the extn. of the four neonicotinoids so that no contamination of the water cycle is attained, while reuse of the DES is possible. The final results were compared with those obtained for liq.-liq. extn. using hydrophobic imidazolium-based ionic liqs. as solvents.

      Solubility of Sodium Salts in Ammonium-Based Deep Eutectic Solvents

      The soly. of sodium chloride (NaCl), sodium bromide (NaBr), and sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) was measured in nine ammonium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs). The aim of the study is to assess the potential use of these DESs as solvents and electrolytes for the sepn. of sodium metal from its salts. The studied DESs were prepd. by combining ammonium salts with various hydrogen-bond donors (HBDs) or metal halides. It was found that the soly. of the sodium salts in DESs increases with temp. in many cases. The max. soly. of NaCl achieved was 100 w = 80 in N,N-diethylethanolammonium chloride:zinc(II) chloride (molar ratio 1:3) at 90 Â°C. In addn., the soly. of the sodium salts was modeled successfully using the non-random two liq. (NRTL) model.

      Hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents as water-immiscible extractants

      Hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (DESs) are presented for the first time. They consist of decanoic acid and various quaternary ammonium salts. These new DESs were successfully evaluated for the recovery of volatile fatty acids from dild. aq. solns.

      Development of deep eutectic solvents applied in extraction and separation
      Li, Xiaoxia; Row, Kyung Ho
      Journal of Separation Science (2016), 39 (18), 3505-3520CODEN: JSSCCJ; ISSN:1615-9314. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Deep eutectic solvents, as a substitute of ionic liqs., have greener credentials than ionic liqs., and have attracted considerable attention in related chem. research. Deep eutectic solvents have attracted increasing attention in chem. for the extn. and sepn. of various target compds. from natural products. This review highlights the prepn. of deep eutectic solvents, unique properties of deep eutectic solvents, and synthesis of deep-eutectic-solvent-based materials. On the other hand, application in the extn. and sepn. of deep eutectic solvents is also included in this report. In this paper, the available data and refs. in this field are reviewed to summarize the applications and developments of deep eutectic solvents. Based on the development of deep eutectic solvents, an exploitation of new deep eutectic solvents and deep eutectic solvents-based materials is expected to diversify into extn. and sepn. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      170
      Deep eutectic solvent-based extraction coupled with green two-dimensional HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS/MS for the determination of anthocyanins from Lycium ruthenicum Murr. fruit
      Sang, Jun; Li, Bing; Huang, Ya-ya; Ma, Qun; Liu, Kang; Li, Cui-qin
      Analytical Methods (2018), 10 (10), 1247-1257CODEN: AMNEGX; ISSN:1759-9679. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This study aimed to ext. and sep. total anthocyanins from Lycium ruthenicum Murr. by combining deep eutectic solvents (DES) with macroporous resin chromatog. and to develop green anal. methods for the detn. of anthocyanins. Choline chloride/1,2-propanediol (1 : 2, mol mol-1) contg. 10% water (vol./vol.) was screened as the optimal extn. solvent, and extn. at 52 Â°C for 45 min using a liq./solid ratio of 20 : 1 gave the max. extn. yield of total anthocyanins (4.45 Â± 0.07 mg g-1). According to the static/dynamic adsorption and desorption tests, LS-32 macroporous resin has the ability to sep. anthocyanins from DES with a recovery ratio above 95%. An off-line heart-cutting two-dimensional HPLC-DAD/ESI-MS method was developed for the qual. and quant. anal. of L. ruthenicum anthocyanins using environmentally friendly mobile phases. Ethanol and a tartaric acid soln. (0.3 mol L-1) were used as the mobile phases of the first-dimensional HPLC-DAD method, and 15 anthocyanin peaks were detected within 17 min. The second-dimensional HPLC-MS method was used to identify the main anthocyanin peaks in the first dimension. Method validation showed that the developed method was accurate, stable and reliable for the anal. of L. ruthenicum anthocyanins. The present study provides an excellent alternative green method for the prepn. and detn. of anthocyanins from plant material.

      171
      Towards a sulfur clean fuel: Deep extraction of thiophene and dibenzothiophene using polyethylene glycol-based deep eutectic solvents
      Lima, Filipa; Gouvenaux, Justine; Branco, Luis C.; Silvestre, Armando J. D.; Marrucho, Isabel M.
      Fuel (2018), 234 (), 414-421CODEN: FUELAC; ISSN:0016-2361. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      In this work, extractive desulfurization of model fuel contg. dibenzothiophene (DBT) and thiophene (Th) as sulfur compds. was carried out using 16 different Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES) based on polyethylene glycol (PEG) and its precursors. The aim of this study is the redn. of the sulfur content of fuels below the environmental regulation (10 ppm), using PEG-based DES as low-cost extn. media under mild conditions and to compare their extractive performance with that of PEG alone, which by itself is a green solvent. For that purpose, 7 different quaternary ammonium and phosphonium salts were combined with four different mol. wt. grades of PEG and PEG precursors such as ethylene glycol and triethylene glycol. The best results were obtained for the DES composed of tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBAC) and PEG400, which showed that it is possible to achieve, in single extn. step, 85% and 68% of extn. efficiency, and deep desulfurization in 2 and 3 cycles, for DBT and Th, resp. In addn., this DES is not sol. in the model fuel and its extn. capacity is independent on the starting sulfur concn. Finally, after being reused six times, TBAC:PEG400 DES still maintained 53% and 17% of its capacity, for DBT and Th removal, resp., and after a regeneration step the performance of the DES was fully recovered.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      172
      Mercury Capture from Petroleum Using Deep Eutectic Solvents
      Warrag, Samah E. E.; Fetisov, Evgenii O.; van Osch, Dannie J. G. P.; Harwood, David B.; Kroon, Maaike C.; Siepmann, J. Ilja; Peters, Cor J.
      Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2018), 57 (28), 9222-9230CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
      Mercury capture is a major challenge in petroleum and natural gas processing. Recently, ionic liqs. (ILs) have been introduced as mercury extractants from oil and gas. ILs yield very high mercury extn. efficiencies (>95%) from hydrocarbons, but their drawbacks include complex synthesis, toxicity, and difficult regeneration after mercury capture. In this work, a new technol. using deep eutectic solvents (DESs) for elemental mercury (Hg0) extn. from hydrocarbons is demonstrated. DESs are an innovative class of designer solvents exhibiting similar properties as ILs, such as low vapor pressure and low flammability, but DESs are formed from inexpensive hydrogen-bond donor and acceptor compds. that are often biodegradable. In this work, four DESs were investigated including choline chloride:urea, choline chloride:ethylene glycol, choline chloride:levulinic acid, and betaine:levulinic acid, where the molar ratio is 1:2 in all cases. The DESs were tested for their thermal stability, d., and viscosity. Their performance for mercury extn. was assessed using satd. solns. in n-dodecane as the model oil. It was found that solvent to feed ratios of 1:1 and 2:1 at temps. of 303.15 and 333.15 K and atm. pressure yield extn. efficiencies greater than 80% for all four DESs. First-principles mol. dynamics simulations probing the solvation in choline chloride:urea indicate a tight first coordination shell for mercury. Calcn. of the Hg-Hg potential of mean force supports formation of a mercury-mercury polycation for a pair of Hg1+ ions, but not for pairs of Hg0 and Hg2+ species. Geometric anal. of the speciation and Mulliken population anal. support a redox reaction involving Hg2+ + 2Cl-.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1eit7bK&md5=dcf57679cef35c8140a82d18ace11abc
      open URL

      New levulinic acid-based deep eutectic solvents: Synthesis and physicochemical property determination
      Li, Guobing; Jiang, Yaotai; Liu, Xiaobang; Deng, Dongshun
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2016), 222 (), 201-207CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Recently, deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have emerged as new and inexpensive ionic liqs. (ILs) analogs. They possess attractive and similar solvent properties with traditional ILs. In present work a serials of DESs were prepd. by pairing renewable levulinic acid (LA) as hydrogen donor with seven quaternary ammonium salts as hydrogen acceptor. The samples were further characterized in the temp. ranging from 293.15 to 333.15 K at atm. pressure with the results of d. (0.99891-1.17735 g cm- 3), dynamic viscosity (12.70-376.50 mPa s), elec. cond. (0.35-8.27 mS cm- 1), and refractive index data (1.44384-1.47273). The temp. dependence of these properties was explored and correlated with simple linear or Vogel-Fulcher-Tamman (VFT) models. The vol. expansivities (Î²), molar volumes (Vm), molar refractions (Rm), and free vols. (fm) values have been calcd. on the basis of d. and refractive index data. The active energy of viscosity (EÎ·), molar elec. cond. (Î), and ionicity were also detd. Partial structure-property relationship for DESs was also investigated. The tunable properties make DESs as a potential reaction medium, electrochem. process medium, solvent and absorbent. Therefore, the detn. and correlation can provide relevant information for the engineering and industrial applications of DESs.

      Mohsenzadeh, A.; Al-Wahaibi, Y.; Al-Hajri, R.; Jibril, B.; Mosavat, N. Sequential deep eutectic solvent and steam injection for enhanced heavy oil recovery and in-situ upgrading. Fuel 2017, 187, 417â 428,  DOI: 10.1016/j.fuel.2016.09.077
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      176
      Sequential deep eutectic solvent and steam injection for enhanced heavy oil recovery and in-situ upgrading
      Mohsenzadeh, A.; Al-Wahaibi, Y.; Al-Hajri, R.; Jibril, B.; Mosavat, N.
      Fuel (2017), 187 (), 417-428CODEN: FUELAC; ISSN:0016-2361. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Recently, Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs) were introduced and investigated as new EOR agents for heavy oil recovery enhancement. In this study, sequential DES and steam flooding was proposed and exptl. investigated as a new scenario for heavy oil recovery enhancement and having potentials for in-situ heavy oil upgrading. DESs used in this study are Choline Chloride:Glycerol (DES1) and Choline Chloride:Urea (DES2). Primary and secondary DES flooding at different concn. followed by high-temp. steam flooding were conducted using 16.5 Â°API heavy oil and Berea sandstone core plugs. DES thermogravimetric anal. (TGA) performed and results verified the relatively high thermal stability of the selected DESs. Maximum decompn. temp. was 320 and 370Â° for DES1 and DES2, resp. This improves their potential for use as chem. additives or pre-flooding agents in thermal EOR methods. Sequential steam flooding after undiluted and 2-fold dild. DES injection recovered an addnl. heavy oil of 12% IOIP compared to steam flooding alone. However, using more dild. solns. (i.e., 20-fold dild. DESs) caused the same and in some cases lower total recovery factor by secondary steam flooding. When followed by steam flooding, DES2 exhibited superior heavy oil recovery enhancement (8-12%) compared with DES1 (1.5-6%) at the same concns. Anal. of physicochem. properties of produced oil for different cases revealed the favorable role of DES in upgrading the in-situ heavy oil. Heavy oil upgrading were quantified through various measurements including increase in API gravity up to 3.5 Â°API, 16.6% redn. in sulfur content or desulphurization and increase in the yields of sat. hydrocarbons. Comparatively, DES1 exhibited better overall performance than DES2 in terms of in-situ heavy oil upgrading.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1Slu7rN&md5=47a0fcca10b96176a80eedf3e0eca9c5

      Khan, M. S.; Lal, B.; Partoon, B.; Keong, L. K.; Bustam, A. B.; Mellon, N. B. Experimental evaluation of a novel thermodynamic inhibitor for CH4 and CO2 hydrates. Procedia engineering 2016, 148, 932â 940,  DOI: 10.1016/j.proeng.2016.06.433
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      177
      Experimental Evaluation of a Novel Thermodynamic Inhibitor for CH4 and CO2 Hydrates
      Khan, Muhammad Saad; Lal, Bhajan; Partoon, Behzad; Keong, Lau Kok; Bustam, Azmi B.; Mellon, Nurhayati Bt
      Procedia Engineering (2016), 148 (), 932-940CODEN: PERNBE; ISSN:1877-7058. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      In natural gas transmission and processing, gas hydrate formation is a major flow assurance challenge which led scientists towards conducting new and more detailed studies on different aspects of gas hydrates inhibitors. Ionic liqs. (IL) recently revealed as novel hydrate inhibitors due to their unique properties like electrostatic charges together with ability to form hydrogen bonding with water mol. lead them viable research area in the field of gas hydrate mitigation. This paper highlighted the exptl. evaluation of thermodn. measurements of tetra Me ammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) for Methane (CH4) and Carbon Dioxide (CO2) gas hydrates. TMAOH belongs to ammonium based ionic liqs. (AILs) which is comparatively economical ILs among the other ILs families. Traditional T-cycle technique with isochoric step heating method was adopted for detg. thermodn. inhibition in this work. Results reveal that TMAOH effectively shift the hydrate equil. curve to upper pressure and lesser temp. regions for CH4 + TMAOH + water system and CO2 + TMAOH + water system. The av. reduced temp. obtained for CH4 + TMAOH + water system is around 1.06 oC while for CO2 + TMAOH + water system, the inhibition effect found to be around 2.09 oC. Therefore, this study provides roadmap for superior alternative for the development of novel thermodn. hydrate inhibitor, which can efficiently control the gas hydrate formation.

      Ramesh, S.; Shanti, R.; Morris, E. Studies on the plasticization efficiency of deep eutectic solvent in suppressing the crystallinity of corn starch based polymer electrolytes. Carbohydr. Polym. 2012, 87 (1), 701â 706,  DOI: 10.1016/j.carbpol.2011.08.047

      179
      Studies on the plasticization efficiency of deep eutectic solvent in suppressing the crystallinity of corn starch based polymer electrolytes
      Ramesh, S.; Shanti, R.; Morris, Ezra
      Carbohydrate Polymers (2012), 87 (1), 701-706CODEN: CAPOD8; ISSN:0144-8617. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A series of polymer electrolytes composed of corn starch (CS), lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) and deep eutectic solvent (DES) were fabricated by soln. casting technique. The DES was synthesized from a mixt. of choline chloride and urea at a molar ratio of 1:2. The addn. of DES is crucial in enhancing the room temp. ionic cond. by increasing the amorphous elastomeric phase in CS:LiTFSI matrix. The ionic transport mechanism is improved, and appreciable amt. of ion conducting polymer electrolytes is produced. The highest ionic cond. achieved for the polymer electrolyte compn. CS:LiTFSI:DES (14:6:80%) is 1.04 Ã 10-3 S/cm. The anomalies that were obsd. with addn. of DES upon formation of neutral ion multiples were visually revealed by the SEM micrographs. The possible dipole-dipole interaction between the constituents was visualized using FTIR upon change in cage peaks.

      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as low-cost and green electrolytes for electrochromic devices
      Cruz, Hugo; Jordao, Noemi; Branco, Luis C.
      Green Chemistry (2017), 19 (7), 1653-1658CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The application of deep eutectic solvents based on choline chloride or lithium chloride with ethylene glycol and glycerol as low-cost, recyclable and green electrolytes for electrochromic devices is reported. Reversible electrochromic devices incorporating DESs as alternative electrolytes and bipyridinium electrochromic probes have been tested and compared to conventional systems.

    186. 186
      Juneidi, I.; Hayyan, M.; Hashim, M. Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability for cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents. Rsc Adv. 2015, 5, 83636â 83647,  DOI: 10.1039/C5RA12425E
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      186
      Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability for cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents
      Juneidi, Ibrahim; Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali
      RSC Advances (2015), 5 (102), 83636-83647CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This study presented the toxicol. and biodegradable assessment of different cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs). They were formed from choline chloride (ChCl) and N,N-di-Et ethanol ammonium chloride (EAC) as salts and four hydrogen bond donors, namely ethylene glycol (EG), glycerol (Gly), urea (U), malonic acid (MA), in addn. to a metal salt, i.e. zinc chloride (ZnCl2), and a hydrated metal salt, i.e. zinc nitrate hexahydrate (ZnN). The toxicity towards Aspergillus niger of pure and aq. DESs was evaluated by observing the inhibition zone using an agar well diffusion assay, and the min. inhibition concn. (MIC) using a broth diln. assay, resp. The MIC values of the DESs varied from 1 to 650 mg mL-1, whereas the inhibition zones changed according to the DES dose amt. Another test for acute toxicity was performed by evaluating the lethal concn. at 50% (LC50) of the same DESs on Cyprinus carpio fish. The LC50 of DESs ranged from practically harmless (e.g. ChCl : EG-DESaq) to highly toxic (e.g. EAC : ZnCl2-DESaq). The toxicity profile of the DESs depended on their concn., type of individual components, and interaction with living organisms. Moreover, the DESs recorded higher toxicity compared to their individual components on fungi. However, lower toxicity was found for the DESs tested on Cyprinus carpio. Types I (org. salts and metal salt) and II (org. salt and hydrate metal salt) eutectics exhibited significantly higher toxicity than type III (org. salts and HBD). This was due to the presence of the innate toxicity of the metal salts. The biodegradability was appraised by a closed bottle test in which all the DESs were found to be readily biodegradable. To the best of our knowledge, there are no previous studies reported regarding the toxicity of cholinium-based DESs on freshwater fish or fungi and the biodegradability of EAC-based DESs. Therefore, this investigation can be used as a benchmark for future development of DESs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFGkurbM&md5=8bbeafa30ad9e4b1096df73eff95f7a8
      open URL
    187. 187
      RadoÅ¡eviÄ, K.; Bubalo, M. C.; SrÄek, V. G.; Grgas, D.; DragiÄeviÄ, T. L.; RedovnikoviÄ, I. R. Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability of choline chloride based deep eutectic solvents. Ecotoxicology and environmental safety 2015, 112, 46â 53,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ecoenv.2014.09.034
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      187
      Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability of choline chloride based deep eutectic solvents
      Radosevic, Kristina; Cvjetko Bubalo, Marina; Gaurina Srcek, Visnje; Grgas, Dijana; Landeka Dragicevic, Tibela; Radojcic Redovnikovic, Ivana
      Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety (2015), 112 (), 46-53CODEN: EESADV; ISSN:0147-6513. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have been dramatically expanding in popularity as a new generation of environmentally friendly solvents with possible applications in various industrial fields, but their ecol. footprint has not yet been thoroughly investigated. In the present study, three choline chloride-based DESs with glucose, glycerol and oxalic acid as hydrogen bond donors were evaluated for in vitro toxicity using fish and human cell line, phytotoxicity using wheat and biodegradability using wastewater microorganisms through closed bottle test. Obtained in vitro toxicity data on cell lines indicate that choline chloride: glucose and choline chloride:glycerol possess low cytotoxicity (EC50>10 mM for both cell lines) while choline chloride:oxalic acid possess moderate cytotoxicity (EC50 value 1.64 mM and 4.19 mM for fish and human cell line, resp.). Results on phytotoxicity imply that tested DESs are non-toxic with seed germination EC50 values higher than 5000 mg L-1. All tested DESs were classified as'readily biodegradable' based on their high levels of mineralization (68-96%). These findings indicate that DESs have a green profile and a good prospect for a wider use in the field of green technologies.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvVGitrbE&md5=8d768400367b3c378f845636e00da992
      open URL

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability for cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents
      Juneidi, Ibrahim; Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali
      RSC Advances (2015), 5 (102), 83636-83647CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This study presented the toxicol. and biodegradable assessment of different cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs). They were formed from choline chloride (ChCl) and N,N-di-Et ethanol ammonium chloride (EAC) as salts and four hydrogen bond donors, namely ethylene glycol (EG), glycerol (Gly), urea (U), malonic acid (MA), in addn. to a metal salt, i.e. zinc chloride (ZnCl2), and a hydrated metal salt, i.e. zinc nitrate hexahydrate (ZnN). (MIC) using a broth diln. assay, resp. The MIC values of the DESs varied from 1 to 650 mg mL-1, whereas the inhibition zones changed according to the DES dose amt.       Hayyan, M.; Hashim, M. A.; Al-Saadi, M. A.; Hayyan, A.; AlNashef, I. M.; Mirghani, M. E. Assessment of cytotoxicity and toxicity for phosphonium-based deep eutectic solvents. Chemosphere 2013, 93 (2), 455â 459,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemosphere.2013.05.013

      189
      Assessment of cytotoxicity and toxicity for phosphonium-based deep eutectic solvents
      Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali; Al-Saadi, Mohammed A.; Hayyan, Adeeb; AlNashef, Inas M.; Mirghani, Mohamed E. S.
      Chemosphere (2013), 93 (2), 455-459CODEN: CMSHAF; ISSN:0045-6535. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      In this work, the cytotoxicity and toxicity of phosphonium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs) with three hydrogen bond donors, namely glycerin, ethylene glycol, and triethylene glycol were investigated. The cytotoxicity effect was tested using brine shrimp (Artemia salina). The toxicity was investigated using the two Gram pos. bacteria Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus, and two Gram neg. bacteria Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The cytotoxicity of tested DESs was much higher than that of their individual components, indicating their toxicol. behavior was different. It was also found that there was toxic effect on the studied bacteria, indicating their potential application as anti-bacterial agents. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time the cytotoxicity and toxicity of phosphonium-based DESs were studied.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtVCgsbbL&md5=ab835834e7316863ae2de5d7ca3da4e5

    190. 190
      Wen, Q.; Chen, J.-X.; Tang, Y.-L.; Wang, J.; Yang, Z. Assessing the toxicity and biodegradability of deep eutectic solvents. Chemosphere 2015, 132, 63â 69,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemosphere.2015.02.061
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      190
      Assessing the toxicity and biodegradability of deep eutectic solvents
      Wen, Qing; Chen, Jing-Xin; Tang, Yu-Lin; Wang, Juan; Yang, Zhen
      Chemosphere (2015), 132 (), 63-69CODEN: CMSHAF; ISSN:0045-6535. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have emerged as a new type of promising ionic solvents with a broad range of potential applications. Although their ecotoxicol. profile is still poorly known, DESs are generally regarded as "green" because they are composed of ammonium salts and H-bond donors (HBDs) which are considered to be eco-friendly. In this work, cholinium-based DESs comprised of choline chloride (ChCl) and choline acetate (ChAc) as the salt and urea (U), acetamide (A), glycerol (G) and ethylene glycol (EG) as the HBD were evaluated for their toxic effects on different living organisms such as Escherichia coli (a bacterium), Allium sativum (garlic, a plant) and hydra (an invertebrate), and their biodegradabilities were assessed by means of closed bottle tests. These DESs possessed an anti-bacterial property and exhibited inhibitory effects on the test organisms adopted, depending on the compn. and concn. of the DES. The mechanism for the impact of DESs and their components on different living organisms can be assocd. to their interactions with the cellular membranes. Not all DESs can be considered readily biodegradable. By extending the limited knowledge about the toxicity and biodegrdn. of this particular solvent family, this investigation on DESs provides insight into our structure-based understanding of their ecotoxicol. behavior.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXktFOms7c%253D&md5=2832cdda99e954605021d0d3ef18efc7
      open URL
    191. 191
      Modica-Napolitano, J. S.; Aprille, J. R. Delocalized lipophilic cations selectively target the mitochondria of carcinoma cells. Advanced drug delivery reviews 2001, 49 (1â2), 63â 70,  DOI: 10.1016/S0169-409X(01)00125-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      191
      Delocalized lipophilic cations selectively target the mitochondria of carcinoma cells
      Modica-Napolitano, J. S.; Aprille, J. R.
      Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews (2001), 49 (1-2), 63-70CODEN: ADDREP; ISSN:0169-409X. (Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.)
      A review with 65 refs. Traditional chemotherapies, aimed at DNA replication in rapidly dividing cells, have achieved only limited success in the treatment of carcinomas due largely to their lack of specificity for cells of tumorigenic origin. It is important, therefore, to investigate treatment strategies aimed at novel cellular targets that are sufficiently different between normal cells and cancer cells so as to provide a basis for selective tumor cell killing. Delocalized lipophilic cations (DLCs) are concd. by cells and into mitochondria in response to neg. inside transmembrane potentials. The higher plasma and/or mitochondrial membrane potentials of carcinoma cells compared to normal epithelial cells account for the selective accumulation of DLCs in carcinoma mitochondria. Since most DLCs are toxic to mitochondria at high concns., their selective accumulation in carcinoma mitochondria and consequent mitochondrial toxicity provide a basis for selective carcinoma cell killing. Several of these compds. have already displayed some degree of efficacy as chemotherapeutic agents in vitro and in vivo. The effectiveness of DLCs can also be enhanced by their use in photochemotherapy or combination drug therapy. Discovery of the biochem. differences that account for the higher membrane potentials in carcinoma cells is expected to lead to the design of new DLCs targeted specifically to those differences, resulting in even greater selectivity and efficacy for tumor cell killing.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjslSmtLk%253D&md5=47f1fea1d9ede2b916903e36e9bbff66
      open URL

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (79), 11749-11752CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DES) as a new kind of green solvent were used for the first time to excellently ext. phenolic compds. from model oil. It was also proved that DES could be used to ext. other polar compds. from non-polar or weakly-polar solvents by liq.-phase microextn.

      Oliveira, F. S.; Pereiro, A. B.; Rebelo, L. P.; Marrucho, I. M. Deep eutectic solvents as extraction media for azeotropic mixtures. Green Chem. 2013, 15 (5), 1326â 1330,  DOI: 10.1039/c3gc37030e
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      193
      Deep eutectic solvents as extraction media for azeotropic mixtures
      Oliveira, Filipe S.; Pereiro, Ana B.; Rebelo, Luis P. N.; Marrucho, Isabel M.
      Green Chemistry (2013), 15 (5), 1326-1330CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The sepn. of azeotropic mixts. is an old engineering problem that cannot be solved by simple distn. processes. One of the current ways to overcome this problem is to use other types of processes, such as extractive/azeotropic distn. or liq.-liq. extn., where entrainers or extn. solvents are applied. Liq.-liq. extn. processes have been emerging as appealing alternatives because they do not require high amts. of energy, volatile org. compds. or high pressures. In this work, deep eutectic solvents (DES) are tested as extn. solvents in the liq.-liq. sepn. of azeotropic mixts. For this study three different DES, all based on choline chloride, were used for the liq.-liq. sepn. of an azeotropic mixt. of heptane + ethanol at 25Â°. The feasibility of DES as extn. solvents was assessed by the detn. of their selectivities and distribution coeffs., and compared with the literature. The data obtained show that DES surpass the performance of existing extn. solvents, leading to an increase in efficiency and a redn. in energy consumption of the overall process.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXms1Glsrc%253D&md5=a9ae53017c4d9fff8e5fd6df4534bea9

    194. 194
      Ruesgas-RamÃ³n, M.; Figueroa-Espinoza, M. C.; Durand, E. Application of deep eutectic solvents (DES) for phenolic compounds extraction: Overview, challenges, and opportunities. J. Agric. Food Chem. 2017, 65 (18), 3591â 3601,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jafc.7b01054
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      194
      Application of Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES) for Phenolic Compounds Extraction: Overview, Challenges, and Opportunities
      Ruesgas-Ramon, Mariana; Figueroa-Espinoza, Maria Cruz; Durand, Erwann
      Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry (2017), 65 (18), 3591-3601CODEN: JAFCAU; ISSN:0021-8561. (American Chemical Society)
      The green chem. era has pushed the scientific community to investigate and implement new solvents in phenolic compds. (PC) extn. as alternatives to org. solvents, which are toxic and may be dangerous. Recently, deep eutectic solvents (DES) have been applied as extn. solvents for PC. They have the advantages of biodegradability and ease of handling with very low toxicity. Nevertheless, the extn. process is affected by several factors: affinity between DES and the target compds., the water content, the mole ratio between DES' starting mols., the liq./solid ratio between the DES and sample, and the conditions and extn. method. On the other hand, PC recovery from DES is a challenge because they can establish a strong hydrogen bond network. Alternatively, another possibility is to use DES as solvent extn. as well as formulation medium. In this way, DES can be suitable for cosmetics, pharmaceutical, or food applications.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Novel choline-chloride-based deep-eutectic-solvents with renewable hydrogen bond donors: levulinic acid and sugar-based polyols
      Maugeri, Zaira; Dominguez de Maria, Pablo
      RSC Advances (2012), 2 (2), 421-425CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Choline chloride (ChCl) was combined with renewable hydrogen bond donors (HBD) to form novel deep eutectic solvents (DES) with m.ps. <100 Â°C. In some cases (e.g., sorbitol or isosorbide as HBDs) chiral DES can be easily produced. Also, the addn. of glycerol decreases the viscosity of DES significantly. In the ChCl : levulinic acid DES case, singular properties were obsd. Thus, equimol. mixts. of ChCl : levulinic acid (1 : 1) formed a crystal at room temp., rapidly melting in contact with air humidity. Addn. of excess of acetone to ChCl : levulinic acid (1 : 2) leads to the almost quant. pptn. of choline chloride, which can be used again to form a DES.

      Adhikari, L.; Larm, N. E.; Baker, G. A. Argentous deep eutectic solvent approach for scaling up the production of colloidal silver nanocrystals. ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2019, 7 (13), 11036â 11043,  DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b01777

      Argentous Deep Eutectic Solvent Approach for Scaling Up the Production of Colloidal Silver Nanocrystals
      Adhikari, Laxmi; Larm, Nathaniel E.; Baker, Gary A.
      ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2019), 7 (13), 11036-11043CODEN: ASCECG; ISSN:2168-0485. (American Chemical Society)
      Conventional colloidal nanocrystal synthesis is conducted in batch formats which produce materials on a scale far below what is required for industrial applications. As a practical soln. to this challenge, we show herein that a task-specific argentous deep eutectic solvent (DES) comprising a 1:4 mixt. of silver triflate with acetamide can be used as a fluidic metal precursor to push the prodn. of silver nanocrystals to large quantities. This approach employs oleylamine as cosolvent, reductant, and colloid capping agent and is shown to quickly produce large amts. of high-quality monodispersed silver nanocrystals (AgNCs) in a simple microwave-mediated redn. (2 min reaction at 200 Â°C). The large initial silver concn. ([Ag]0) of the DES-based reaction medium in turn allows a high colloidal concn. of AgNCs to be accomplished. For an [Ag]0 of 0.50 M, the highest silver concn. which gave uniform AgNCs a colloidal concn. of 54 mg mL-1 was attained, equiv. to the prodn. of â¼58 g of AgNCs per kg of DES reaction medium. Interestingly, although low concns. of metal have been historically preferred in order to suppress uncontrolled nanocrystal growth, aggregation, and fusion, a "size-focusing" effect is evident in the highly concd. regime. Indeed, for an [Ag]0 of 0.30 M, the reaction yielded 15.7 Â± 2.1 nm AgNCs (13% relative std. deviation), which were more uniform than AgNCs made in the [Ag]0 = 0.02-0.26 M range. Notably, little loss in nanocrystal quality occurred under more intensified process conditions (i.e., higher silver concn.) until 0.63 M [Ag]0 was reached. This work highlights the promise of metallic DESs for the purpose of high-vol. colloidal nanocrystal prodn. by novel yet rational synthetic strategies in future nanomanufg. efforts.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Deep-Eutectic-Solvent-Based Self-Healing Polymer Electrolyte for Safe and Long-Life Lithium-Metal Batteries
      Jaumaux, Pauline; Liu, Qi; Zhou, Dong; Xu, Xiaofu; Wang, Tianyi; Wang, Yizhou; Kang, Feiyu; Li, Baohua; Wang, Guoxiu
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2020), 59 (23), 9134-9142CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The deployment of high-energy-d. lithium-metal batteries has been greatly impeded by Li dendrite growth and safety concerns originating from flammable liq. electrolytes. Herein, we report a stable quasi-solid-state Li metal battery with a deep eutectic solvent (DES)-based self-healing polymer (DSP) electrolyte. This electrolyte was fabricated in a facile manner by in situ copolymn. of 2-(3-(6-methyl-4-oxo-1,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-yl)ureido)ethyl methacrylate (UPyMA) and pentaerythritol tetraacrylate (PETEA) monomers in a DES-based electrolyte contg. fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as an additive. The well-designed DSP electrolyte simultaneously possesses non-flammability, high ionic cond. and electrochem. stability, and dendrite-free Li plating. When applied in Li metal batteries with a LiMn2O4 cathode, the DSP electrolyte effectively suppressed manganese dissoln. from the cathode and enabled high-capacity and a long lifespan at room and elevated temps.

      Theoretical Study on Deep Eutectic Solvents as Vehicles for the Delivery of Anesthetics
      Gutierrez, Alberto; Atilhan, Mert; Aparicio, Santiago
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2020), 124 (9), 1794-1805CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
      The solvation and solubilization of selected anesthetic active pharmaceutical ingredients (bupivacaine, prilocaine, and procaine) in arginine-based deep eutectic solvents are studied using a theor. approach considering quantum chem. and classical mol. dynamics. The intermol. forces between the anesthetics and the solvent are characterized, with particular attention to hydrogen bonding, in terms of strength, topol. properties, interaction mechanism, structuring, and dynamic properties of solvation shells. The reported results show the nanoscopic properties that confirm these solvents as suitable materials for anesthetics drug delivery in the liq. phase.

      Hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents in microextraction techniques-A review
      Makos, Patrycja; Slupek, Edyta; Gebicki, Jacek
      Microchemical Journal (2020), 152 (), 104384CODEN: MICJAN; ISSN:0026-265X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Over the past decade, deep eutectic solvents (DES) have been widely studied and applied in sample prepn. techniques. Until recently, most of the synthesized DES were hydrophilic, which prevented their use in the extn. of aq. samples. However, after 2015 studies on the synthesis and application of hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (HDES) has rapidly expanded. Due to unique properties of HDES i.e. d., viscosity, acidity or basicity, polarity and volatility, good extractabilities for various target analytes, which could be altered by careful selection of the hydrogen bond donor (HBD) and hydrogen bond acceptor (HBA) components, HDES are promising alternatives to the traditional org. solvents employed in sample prepn. Moreover, the possibility HDES synthesis of non-toxic ingredients, makes HDES meet all the stds. of green anal. chem. Practical applications of HDES in sample prepn. include conventional liq.-liq. extn., and several types of liq.-phase microextn., as well as solid phase extn. The present review covers a comprehensive summarizing of available literature data on the most important physicochem. properties of HDES playing a key role in aq. sample prepn. methods, their limitations as well as challenges in this area, and a perspective of their future are described.

      Carbon Dioxide Capture with Ionic Liquids and Deep Eutectic Solvents: A New Generation of Sorbents
      Sarmad, Shokat; Mikkola, Jyri-Pekka; Ji, Xiaoyan
      ChemSusChem (2017), 10 (2), 324-352CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review concerning the potential of chem. functionalized ionic liqs. (IL) and deep eutectic solvents (DES) as industrial flue gas CO2 absorbents is given. Generally, incorporating CO2-philic functional groups, e.g., amines, in cation and/or anion UK moieties can promote their absorption capacity; the IL anion portion functionalization is more effective than the cation portion functionalization. DES have favorable solvent properties and can capture CO2, but research is scarce and undeveloped vs. IL studies. It is possible to develop novel DES with promising absorption capacity; however, more studies are needed to det. the DES CO2 absorption mechanism and to clarify how these sorbents can be adjusted and fine-tuned to be best tailored as optimized media for CO2 capture. Topics discussed include: introduction; IL (as phys. absorbents for CO2 sepn.[phys. absorption and Coulombic interactions, CO2 soly.], functionalization [cation, anion], dual functionalization, Il-Il or Il-small org. mol. mixts.); DES (functional groups to adjust properties [f.p., d., viscosity, surface tension], CO2 capture [choline Cl--based, lactate-based, phosphonium- and ammonium-based, task-specific, summary]); and conclusions.

      Capture of Toxic Gases by Deep Eutectic Solvents
      Chen, Yu; Han, Xiaoxue; Liu, Zhenghui; Yu, Dongkun; Guo, Wangxin; Mu, Tiancheng
      ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2020), 8 (14), 5410-5430CODEN: ASCECG; ISSN:2168-0485. (American Chemical Society)
      A review concerning the efficient, selective, sustainable, low cost capture of industrial toxic gases (SO2, NH3, H2S, NO2, NO) by green deep eutectic solvents (DES) is given. DES capture of CO2 was not included since several reviews on that topic have already been published. Topics covered include: introduction; SO2 capture by DES (H bond donors [HBD] and H-bond acceptors [HBA]; mole ratio, temp., time, gas flow rate, and water effects; interaction mechanisms; regeneration); NH3 capture by DES (HBA and HBD, mole ratio, temp., pressure, and water effects; absorption rate; interaction mechanism; regeneration); H2S capture by DES; NO2 capture by DES; NO capture by DES; selective gas capture by DES (SO2 selectivity over CO2, NH3 selectivity over other gases, H2S selectivity over other gases); DES synthesis, cost, hygroscopicity, biocompatibility, biodegradability, stability, volatility, and toxicity; comparing toxic gas capture by ionic liqs. vs. DES; and conclusions and outlook.

      Chandran, D.; Khalid, M.; Walvekar, R.; Mubarak, N. M.; Dharaskar, S.; Wong, W. Y.; Gupta, T. C. S. M. Deep eutectic solvents for extraction-desulphurization: A review. J. Mol. Liq. 2019, 275, 312â 322,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2018.11.051
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      204
      Deep eutectic solvents for extraction-desulphurization: A review
      Chandran, Davannendran; Khalid, Mohammad; Walvekar, Rashmi; Mubarak, Nabisab Mujawar; Dharaskar, Swapnil; Wong, Wai Yin; Gupta, Thummalapalli Chandra Sekhara Manikyam
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2019), 275 (), 312-322CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. At present, greater pressure is continuously applied to the desulphurization process to produce fuel with low sulfur content. Relying on the conventional hydro-desulphurization (HDS) method totally would result in significant increase in the cost due to the required modifications to the HDS unit, as well as increased consumption of hydrogen, electricity and catalyst. Despite extn.-desulphurization method by employing ionic liqs. (ILs) as solvent has gathered attention for the past two decades, the toxicity of ILs led to research works to seek alternative green absorbent as a substitute. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs), a less toxic solvent than ILs discovered in 2001 have been actively researched as a substitute solvent since 2013. This review aims to comprehensively discuss DESs for desulphurization application emphasizing on the factors affecting extn.-desulphurization. DESs as a solvent for extn.-desulphurization exhibited high sulfur removal capabilities. Selection of DESs, extn. time, extn. temp., model oil ratio, multistage extn. and DESs regeneration are deemed to affect the desulphurization yield. Economical raw material and synthesis cost, low solvent to feed treat ratio and beneficial green solvent characteristic exhibit DESs' suitability for desulphurization.

      Wagle, D. V.; Zhao, H.; Baker, G. A. Deep eutectic solvents: sustainable media for nanoscale and functional materials. Accounts of chemical research 2014, 47 (8), 2299â 2308,  DOI: 10.1021/ar5000488
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      206
      Deep Eutectic Solvents: Sustainable Media for Nanoscale and Functional Materials
      Wagle, Durgesh V.; Zhao, Hua; Baker, Gary A.
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2014), 47 (8), 2299-2308CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) represent an alternative class of ionic fluids closely resembling room-temp. ionic liqs. (RTILs), although, strictly speaking, they are distinguished by the fact that they also contain an org. mol. component (typically, a hydrogen bond donor like a urea, amide, acid, or polyol), frequently as the predominant constituent. Practically speaking, DESs are attractive alternatives to RTILs, sharing most of their remarkable qualities (e.g., tolerance to humidity, negligible vapor pressure, thermostability, wide electrochem. potential windows, tunability) while overcoming several limitations assocd. with their RTIL cousins. Particularly, DESs are typically, less expensive, more synthetically accessible (typically, from bulk commodity chems. using solvent/waste-free processes), nontoxic, and biodegradable. In this Account, we provide an overview of DESs as designer solvents to create well-defined nanomaterials including shape-controlled nanoparticles, electrodeposited films, metal-org. frameworks, colloidal assemblies, hierarchically porous carbons, and DNA/RNA architectures. These breakthroughs illustrate how DESs can fulfill multiple roles in directing chem. at the nanoscale: acting as supramol. template, metal/carbon source, sacrificial agent (e.g., ammonia release from urea), and/or redox agent, all in the absence of formal stabilizing ligand (here, solvent and stabilizer are one and the same). The ability to tailor the physicochem. properties of DESs is central to controlling their interfacial behavior. The preorganized "supramol." nature of DESs provides a soft template to guide the formation of bimodal porous carbon networks or the evolution of electrodeposits. A no. of essential parameters (viscosity, polarity, surface tension, hydrogen bonding), plus coordination with solutes/surfaces, all play significant roles in modulating species reactivity and mass transport properties governing the genesis of nanostructure. Furthermore, DES components may modulate nucleation and growth mechanisms by charge neutralization, modification of redn. potentials (or chem. activities), and passivation of particular crystal faces, dictating growth along preferred crystallog. directions. Broad operational windows for electrochem. reactions coupled with their inherent ionic nature facilitate the electrodeposition of alloys and semiconductors inaccessible to classical means and the use of cosolvents or applied potential control provide under-explored strategies for mediating interfacial interactions leading to control over film characteristics. The biocompatibility of DESs suggests intriguing potential for the construction of biomol. architectures in these novel media. It has been demonstrated that nucleic acid structures can be manipulated in the ionic, crowded, dehydrating (low water activity) DES environment-including the adoption of duplex helical structures divergent from the canonical B form and parallel G-quadruplex DNA persisting near water's b.p.-challenging the misconception that water is a necessity for maintenance of nucleic acid structure/functionality and suggesting an enticing trajectory toward DNA/RNA-based nanocatalysis within a strictly anhyd. medium. DESs offer tremendous opportunities and open intriguing perspectives for generating sophisticated nanostructures within an anhyd. or low-water medium. We conclude this Account by offering our thoughts on the evolution of the field, pointing to areas of clear and compelling utility which will surely see fruition in the coming years. Finally, we highlight a few hurdles (e.g., need for a universal nomenclature, absence of water-immiscible, oriented-phase, and low-viscosity DESs) which, once navigated, will hasten progress in this area.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXpt1Kqu7s%253D&md5=63f40c2d591b33d212e2e8644b42f320
      open URL
    207. 207
      MacÃ¡rio, I.; Oliveira, H.; Menezes, A.; Ventura, S.; Pereira, J.; GonÃ§alves, A.; Coutinho, J.; GonÃ§alves, F. Cytotoxicity profiling of deep eutectic solvents to human skin cells. Sci. Rep. 2019, 9 (1), 1â 9,  DOI: 10.1038/s41598-019-39910-y
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Cytotoxicity profiling of deep eutectic solvents to human skin cells
      Macario, I. P. E.; Oliveira, H.; Menezes, A. C.; Ventura, S. P. M.; Pereira, J. L.; Goncalves, A. M. M.; Coutinho, J. A. P.; Goncalves, F. J. M.
      Scientific Reports (2019), 9 (1), 1-9CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Research)
      The tailor-made character of deep eutectic solvents (DES) turns them very attractive to be used in several applications, including in health-related areas such as pharmaceutical, nutraceutical, and cosmetic industries. However, although DES has been touted as "green" solvents, several works proved that their potential toxicity should not be neglected. Using the premise of DES applicability in the cosmetic and pharmaceutical sectors, we chose two cell lines to work as a skin model (keratinocytes HaCaT and tumor melanocytes MNT-1), to assess DES cytotoxicity. The effect of three different hydrogen bond acceptors (HBA) ([Chol]Cl, [N1111]Cl and [N4444]Cl) and three different hydrogen bond donors (HBD) (hexanoic and butanoic acid, ethylene glycol, 1-propanol and urea) were evaluated through a common viability assay (MTT assay). Results were promising since [Chol]Cl and [N1111]Cl- based DES showed good biocompatibility for the tested cells. [N4444]Cl-based DES, however, showed cytotoxicity for both cell lines, with the HBA being the driver of the toxicity. Interestingly, some compds. increased cell viability in the HaCaT cell line, namely [Chol]Cl, ethylene glycol, hexanoic acid, urea, and all [Chol]Cl and [N1111]Cl-based DES and should be considered as targets for future studies. These results highlight their possible use in cosmetic or pharmaceutical formulations.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXot1Squrc%253D&md5=d9a251d601e9c8a8b0584a8f599431b7
      open URL

      Hayyan, M.; Hashim, M. A.; Hayyan, A.; Al-Saadi, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M.; Mirghani, M. E.; Saheed, O. K. Are deep eutectic solvents benign or toxic?. Chemosphere 2013, 90 (7), 2193â 2195,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemosphere.2012.11.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      208
      Are deep eutectic solvents benign or toxic?
      Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali; Hayyan, Adeeb; Al-Saadi, Mohammed A.; AlNashef, Inas M.; Mirghani, Mohamed E. S.; Saheed, Olorunnisola Kola
      Chemosphere (2013), 90 (7), 2193-2195CODEN: CMSHAF; ISSN:0045-6535. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      In continuation of investigation for environmentally benign protocol for new solvents termed deep eutectic solvents (DESs), it is herein reported results concerning the toxicity and cytotoxicity of choline chloride (ChCl) based DESs with 4 hydrogen bond donors including glycerin, ethylene glycol, triethylene glycol and urea. The toxicity was investigated using 2 Gram pos. bacteria Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus, and 2 Gram neg. bacteria Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The cytotoxicity effect was tested using the Artemia salina leach. It was found that there was no toxic effect for the tested DESs on all of the studied bacteria confirming their benign effects on these bacteria. Nevertheless, it was found that the cytotoxicity of DESs was much higher than their individual components (e.g. glycerin, ChCl) indicating that their toxicol. behavior is different. For our best knowledge this is the 1st time that toxicity and cytotoxicity of DESs were studied. The toxicity and cytotoxicity of DESs varied depending on the structure of components. Careful usage of the terms non-toxicity and biodegradability must be considered. More investigation on this matter is required.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhslCrsr7K&md5=504723e3f6d35415297a4895e52ffe51
      open URL

      Selected issues related to the toxicity of ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents-a review
      Kudlak, Blazej; Owczarek, Katarzyna; Namiesnik, Jacek
      Environmental Science and Pollution Research (2015), 22 (16), 11975-11992CODEN: ESPLEC; ISSN:0944-1344. (Springer)
      Green Chem. plays a more and more important role in implementing rules of sustainable development to prevent environmental pollution caused by technol. processes, while simultaneously increasing the prodn. yield. Ionic liqs. (ILs) and deep eutectic solvents (DESs) constitute a very broad group of substances. Apart from many imperfections, ILs and DESs have been the most promising discoveries in the world of Green Chem. in recent years. The main advantage of ILs is their unique physicochem. properties-they are very desirable from the technol. point of view, but apart from these benefits, ILs appear to be highly toxic towards organisms from different trophic levels. DES areas of usage are very spread, because they cover org. synthesis, extn. processes, electrochem., enzymic reactions and many others. Moreover, DESs seem to be a less toxic alternative to ionic liqs. New possibilities of applications and future development trends are sought and presented, including such important solns. of life branches as pharmaceuticals' prodn. and medicine.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXpvVKgtbc%253D&md5=a30162cc4cf1f9b516214c81050b22b7
      open URL
    210. 210
      Earle, M. J.; EsperanÃ§a, J. M.; Gilea, M. A.; Canongia Lopes, J. N.; Rebelo, L. P.; Magee, J. W.; Seddon, K. R.; Widegren, J. A. The distillation and volatility of ionic liquids. Nature 2006, 439 (7078), 831â 834,  DOI: 10.1038/nature04451
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      210
      The distillation and volatility of ionic liquids
      Earle, Martyn J.; Esperanca, Jose M. S. S.; Gilea, Manuela A.; Canongia Lopes, Jose N.; Rebelo, Luis P. N.; Magee, Joseph W.; Seddon, Kenneth R.; Widegren, Jason A.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2006), 439 (7078), 831-834CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      It is widely believed that a defining characteristic of ionic liqs. (or low-temp. molten salts) is that they exert no measurable vapor pressure, and hence cannot be distd. Here we demonstrate that this is unfounded, and that many ionic liqs. can be distd. at low pressure without decompn. Ionic liqs. represent matter solely composed of ions, and so are perceived as non-volatile substances. During the last decade, interest in the field of ionic liqs. has burgeoned, producing a wealth of intellectual and technol. challenges and opportunities for the prodn. of new chem. and extractive processes, fuel cells and batteries, and new composite materials. Much of this potential is underpinned by their presumed involatility. This characteristic, however, can severely restrict the attainability of high purity levels for ionic liqs. (when they contain poorly volatile components) in recycling schemes, as well as excluding their use in gas-phase processes. We anticipate that our demonstration that some selected families of commonly used aprotic ionic liqs. can be distd. at 200-300 Â°C and low pressure, with concomitant recovery of significant amts. of pure substance, will permit these currently excluded applications to be realized.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhsVSkurk%253D&md5=9e8d177c2100d4ecc45c62f3ca92c357
      open URL
    211. 211
      Leitch, A. C.; Abdelghany, T. M.; Probert, P. M.; Dunn, M. P.; Meyer, S. K.; Palmer, J. M.; Cooke, M. P.; Blake, L. I.; Morse, K.; Rosenmai, A. K. The toxicity of the methylimidazolium ionic liquids, with a focus on M8OI and hepatic effects. Food Chem. Toxicol. 2020, 136, 111069,  DOI: 10.1016/j.fct.2019.111069
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      211
      The toxicity of the methylimidazolium ionic liquids, with a focus on M8OI and hepatic effects
      Leitch, Alistair C.; Abdelghany, Tarek M.; Probert, Philip M.; Dunn, Michael P.; Meyer, Stephanie K.; Palmer, Jeremy M.; Cooke, Martin P.; Blake, Lynsay I.; Morse, Katie; Rosenmai, Anna K.; Oskarsson, Agneta; Bates, Lucy; Figueiredo, Rodrigo S.; Ibrahim, Ibrahim; Wilson, Colin; Abdelkader, Noha F.; Jones, David E.; Blain, Peter G.; Wright, Matthew C.
      Food and Chemical Toxicology (2020), 136 (), 111069CODEN: FCTOD7; ISSN:0278-6915. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Ionic liqs. are a diverse range of charged chems. with low volatility and often liqs. at ambient temps. This characteristic has in part lead to them being considered environmentally-friendly replacements for existing volatile solvents. However, methylimidazolium ionic liqs. are slow to break down in the environment and a recent study at Newcastle detected 1 octyl 3 methylimidazolium (M8OI) - an 8 carbon variant methylimidazolium ionic liq. - in soils in close proximity to a landfill site. The current M8OI toxicity database in cultured mammalian cells, in exptl. animal studies and in model indicators of environmental impact are reviewed. Selected anal. data from the Newcastle study suggest the soils in close proximity to the landfill site, an urban soil lacking overt contamination, had variable levels of M8OI. The potential for M8OI - or a structurally related ionic liq. - to trigger primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), an autoimmune liver disease thought to be triggered by an unknown agent(s) in the environment, is reviewed.

    213. 213
      Jia, H.; Huang, P.; Han, Y.; Wang, Q.; Jia, K.; Sun, T.; Zhang, F.; Yan, H.; Lv, K. Investigation for the novel use of a typical deep eutectic solvent as a potential shale inhibitor. Energy Sources, Part A: Recovery, Utilization, and Environmental Effects 2022, 44 (1), 1402â 1415,  DOI: 10.1080/15567036.2019.1643953
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      213
      Investigation for the novel use of a typical deep eutectic solvent as a potential shale inhibitor
      Jia, Han; Huang, Pan; Han, Yugui; Wang, Qiuxia; Jia, Kaile; Sun, Tunan; Zhang, Fan; Yan, Hui; Lv, Kaihe
      Energy Sources, Part A: Recovery, Utilization, and Environmental Effects (2022), 44 (1), 1402-1415CODEN: ESPACB; ISSN:1556-7036. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
      The hydration and swelling of shale cause borehole instability and seriously threaten the drilling safety, esp. for the use of water-based drilling fluids. In this paper, the potential application of a typical deep eutectic solvent CU-DES comprised of choline chloride and urea (molar ratio 1:2) as a novel shale inhibitor was investigated for the first time. The inhibitive properties of CU-DES were evaluated by expts. such as bentonite inhibition test, linear swelling test, and shale cuttings hot-rolling dispersion test. Compared with traditional inhibitors KCl and polyether diamine (PDA), CU-DES with a lower concn. exhibited the much higher inhibitive capacity. Furthermore, CU-DES maintained excellent performance even at high temp. (160Â°C), which made it possible to utilize in high-temp. well drilling. To explain the inhibition mechanism of CU-DES, a series of anal. methods, including particle size distribution measurement, Zeta potential measurement, SEM, FTIR, and XRD were conducted. The results demonstrated that the great inhibitive properties of CU-DES were mainly dependent on both the electrostatic attraction and the hydrogen bond between CU-DES and clay.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtl2itrnM&md5=7ecbeadfb5874e5e7fcb7040c1386884
      open URL

      Jia, H.; Huang, P.; Wang, Q.; Han, Y.; Wang, S.; Zhang, F.; Pan, W.; Lv, K. Investigation of inhibition mechanism of three deep eutectic solvents as potential shale inhibitors in water-based drilling fluids. Fuel 2019, 244, 403â 411,  DOI: 10.1016/j.fuel.2019.02.018
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      214
      Investigation of inhibition mechanism of three deep eutectic solvents as potential shale inhibitors in water-based drilling fluids
      Jia, Han; Huang, Pan; Wang, Qiuxia; Han, Yugui; Wang, Shaoyan; Zhang, Fan; Pan, Wei; Lv, Kaihe
      Fuel (2019), 244 (), 403-411CODEN: FUELAC; ISSN:0016-2361. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Three different deep eutectic solvents CM-DES, CP-DES and CIM-DES were synthesized and investigated for their novel use as shale inhibitors. Their inhibitive properties were evaluated and compared with traditional inhibitor KCl and currently popular inhibitor polyether diamine (PDA) through the inhibition tests such as bentonite inhibition test, linear swelling test, shale cuttings hot-rolling dispersion test, etc. All three DESs presented remarkable inhibition performance with lower concns. and performed quite well even at high temp. (160 Â°C). Based on the results of SEM, Zeta potential measurement, surface tension measurement, thermogravimetric anal. and X-ray diffraction anal., we proposed that the great inhibitive properties of DESs were probably attributed to the electrostatic attraction and hydrogen bond between DESs and clay, and the different structures of DESs resulted in different inhibitive capacity. With the excellent inhibitive properties, the synthesized DESs demonstrated potential application as effective shale inhibitors in water-based drilling fluids.

      Beg, M.; Haider, M. B.; Thakur, N. K.; Husein, M.; Sharma, S.; Kumar, R. Clay-water interaction inhibition using amine and glycol-based deep eutectic solvents for efficient drilling of shale formations. J. Mol. Liq. 2021, 340, 117134,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2021.117134
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      215
      Clay-water interaction inhibition using amine and glycol-based deep eutectic solvents for efficient drilling of shale formations
      Beg, Mukarram; Haider, Mohd Belal; Thakur, Nitu Kumari; Husein, Maen; Sharma, Shivanjali; Kumar, Rakesh
      Journal of Molecular Liquids (2021), 340 (), 117134CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Water-based muds (WBMs) are preferred over oil-based muds owing to their lower cost and environmentally friendly nature. However, shale instability arising from clay-water interaction is a challenging concern. The current work explores the potential of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as shale stabilizers for WBMs. Four amine and glycol-based DESs with different chem. compn. were synthesized in the lab. The rheol. and filtration properties of WBMs showed that DES-A, which is composed of tetra-Bu ammonium bromide and diethanol amine, and DES-B, which is composed of tetra-Bu ammonium bromide and diethylene glycol, with less sterically hindered cationic functionality improved the mud functionality. Shale inhibition performance of DESs was collected from capillary suction timer, linear swell meter and shale disintegration tests. These tests revealed that DES-A and DES-B are highly efficient and outperform the conventional shale inhibitor KCl and the com. available ionic liq. 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BMIM[Cl]). Shale swelling in presence of 0.2 w/v% DES-A and DES-B decreased by â¼54.6% and â¼70.9%, resp. Moreover, shale recovery improved by â¼17.2% and â¼18.2% and capillary suction time decreased by 45% and 48% in presence of 0.5 w/v% of DES-A and DES-B, resp. The quaternary ammonium functionality helped in shale stabilization which was further improved due to the presence of -OH group in the hydrogen bond donor in DESs. Quick cost anal. showed the feasibility of industry scale application of DES-A and DES-B as shale inhibitors into WBMs.

    216. 216
      Ma, J.; Pang, S.; Zhou, W.; Xia, B.; An, Y. Novel deep eutectic solvents for stabilizing clay and inhibiting shale hydration. Energy Fuels 2021, 35 (9), 7833â 7843,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.energyfuels.1c00319
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      216
      Novel Deep Eutectic Solvents for Stabilizing Clay and Inhibiting Shale Hydration
      Ma, Jingyuan; Pang, Shaocong; Zhou, Wei; Xia, Boru; An, Yuxiu
      Energy & Fuels (2021), 35 (9), 7833-7843CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
      The hydration and swelling of shale caused by water in water-based drilling fluids is one of the most important problems that causes wellbore instability. The development of high-performance shale inhibitors is an important prerequisite for ensuring the drilling of shale formations. In this study, four deep eutectic solvents (DESs) based on choline chloride (urea-DES, Gly-DES, Oxa-DES, and Cit-DES) were synthesized and introduced as promising shale inhibitors. Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FT-IR) and hydrogen NMR spectroscopy (1H NMR) were used to characterize the structural information on DESs. The inhibition ability of DESs was evaluated by a bentonite inhibition test, a linear swelling test, and a settlement test. Compared with the traditional inhibitors, such as potassium chloride (KCl) and polyether amine, the four DESs can effectively inhibit the hydration and swelling of shale. Five wt % DESs can maintain low rheol. parameters when the content of sodium bentonite (Na-bent) was as high as 40 wt %. Among them, Gly-DES not only exhibited the most efficient inhibition capability but also had the advantage of not affecting the basic performance of the drilling fluid. Inhibitory mechanism anal. showed that the electrostatic interaction and hydrogen bonding between DESs and sodium bentonite (Na-bent) are the most important factors to inhibit clay hydration. Besides, the redn. of the surface tension of the liq. by DESs effectively weakened the driving force for water to penetrate the Na-bent layer. Finally, it is important to note that, although DESs exhibited strong inhibitory capabilities, some DESs, such as Oxa-DES and Cit-DES, are prone to adversely affect the basic performance of drilling fluids. Therefore, a careful selection is required.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXpt1Git7o%253D&md5=03499eb91da138133317a48ab396c713
      open URL
