    218. 218
      Palmelund, H.; Rantanen, J.; LÃ¶bmann, K. Deliquescence behavior of deep eutectic solvents. Applied Sciences 2021, 11 (4), 1601,  DOI: 10.3390/app11041601
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      218
      Deliquescence behavior of deep eutectic solvents
      Palmelund, Henrik; Rantanen, Jukka; Loebmann, Korbinian
      Applied Sciences (2021), 11 (4), 1601CODEN: ASPCC7; ISSN:2076-3417. (MDPI AG)
      Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) are formed by a hydrogen bond donor and an acceptor. The hydrogen bond interactions between these two components significantly depress the melting temp. of the mixt. DESs have been used as an alternative for org. solvents in various branches of the chem. industry. Many DESs are very hygroscopic and water is known to change the properties of DESs, but there has neven been a systematic study performed on the deliquesence behavior of DESs. Therefore, this study investigated the thermal and deliquescent behavior of four DESs. The DES mixts. were stored in desiccators at different relative humidities (RH) to investigate the crit. RH (RH0) for deliquescence. It was found that, due to the formation of a eutonic mixt., the RH0 to induce deliquescence for a given DES mixt. was lower compared to the individual components comprising the DES. The results showed that, even though all investigated DESs had eutectic melting temps. above room temp., but due to the low RH0, they were able to appear liq. at room temp. under ambient conditions. The eutonic and eutectic compns. were identified at different compns. for the DESs. The results emphasize that great care must be taken to control the process and storage conditions for DESs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXhsFSjtbzF&md5=f465c46fb982725989a61a9ff2b359b3
      open URL

      Dai, Y.; Witkamp, G.-J.; Verpoorte, R.; Choi, Y. H. Tailoring properties of natural deep eutectic solvents with water to facilitate their applications. Food chemistry 2015, 187, 14â 19,  DOI: 10.1016/j.foodchem.2015.03.123
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      219
      Tailoring properties of natural deep eutectic solvents with water to facilitate their applications
      Dai, Yuntao; Witkamp, Geert-Jan; Verpoorte, Robert; Choi, Young Hae
      Food Chemistry (2015), 187 (), 14-19CODEN: FOCHDJ; ISSN:0308-8146. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Previously it was demonstrated that natural deep eutectic solvents (NADES) are promising green solvents for the extn. of natural products. However, despite their potential, an obvious disadvantage of NADES is the high viscosity. Here we explored the diln. effect on the structures and physicochem. properties of NADES and their improvements of applications using quercetin and carthamin. The results of FT-IR and 1H NMR expts. demonstrated that there are intensive H-bonding interactions between the two components of NADES and diln. with water caused the interactions weaken gradually and even disappeared completely at around 50% (vol./vol.) water addn. A small amt. of water could reduce the viscosity of NADES to the range of water and increase the cond. by up to 100 times for some NADES. This study provides the basis for modulating NADES in a controllable way for their applications in food processing, enzyme reactions, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics.

Several NSAIDs are readily sol. in various DESs to a high concn. Aspirin, a hydrolabile NSAID, was 8.2-fold more stable against cleavage in DES than in water.

      Shah, D.; Mjalli, F. S. Effect of water on the thermo-physical properties of Reline: An experimental and molecular simulation based approach. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2014, 16 (43), 23900â 23907,  DOI: 10.1039/C4CP02600D
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      221
      Effect of water on the thermo-physical properties of Reline: An experimental and molecular simulation based approach
      Shah, Dhawal; Mjalli, Farouq S.
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (43), 23900-23907CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Increasing applications of ionic liqs. and their analogs, Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs), requires further study into the effect of moisture content on the physicochem. characteristics of these fluids. Although it is common practice to synthesize these fluids in a moisture-controlled environment, as moisture is generally considered to have an impact on their properties, there are no systematic studies on this. The authors herein examine the effects of water on Reline, a Type-III DES composed of urea and choline chloride. Expts. were performed to obtain the phys. properties of aq. Reline soln. The authors obsd. moderate changes in d., speed of sound, refractive index, and pH with increasing water fraction; however, the change in viscosity and cond. was strong and exponential. Mol. dynamics simulations were performed to analyze the intermol. interactions of Reline and aq. Reline solns. The simulations primarily present the significance of urea-anion interaction to explain the low m.p. of the DES. In the presence of water, the anion is preferentially hydrated as compared to urea or the cation. More interestingly, simulations help to classify the effects of water into different regimes. At low water fractions (<5%) the urea-urea interactions are enhanced, as is revealed through the hydrogen bond anal. Beyond 25% water fractions, the components of Reline are individually hydrated and have high diffusivity, which is further reflected in the change in transport properties. The results presented herein provide valuable information on aq. Reline solns. both in terms of exptl. data and mol. insights, which in turn, the authors believe, might assist in developing further applications of Reline and other related DESs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVSmt7fN&md5=ad7f218251e9d12ea46919ac1e66e26e
      open URL

      Rathore, A. S. Roadmap for implementation of quality by design (QbD) for biotechnology products. Trends Biotechnol. 2009, 27 (9), 546â 553,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tibtech.2009.06.006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      222
      Roadmap for implementation of quality by design (QbD) for biotechnology products
      Rathore, Anurag S.
      Trends in Biotechnology (2009), 27 (9), 546-553CODEN: TRBIDM; ISSN:0167-7799. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Quality by design (QbD) was receiving a lot of attention in the pharmaceutical community of late. Successful QbD implementation requires a thorough understanding of the relationship between the crit. quality attributes (CQAs) and the clin. properties of the product, the relationship between the process and CQAs and the variability in raw materials. This article presents a roadmap for successful QbD implementation for therapeutic biotechnol. products. The approach presented here is aligned with existing regulatory guidance documents. Key developments are reviewed and case studies are used to illustrate these concepts. It is concluded that although several QbD concepts are being practiced by the biotechnol. industry, successful dialogue and partnership between the industry and its regulators will be the key to successful QbD implementation.

      Quainoo, A. K.; Negash, B. M.; Bavoh, C. B.; Idris, A. Natural amino acids as potential swelling and dispersion inhibitors for montmorillonite-rich shale formations. J. Pet. Sci. Eng. 2021, 196, 107664,  DOI: 10.1016/j.petrol.2020.107664
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      223
      Natural amino acids as potential swelling and dispersion inhibitors for montmorillonite-rich shale formations
      Quainoo, Ato Kwamena; Negash, Berihun Mamo; Bavoh, Cornelius B.; Idris, Alamin
      Journal of Petroleum Science & Engineering (2021), 196 (), 107664CODEN: JPSEE6; ISSN:0920-4105. (Elsevier B.V.)
      In this paper, the destabilization inhibition potentials and mechanisms of Alanine, Arginine, and Proline on montmorillonite clay were investigated. A swelling test was done using an M4600 HPHT Linear swell meter at 1000 psi, 25Â°C, and 2 wt% inhibitor solns. Shear rates and temps. in the range of 0.01 s-1 to 1000 s-1 and 25Â°C 50Â°C, resp., were applied on a high-precision Discovery Hybrid Rheometer to investigate the effect of the amino acids on the suspension's rheol. Also, the inhibitors' neutralization and surface modification properties were detd. via zeta potential, wettability alteration, and FTIR analyses using the nano zeta sizer, goniometer, and the spectrometer resp. Furthermore, COSMO-RS was employed to study the hydrogen bonding interactions of amino acids and water. Upon completion, Proline displayed the best inhibition performance reducing the swelling of the montmorillonite by 22.5%, whiles KCl only showed a 17.8% redn. Also, the rheol. tests confirmed that the amino acids pos. enhanced the base fluid properties. In addn., Proline, Alanine, and Arginine altered the surface of the clay mineral by 89%, 64%, and 38%, resp., when compared to the base fluid. This made their clay surfaces less hydrophilic and thus, reduced the attraction between water mols. and the clay mineral.

      Alemdar, A.; GÃ¼ngÃ¶r, N.; Ece, O.; Atici, O. The rheological properties and characterization of bentonite dispersions in the presence of non-ionic polymer PEG. J. Mater. Sci. 2005, 40 (1), 171â 177,  DOI: 10.1007/s10853-005-5703-4

      226
      The rheological properties and characterization of bentonite dispersions in the presence of non-ionic polymer PEG
      Alemdar, A.; Guengoer, N.; Ece, O. I.; Atici, O.
      Journal of Materials Science (2005), 40 (1), 171-177CODEN: JMTSAS; ISSN:0022-2461. (Springer)
      The effect of poly(ethylene glycol) on the flow behavior of Ca-bentonite and soda activated bentonite dispersions was characterized by the plastic viscosity, the relative viscosity and the yield values. In the range 0.025-12.5 mol/m3, poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG400, PEG3000, PEG8000) was added to bentonite-water systems in different concns. Three layered phases with different basal spacings for each Ca- and Na-bentonites were obtained, as shown by XRD studies. The max. swelling had a basal spacing at 1.82 nm for both PEG400 contg. Ca- and Na-bentonites. In addn., expanded basal spacings are displayed at 1.91 nm for Ca- and 2.08 nm for PEG8000 contg. Na-bentonites. After the PEG addn., some significant changes in rheol. properties were obsd.; corresponding changes were also found during XRD and IR studies. The results are interpreted according to the type of bentonites, mol. wt. of PEG and their concns.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhsVKiur0%253D&md5=975426e9d2e9c2207818d13771af7703
      open URL
    227. 227
      Okoro, E. E.; Igwilo, K. C.; Mamudu, A. O.; Ekeinde, E. B.; Dosunmu, A. Data on shale-water based drilling fluid interaction for drilling operation. Data in brief 2018, 19, 1620â 1626,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dib.2018.06.014
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      227
      Data on shale-water based drilling fluid interaction for drilling operation
      Okoro Emeka Emmanuel; Igwilo Kevin C; Mamudu Angela Onose; Ekeinde Evelyn Bose; Dosunmu Adewale
      Data in brief (2018), 19 (), 1620-1626 ISSN:2352-3409.
      The shale dispersion test (rolling test) is a common procedure that is used to measure the interactions between drilling fluids and shales. The shale rolling test depends on the moisture content of the shale, the shale composition, the viscosity of the test fluid, the rotation speed of the rollers, and the test temperature. The rheological behavior of the test fluid has the strongest influence on test results. The data was generated experimentally, shale samples from Agbada formation Niger-Delta was used. These shale samples were cored at a depth of 2000 ft and 3400 ft. Water based mud that will minimize shale dispersion and swelling of shale was formulated. The dispersion test was conducted, and it involves exposing a weighted quantity of sized shale to the formulated mud in roller-oven. This test is used to design fluids and screen the effectiveness of inhibitor additives to maintain the integrity of the cuttings and minimize the interaction of fluids with the shale sections during the drilling and completion operations. The swelling test was conducted and the linear expansion adopted because it is the most representative of the increase seen by the wellbore but was measured in the direction perpendicular to the bedding plane as this is the direction of swelling into the wellbore.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3czgtFyiug%253D%253D&md5=e354ca6c4f4eb43542f7d40b26a3f0ee
      open URL

    229. 229
      Zhong, H.; Qiu, Z.; Tang, Z.; Zhang, X.; Xu, J.; Huang, W. Study of 4, 4â²-methylenebis-cyclohexanamine as a high temperature-resistant shale inhibitor. J. Mater. Sci. 2016, 51 (16), 7585â 7597,  DOI: 10.1007/s10853-016-0037-y
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      229
      Study of 4, 4'-methylenebis-cyclohexanamine as a high temperature-resistant shale inhibitor
      Zhong, Hanyi; Qiu, Zhengsong; Tang, Zhichuan; Zhang, Xin; Xu, Jiangen; Huang, Weian
      Journal of Materials Science (2016), 51 (16), 7585-7597CODEN: JMTSAS; ISSN:0022-2461. (Springer)
      In order to develop high-performance water-based drilling fluid with the aim of meeting the increasing requirement of drilling industry, highly inhibitive and high-temp.-resistant shale inhibitors are essential. In this study, 4, 4'-methylenebis-cyclohexanamine was introduced as a potential shale inhibitor. The inhibitive properties of the amine compd. in comparison with currently available polyether diamine inhibitor were evaluated using bentonite inhibition test, shale cuttings hot-rolling dispersion test, linear swelling test, and pressure transmission test. The inhibitive mechanism was investigated with zeta potential measurement, X-ray diffraction anal., and contact angle measurement. The results indicated that 4, 4'-methylenebis-cyclohexanamine can inhibit shale hydration and dispersion effectively, and prevent pressure transmission to a certain extent, performing better than that of polyether diamine. Furthermore, the new diamine provides reliable thermal stability as high as 220 Â°C, preserving the benefits of high-temp. wells application. This novel diamine inhibits shale hydration and dispersion with the combination of chem. inhibition and phys. plugging. The intercalation into the interlayer of clay with monolayer collapses the hydrated clay structure and expels the water mols. After adsorption, clay surface became more hydrophobic, which prevents the imbibition of water. The variation of soly. separates the compd. from the soln., which can plug the micro-pores of shale and prevent fluid invasion.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xns1eisrY%253D&md5=0fae39f6137bd8e626fb1cc9b4e44752

        Rahman, M. T.; Negash, B. M.; Moniruzzaman, M.; Quainoo, A. K.; Bavoh, C. B.; Padmanabhan, E. An overview on the potential application of ionic liquids in shale stabilization processes. Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering 2020, 81, 103480,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jngse.2020.103480
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        An Overview on the potential application of ionic liquids in shale stabilization processes
        Rahman, Md. Tauhidur; Negash, Berihun Mamo; Moniruzzaman, Muhammad; Quainoo, Ato Kwamena; Bavoh, Cornelius B.; Padmanabhan, Eswaran
        Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering (2020), 81 (), 103480CODEN: JNGSA4; ISSN:1875-5100. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. This article comprehensively reviews the potential application and effects of different moieties of ionic liqs. (ILs) on shale stabilization processes. The shale swelling inhibitory mechanisms and dispersion properties of 22 ILs were discussed. The effect of ILs concn., temp., chain length, cations, anions and polymn. functionally are discussed. Also, the toxicity and biodegradability of ILs are briefly provided. This study highlighted that more pos. groups and alkyl substituents, and shorter alkyl chains are helpful for high performances. Understanding different ILs anion/cation effects are highly required. The study provides guidelines to design ILs for shale stabilization.

      6. 6
        Hurnaus, T.; Plank, J. Behavior of titania nanoparticles in cross-linking hydroxypropyl guar used in hydraulic fracturing fluids for oil recovery. Energy Fuels 2015, 29 (6), 3601â 3608,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.energyfuels.5b00430
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Behavior of Titania Nanoparticles in Cross-linking Hydroxypropyl Guar Used in Hydraulic Fracturing Fluids For Oil Recovery
        Hurnaus, Thomas; Plank, Johann
        Energy & Fuels (2015), 29 (6), 3601-3608CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
        Fluids pumped in hydraulic fracturing operations constitute highly viscous gels achieved via crosslinking of the polysaccharide deriv. hydroxypropyl guar (HPG), e.g., with titanium or zirconium complexes. In this study, the mechanism underlying the crosslinking effect was clarified exptl. for the titanium system. It was found that the crosslinking effect is not based on a ligand exchange reaction with the cis-hydroxy functionalities present in HPG but instead relies on TiO2 nanoparticles resulting from hydrolysis of the Ti complexes. For example, 6 nm titania nanospheres (anatase polymorph) synthesized via acid hydrolysis of tetraisopropyl orthotitanate can increase the viscosity of a HPG soln. by a factor of 25. However, this effect was obsd. only at pH = 2-4 where the nanoparticles are stable. At higher pH values, electrostatic repulsion between the nanoparticles decreases, resulting in agglomeration as was obsd. via zeta potential and pH-dependent particle size measurement. Such agglomerates exhibit a lower surface area and thus produce a weaker or no crosslinking at all. Similar effects were obtained from TiO2 particles when their diam. was increased stepwise from 6 to 14 nm. Minor addns. of citric acid can stabilize the nanoparticles even at pH 5-11, thus allowing efficient crosslinking of HPG also in an alk. environment while excessive amts. of citric acid (>5 mmol/g TiO2) retard the crosslinking process. Attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform IR (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy revealed that the crosslinking mechanism is based on the formation of hydrogen bonds between OH groups present on the surface of titania and along the galactomannan chain of HPG. The study confirms that TiO2 nanoparticles represent the active species responsible for the crosslinking of HPG in fracturing fluids when titanium complexes are used.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXnvFarsr8%253D&md5=5480c3e1ea583172d0170afa7d2b0d0f
        open URL
      7. 7
        Danso, D. K.; Negash, B. M.; Ahmed, T. Y.; Yekeen, N.; Ganat, T. A. O. Recent advances in multifunctional proppant technology and increased well output with micro and nano proppants. J. Pet. Sci. Eng. 2021, 196, 108026,  DOI: 10.1016/j.petrol.2020.108026
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        Recent advances in multifunctional proppant technology and increased well output with micro and nano proppants
        Danso, David Kwaku; Negash, Berihun Mamo; Ahmed, Tigabwa Y.; Yekeen, Nurudeen; Omar Ganat, Tarek Arbi
        Journal of Petroleum Science & Engineering (2021), 196 (), 108026CODEN: JPSEE6; ISSN:0920-4105. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Proppants have evolved from their primary role of preventing fracture closure to performing tech. functional roles within reservoirs. This paper presents an extensive review of recent advances in functional proppant technol. Multifunctional proppant roles, such as the enhancement of multiphase flow of reservoir fluids, delivery of CO2 for enhanced gas recovery, detection of fracture geometry, removal of contaminants, fracture moderation, treatment of flowback water, as well as proppant flow back retardation are presented. Advances in proppants with good transport and placement properties, such as, self suspended proppants and in-situ generated proppants were further addressed. Recent field and lab. works suggested that conventionally sized proppants (<149 Î¼m) leave the majority of stimulated reservoir unpropped. The role of micro and nano proppants in recovering these untapped areas are critically reviewed. The optimum size of micro and nanoproppant for effective propping of induced unpropped fractures were discussed. Due to the increasing proppants pumped per lateral foot, cheap sources of regional industrial waste materials such as granitic waste powder, used foundry sand, and blast furnace slag are recommended as potential sources of micro and nano proppants. These cost-effective materials could complement the conventional sand proppants, and their application for averting the closure of micro-fissures could help in sustaining the environment from excessive regional sand mining.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Vickers, Neil J.
        Current Biology (2017), 27 (14), R713-R715CODEN: CUBLE2; ISSN:0960-9822. (Cell Press)
        Male moths compete to arrive first at a female releasing pheromone. A new study reveals that addnl. pheromone cues released only by younger females may prompt males to avoid them in favor of older but more fecund females.

      11. 11
        Li, A.; Ding, W.; He, J.; Dai, P.; Yin, S.; Xie, F. Investigation of pore structure and fractal characteristics of organic-rich shale reservoirs: A case study of Lower Cambrian Qiongzhusi formation in Malong block of eastern Yunnan Province, South China. Marine and Petroleum Geology 2016, 70, 46â 57,  DOI: 10.1016/j.marpetgeo.2015.11.004
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Investigation of pore structure and fractal characteristics of organic-rich shale reservoirs: A case study of Lower Cambrian Qiongzhusi formation in Malong block of eastern Yunnan Province, South China
        Li, Ang; Ding, Wenlong; He, Jianhua; Dai, Peng; Yin, Shuai; Xie, Fei
        Marine and Petroleum Geology (2016), 70 (), 46-57CODEN: MPEGD8; ISSN:0264-8172. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        In order to study pore structure and fractal characteristics of the org.-rich marine shale, fourteen shale samples from Lower Cambrian Qiongzhusi formation in Malong block of eastern Yunnan province were investigated by org. geochem. anal. (total org. carbon content anal. and thermal maturity anal.), X-ray diffraction (XRD) anal., porosity and permeability tests, field emission SEM (FE-SEM), low-pressure nitrogen adsorption and methane adsorption expts. Fractal dimensions D1 and D2 (at relative pressure of 0-0.5 and 0.5-1, resp.) were obtained from the nitrogen adsorption data using the fractal Frenkel-Halsey-Hill (FHH) method. Not only have the relationships among pore structure parameters of shale, the relationships between TOC content, mineral compns., pore structure parameters and fractal dimensions been discussed, but also the significance of two fractal dimensions D1 and D2 and the impact of fractal dimensions on adsorption capacity have been investigated. The results showed that fourteen shale samples have TOC content ranging from 1.25% to 7.72%, two fractal dimensions both increase with the increasing TOC content, and gradually come to a standstill-the curves present the shape of "parabola". The major mineralogical compns. of shales are quartz and clay minerals, the quartz contents are between 25.5% and 42.7%, the clay contents are between 26.6% and 44.2%. Fractal dimension D1 has a neg. correlation with quartz contents and a pos. correlation with clay minerals contents, but fractal dimension D2 has no apparent relationship with quartz and clay minerals contents. The sp. surface area is in the range of 4.98 m2/g-19.66 m2/g, the total pore vol. is between 0.00479 cm3/g and 0.01765 cm3/g, and the av. pore diam. is between 3.37 nm and 6.02 nm. Two fractal dimensions increase with the increasing surface area and pore vol., and also increase with the decreasing av. pore diam. because of the complicated pore surface and structure of small pores. Further investigation indicates that D1 represents fractal characteristics from the irregular pore surface, while D2 represents fractal characteristics related to the complicated pore structure, and shale samples with larger fractal dimensions have higher methane adsorption capacity. Therefore fractal anal. is helpful to have a better understanding of pore structure and adsorption capacity of marine shale.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXitVSgs7vK&md5=aa918c9c20094e0914db8bb6ad1b457f
        open URL

      13. 13
        Liu, D.; Yan, Y.; Bai, G.; Yuan, Y.; Zhu, T.; Zhang, F.; Shao, M.; Tian, X. Mechanisms for stabilizing and supporting shale fractures with nanoparticles in Pickering emulsion. J. Pet. Sci. Eng. 2018, 164, 103â 109,  DOI: 10.1016/j.petrol.2018.01.048
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Mechanisms for stabilizing and supporting shale fractures with nanoparticles in Pickering emulsion
        Liu, Dexin; Yan, Yicheng; Bai, Gang; Yuan, Yuanjiu; Zhu, Tongyu; Zhang, Fang; Shao, Minglu; Tian, Xuyang
        Journal of Petroleum Science & Engineering (2018), 164 (), 103-109CODEN: JPSEE6; ISSN:0920-4105. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Slickwater hydraulic fracturing technol. is widely used in shale reservoirs to form complex networks and improve hydrocarbon recovery, but the proppant cannot be delivered to the remote fractures due to its low viscosity. Pickering emulsion stabilized by nanoparticles is developed as a hydraulic fracturing fluid for shale reservoirs. In this study, nano-silicas were used to prep. and stabilize Pickering emulsion. During fracturing process, this emulsion is broken to release nano-silicas, which would adsorb on fractures surfaces or assemble in fractures. The nano-silicas in low mass concn. Pickering emulsion pave on the surfaces of shales uniformly, hence stabilize the shale and prevent clay hydration. And when in high mass concn. Pickering emulsion, nano-silicas can accumulate in fractures to support and prevent them from closing. Since Pickering emulsion itself contains nanoparticles to serve as proppants, it can penetrate the entire fracture and complex network which maximize the effective fracture area and stimulate reservoir vol., furthermore replacing traditional proppant pumping.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisVarsrg%253D&md5=a75de99c0b9854c0b7d9335f636cb80a
        open URL

      15. 15
        Danso, D. K.; Negash, B. M.; Yekeen, N.; Khan, J. A.; Rahman, M. T.; Ibrahim, A. U. Potential valorization of granitic waste material as microproppant for induced unpropped microfractures in shale. Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering 2021, 96, 104281,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jngse.2021.104281
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Potential valorization of granitic waste material as microproppant for induced unpropped microfractures in shale
        Danso, David Kwaku; Negash, Berihun Mamo; Yekeen, Nurudeen; Khan, Javed Akbar; Rahman, Md Tauhidur; Ibrahim, Adamu Umar
        Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering (2021), 96 (), 104281CODEN: JNGSA4; ISSN:1875-5100. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Billions of tons of quarried material are globally produced per annum, generating siliceous solid cutting and powder waste which are usually disposed of in landfill sites. Herein, two cheap and distinct granite quarry waste cuttings have been reduced into microproppant dimensions. They were characterized for potential application in hydraulic fracturing as an economic alternative to siliceous com. available microproppants. The particle size distributions, morphol., particle d., the mineralogy, microscale mech. hardness, and modulus of the produced microproppants were evaluated to confirm their potential application as microproppants. Also, the split core fracture cond. of the produced microproppants was measured. Laser diffraction revealed particle size distribution with d50 of about 11Î¼m suitable for common natural fracture widths. Morphol. images showed low sphericity and roundness appropriate for channel fracturing proppant placement. A particle d. of 2.6 and 2.9 g/cc was obtained for the produced microproppants. However, a review of most granite particle d. indicated proximity to commonly used quartz-based microproppant. Their d. and smaller sizes suggest good transport properties. Of the mineralogy study showed high amts. of silica content with dominant crystal phases of albite, anorthite, and orthoclase which exhibited theor. hardness between (5.2-7.2 GPa) and modulus between (77.8-98.0 GPa). Nanoindentation confirmed the micromech. hardness and modulus detd. by d. functional theory. The hardness and modulus lie between class C Fly ash and Ottawa sand which have demonstrated good performance as microproppants. Hence granite microproppants have the potential to resist reservoir stresses. Granite microproppant pillars were able to improve the baseline permeability of a fractured shale core by a magnitude of ten. Granitic microproppants are cheaper sources of silica capable of maintaining microfracture width and preventing rapid prodn. decline within unconventional shale reservoirs while contributing to the conservation of overly exploited natural sand deposits.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXit1ert7vF&md5=f04d2c867a206e91dd1e9ac22253fbc3

Uncertainty handling in wellbore trajectory design: a modified cellular spotted hyena optimizer-based approach.       17. 17
        Rahman, M. T.; Negash, B. M.; Idris, A.; Miah, M. I.; Biswas, K. Experimental and COSMO-RS simulation studies on the effects of polyatomic anions on clay swelling. ACS omega 2021, 6 (40), 26519â 26532,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.1c03786
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Experimental and COSMO-RS Simulation Studies on the Effects of Polyatomic Anions on Clay Swelling
        Rahman, Md Tauhidur; Negash, Berihun Mamo; Idris, Alamin; Miah, Mohammad Islam; Biswas, Kallol
        ACS Omega (2021), 6 (40), 26519-26532CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        Ionic liqs. (ILs) can play a vital role in clay swelling inhibition during hydraulic fracturing. Previous studies highlighted the effect of side-chain length attached to the cationic core and different anions possessing almost the same chem. properties on inhibition performance. However, polyat. anions have the potential to superiorly inhibit swelling compared to monoat. anions. In this study, three ILs, namely, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BMIMCl), 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMIMBF4), and 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate (BMIMPF6), were utilized to assess the effects of polyat. anions on clay swelling inhibition. These performances were compared with the performances of a conventional inhibitor, potassium chloride (KCl). X-ray diffraction (XRD) testing was applied to check the mineral components present in the bentonite clay sample studied in this research. Clay swelling inhibition performance and rheol. properties of these ILs were evaluated by the bentonite plate soaking test, linear swelling test, and rheol. test. The swelling inhibition mechanisms were investigated through Î¶-potential measurement, Fourier transform IR (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and contact angle measurement. Moreover, COSMO-RS computer simulation was conducted to explain the inhibition mechanisms theor. The results demonstrated that BMIMPF6 showed superior inhibition performance and reduced the swelling by 21.55%, while only 9.26% redn. was attained by potassium chloride (KCl). The adsorption ability on the bentonite surface through electrostatic attraction, higher activity coeff., and less electronegativity of PF6- anion played a vital role in attaining such superior inhibition performance by BMIMPF6.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXitFSru7fL&md5=f4b6569a6998129a5b8d5d5034a2696a
        open URL
      18. 18
        Chatterjee, A.; Iwasaki, T.; Hayashi, H.; Ebina, T.; Torii, K. Electronic and structural properties of montmorilloniteâa quantum chemical study. J. Mol. Catal. A: Chem. 1998, 136 (2), 195â 202,  DOI: 10.1016/S1381-1169(98)00051-X
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        Electronic and structural properties of montmorillonite - a quantum chemical study
        Chatterjee, A.; Iwasaki, T.; Hayashi, H.; Ebina, T.; Torii, K.
        Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical (1998), 136 (2), 195-202CODEN: JMCCF2; ISSN:1381-1169. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        The importance of geometry and its relation with property in montmorillonite have been studied in terms of octahedral aluminum and tetrahedral silicon present in the framework. Quantum chem. (QC) calcns. were performed using MNDO (modified neglect of differential overlap) and DFT (d. functional theory) is reported. Cluster calcns. were performed on two octahedral aluminum sites present in the unit cell of montmorillonite to show the distinguishability between the two octahedral aluminums. The energy difference between two aluminum octahedral cluster was 1.12 eV. This was further justified by the calcn. of magnesium substitution energy for two different positions of aluminum. This difference in two octahedral aluminum sites was mainly due to the typical orientation of the bridging hydroxyl groups attached with the octahedral aluminums. Calcns. were also performed on tetrahedral silica hexagons with and without aluminum substitution to predict the Bronsted acid strength of the surface both by MNDO and DMOL QC methods; which shows that aluminum substitution is an unfavorable process in this type of clay. The above structure property relationship in case of montmorillonite will further help in explaining the catalytic activity of the material.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXntVygt70%253D&md5=0dd712038f714c5137ed83387ab9a532
        open URL
      19. 19
        Liu, T.; Chen, Y.-Q. A molecular dynamics study of the swelling patterns of Na/Cs-montmorillonites and the hydration of interlayer cations. Chinese Physics B 2013, 22 (2), 027103,  DOI: 10.1088/1674-1056/22/2/027103
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        A molecular dynamics study of the swelling patterns of Na/Cs-montmorillonites and the hydration of interlayer cations
        Liu, Tao; Chen, Yu-Qing
        Chinese Physics B (2013), 22 (2), 027103/1-027103/5CODEN: CPBHAJ; ISSN:1674-1056. (IOP Publishing Ltd.)
        We report on a mol. dynamics study of the swelling patterns of an Na-rich/Cs-poor montmorillonite and a Cs-montmorillonite. The recently developed CLAYFF force field is used to predict the basal spacing as a function of the water content in the interlayer. The simulations reproduce the swelling patterns of the Na and Cs-montmorillonite, suggesting a mechanism of its hydration different from that of the montmorillonite. In addn., we find that the differences in size and hydration energy of Na and Cs ions have strong implications for the structure and the internal energy of interlayer water. In particular, our results indicate that the hydrate difference in the presence of coexistent Na and Cs has a larger influence on the behavior of a clay-water system. For Na-rich/Cs-poor montmorillonite, the hydration energy values of Na ions and water mols. each have a dramatic increase compared with those in Na-montmorillonite on the interlayer spacing, and the hydration energy values of Cs ions and water mols. decrease somewhat compared with those in Cs-montmorillonite.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVWrsLjJ&md5=702c965eff8baeff03acc62a41f645ca
        open URL
      20. 20
        Teich-McGoldrick, S. L.; Greathouse, J. A.; Jove-Colon, C. F.; Cygan, R. T. Swelling properties of montmorillonite and beidellite clay minerals from molecular simulation: comparison of temperature, interlayer cation, and charge location effects. J. Phys. Chem. C 2015, 119 (36), 20880â 20891,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.5b03253
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Swelling Properties of Montmorillonite and Beidellite Clay Minerals from Molecular Simulation: Comparison of Temperature, Interlayer Cation, and Charge Location Effects
        Teich-McGoldrick, Stephanie L.; Greathouse, Jeffery A.; Jove-Colon, Carlos F.; Cygan, Randall T.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2015), 119 (36), 20880-20891CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        The swelling properties of smectite clay minerals are relevant to many engineering applications including environmental remediation, repository design for nuclear waste disposal, borehole stability in drilling operations, and additives for numerous industrial processes and com. products. We used mol. dynamics and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations to study the effects of layer charge location, interlayer cation, and temp. on intracryst. swelling of montmorillonite and beidellite clay minerals. For a beidellite model with layer charge exclusively in the tetrahedral sheet, strong ion-surface interactions shift the onset of the two-layer hydrate to higher water contents. In contrast, for a montmorillonite model with layer charge exclusively in the octahedral sheet, weaker ion-surface interactions result in the formation of fully hydrated ions (two-layer hydrate) at much lower water contents. Clay hydration enthalpies and interlayer at. d. profiles are consistent with the swelling results. Water adsorption isotherms from grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations are used to relate interlayer hydration states to relative humidity, in good agreement with exptl. findings.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsVWntbbK&md5=80e5f43b4e85ec96992d984cfd4f4093
        open URL

      23. 23
        Zhong, H.; Qiu, Z.; Zhang, D.; Tang, Z.; Huang, W.; Wang, W. Inhibiting shale hydration and dispersion with amine-terminated polyamidoamine dendrimers. Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering 2016, 28, 52â 60,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jngse.2015.11.029
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Inhibiting shale hydration and dispersion with amine-terminated polyamidoamine dendrimers
        Zhong, Hanyi; Qiu, Zhengsong; Zhang, Daoming; Tang, Zhichuan; Huang, Weian; Wang, Weiji
        Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering (2016), 28 (), 52-60CODEN: JNGSA4; ISSN:1875-5100. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Dendrimers have been paid increasing attention in the area of drilling fluid recently due to their unique structure and properties. The inhibitive properties of amine terminated polyamidoamine (PAMAM) dendrimers ranging from G0 to G5 were evaluated by relative inhibition rate, shale cuttings hot-rolling dispersion test and particle size distribution measurement resp. Meanwhile the inhibitive capacity of the polymers under various pH value conditions was studied. The interaction between sodium bentonite and PAMAM dendrimers was characterized by zeta potential measurement and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The results indicated that, G0 and G5 are superior to polyether diamine, while G1, G2, G3 and G4 perform better than KCl. PAMAM dendrimers from G0 to G5 can decrease the zeta potential of clay particles from -39 mV to about -22.6 mV at natural pH values and reverse the charge when the pH value is adjusted to 9. When intercalated into the clay interlayer in aq. soln., the candidate PAMAM dendrimers can form monolayer arrangement at lower concns. and reduce the interlayer spacing of hydrated clay from 1.95 nm to 1.38-1.63 nm, which is the direct evidence of inhibiting shale hydration. With the increase of concn., mixed phase and bilayer orientation are formed in the interlayer. The multi-terminal amine groups of dendrimers can effectively bind the adjacent layers together with electrostatic attraction and hydrogen bonding, and expel the water mols. out of the interlayer, contributing to the suppression of clay swelling and dispersion. The pH value redn. of aq. soln. improves the protonation of terminal-amine group, which can intensify the interaction between the polymers and clay, inducing the decrease of hydrated interlayer spacing and the zeta potential of clay particles, thus enhancing the inhibitive properties.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXitVSgs7nM&md5=b67dd83dc5867a6081a0d01c803b0c87
        open URL
      24. 24
        Jain, R.; Mahto, V. Formulation of a water based drilling fluid system with synthesized graft copolymer for troublesome shale formations. Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering 2017, 38, 171â 181,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jngse.2016.12.018
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Formulation of a water based drilling fluid system with synthesized graft copolymer for troublesome shale formations
        Jain, Rajat; Mahto, Vikas
        Journal of Natural Gas Science and Engineering (2017), 38 (), 171-181CODEN: JNGSA4; ISSN:1875-5100. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Shale formations consisting of reactive clay mineral of smectite group like montmorillonite may lead to severe wellbore instability problems with conventional water based drilling fluids. This may be due to their high magnitude of rock-fluid interaction inside the wellbore. Problems like hole enlargement, pipe sticking, high toque and drag etc. may escalate drilling cost and time. The present study deals with the applicability of synthesized polyacrylamide/dially di-Me ammonium chloride-grafted-gum acacia copolymer in formulation of novel water based drilling mud system (WBDMS) for troublesome shale formations. The mechanism behind the synthesis was free radical polymn. The structural information and morphol. properties of copolymer were detd. by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR) and Field emission SEM (FESEM). Further, its effect on filtration and rheol. of developed mud system was analyzed thoroughly as per API std. procedures. Further, effectiveness of graft copolymer on the shale stabilization was investigated using shale dispersion and slake durability tests. The reactivity of core sample with the developed drilling fluid system was analyzed using core flooding exptl. setup. The exptl. investigations showed that synthesized graft copolymer has significant effect on rheol. parameters and filtration characteristics of the system due to its synergistic effects in the developed system. Also, its shale stabilization property was superior to the com. used shale stabilizer (partially hydrolyzed polyacrylamide polymer). It was evident from the high values of shale recovery and slake durability index. This was achieved due to the presence of cationic ions and formation of a protective coating on shale cuttings. It has also resulted in the low magnitude of rock-fluid interaction. The developed drilling fluid system exhibited low reactivity with the core sample during core flow studies. Thus, the synthesized graft copolymer can be utilized as an additive in the formulation of water based mud system customized for reactive shale formations.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlsVGntQ%253D%253D&md5=8bbbc4981760cc9cc3c4abcd6f01f30f
        open URL
      25. 25
        Zhao, X.; Qiu, Z.; Sun, B.; Liu, S.; Xing, X.; Wang, M. Formation damage mechanisms associated with drilling and completion fluids for deepwater reservoirs. J. Pet. Sci. Eng. 2019, 173, 112â 121,  DOI: 10.1016/j.petrol.2018.09.098
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        Formation damage mechanisms associated with drilling and completion fluids for deepwater reservoirs
        Zhao, Xin; Qiu, Zhengsong; Sun, Baojiang; Liu, Shujie; Xing, Xijin; Wang, Mingliang
        Journal of Petroleum Science & Engineering (2019), 173 (), 112-121CODEN: JPSEE6; ISSN:0920-4105. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Immense oil and gas reserves exist in the deepwater of the South China Sea, and the first priority for implementing successful drilling and completion operations without reservoir damage is to understand the damaging mechanisms to the reservoir formation. With the use of deepwater reservoir cores from the western South China Sea, the mineral compn., microstructure, porosity, and permeability characteristics of the reservoir formation were analyzed. With the use of core flow tests, potential fluid sensitivity was analyzed to det. how and which fluids can damage the reservoir formation during drilling and completion. The results show that the reservoir formation is composed of unconsolidated siltstone with a clay mineral content of 6-19%, and has high porosity and permeability with large pore throats. Sensitivity damage due to the increasing flow rate is strong, and an unusual salinity sensitivity exists with a crit. salinity at 40,000-45,000 mg/L. Moderate alkali fluids sensitivity damage exists, with water sensitivity being weak. The main mechanisms of formation damage by drilling and completion fluids were analyzed as following: plugging of pore throats by solid invasion occurs because the sizes of the solid materials in the drilling fluids are just ideal for the formation of an external filter. Rock-fluid incompatibilities occur due to the increasing flow rate and salinity of the fluids because the formation rock is unconsolidated and the fines will easily detach and migrate, plugging the pore throats. Therefore, effective temporary plugging of the pore throats with a large diam. is important for protecting the reservoir. This study provides basic data for the design and implementation of reservoir protection measures in deepwater oil and gas exploration.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvFWitb3O&md5=4186fea07377e4908b7ed742f44867d5
        open URL
      26. 26
        Zhao, X.; Qiu, Z.; Zhao, C.; Xu, J.; Zhang, Y. Inhibitory effect of water-based drilling fluid on methane hydrate dissociation. Chem. Eng. Sci. 2019, 199, 113â 122,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ces.2018.12.057
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26
        Inhibitory effect of water-based drilling fluid on methane hydrate dissociation
        Zhao, Xin; Qiu, Zhengsong; Zhao, Chao; Xu, Jiangen; Zhang, Yubin
        Chemical Engineering Science (2019), 199 (), 113-122CODEN: CESCAC; ISSN:0009-2509. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Hydrate dissocn. poses a significant problem during drilling operations in hydrate-bearing sediments. The drilling fluid is in direct contact with hydrates, and understanding its inhibitory effect on hydrate dissocn. is important for stabilizing hydrates during drilling operations. In this work, an app. was designed for investigating hydrate dissocn. in drilling fluids, and the effects of thermodn. hydrate inhibitors (THIs), polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), and soybean lecithin on hydrate dissocn. were studied. The inhibitory effect of a water-based drilling fluid in the presence of the potential hydrate dissocn. inhibitors was also studied. An unexpected inhibitory effect occurred with ethylene glycol (EG) at concns. below 10 wt%, resulting from a range of factors including the dissocn. driving force, and mass and heat transfers in the EG soln. PVP and lecithin reduced the hydrate dissocn. rate and increased the time required for complete dissocn. of hydrates. These can, therefore, be used in water-based drilling fluids to inhibit hydrate dissocn. A combination of 0.1 wt% PVP and 0.5 wt% lecithin was selected as an optimal hydrate dissocn. inhibitor, considering its inhibitory effect and compatibility with the drilling fluid. Using EG at a concn. below 10 wt% as a THI instead of NaCl can also help inhibit hydrate dissocn. The findings of this work provide a basis for the development and design of drilling fluids for drilling in hydrate-bearing sediments.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Xu, J.-g.; Qiu, Z.-s.; Zhao, X.; Zhong, H.-y.; Li, G.-r.; Huang, W.-a. Synthesis and characterization of shale stabilizer based on polyethylene glycol grafted nano-silica composite in water-based drilling fluids. J. Pet. Sci. Eng. 2018, 163, 371â 377,  DOI: 10.1016/j.petrol.2018.01.007
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        Synthesis and characterization of shale stabilizer based on polyethylene glycol grafted nano-silica composite in water-based drilling fluids
        Xu, Jian-gen; Qiu, Zheng-song; Zhao, Xin; Zhong, Han-yi; Li, Gong-rang; Huang, Wei-an
        Journal of Petroleum Science & Engineering (2018), 163 (), 371-377CODEN: JPSEE6; ISSN:0920-4105. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In order to solve wellbore instability problems in the drilling process, high-performance shale stabilizers in water-based drilling fluids are essential. In this paper, a novel shale stabilizer based on polyethylene glycol grafted nano-silica composite (PEG-NS) was successfully synthesized. Conventional techniques were used to characterize PEG-NS including Flourier transform IR spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), particle size distribution (PSD) and thermogravimetric anal. (TGA). The results showed that the structure of PEG-NS was in agreement with the design objective. The particle size of PEG-NS ranged from 110 to 434 nm, and PEG-NS had good thermal stability. Pressure transmission test, pore structure characterization of shale, rolling recovery test were applied to evaluate the comprehensive performance of PEG-NS as a novel shale stabilizer. The exptl. data indicated that PEG-NS could effectively retard the pore pressure transmission and reduce the permeability of shale sample. PEG-NS could adsorb onto the shale surface and a dense plugging film could finally coat on it. Moreover, PEG-NS also exhibited better inhibition performance compared with that of potassium chloride (KCl) and polymeric alc. (JHC) at the same concn. Hence, PEG-NS could be a good shale stabilizer in water-based drilling fluids for drilling reactive shale formations.

        Poudel, J.; Ohm, T.-I.; Oh, S. C. A study on torrefaction of food waste. Fuel 2015, 140, 275â 281,  DOI: 10.1016/j.fuel.2014.09.120

        31
        A study on torrefaction of food waste
        Poudel, Jeeban; Ohm, Tae-In; Oh, Sea Cheon
        Fuel (2015), 140 (), 275-281CODEN: FUELAC; ISSN:0016-2361. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Torrefaction of biomass under anoxic condition can produce an energy dense and consistent quality solid biomass fuel for combustion and co-firing applications. This paper investigates the fuel characteristics of food waste at torrefaction temps. ranging from 150 to 600 Â°C, for torrefaction residence time varying from 0 to 50 min in a horizontal tubular reactor. The torrefied products were characterized in terms of their elemental compn., energy yield, ash content and volatile fraction. The gaseous products from torrefaction of food waste were also analyzed. Thermogravimetric anal. was carried out in order to obtain the kinetic parameters for the torrefaction reaction of food waste. It was found that the food waste undergoes changes in their phys. and chem. properties during torrefaction. The energy and mass yield were also found to decrease with an increase in the torrefaction temp., whereas the higher heating value increased.

        32
        Synthesis, characterization, and working mechanism of a synthetic high temperature (200Â°c) fluid loss polymer for oil well cementing containing allyloxy-2-hydroxy propane sulfonic (AHPS) acid monomer
        Tiemeyer, Constantin; Plank, Johann
        Journal of Applied Polymer Science (2013), 128 (1), 851-860CODEN: JAPNAB; ISSN:0021-8995. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        A polymer comprising of 2-acrylamido-2-Me propane sulfonic acid, N, N-dimethyl acrylamide, allyloxy-2-hydroxy propane sulfonic acid (AHPS), acrylic acid, and N, N-methylene bisacrylamide was synthesized by aq. free radical copolymn. and tested as high temp. performing fluid loss additive (FLA) in oil well cement. Successful incorporation of AHPS was confirmed and characteristic properties of the copolymer were detd. using size exclusion chromatog. The FLA showed excellent water retention in cement at 200Â°/70 bar. At this temp., polymer structure changed from branched to linear and hydrodynamic size decreased by â¼50%, thus indicating potential fragmentation, while performance remained unaffected by these alterations. The FLA copolymer does not viscosify cement slurries which is advantageous in high temp. well cementing. The working mechanism of the AHPS-based copolymer was found to rely on redn. of filtercake permeability which is caused by a voluminous coppt. of the FLA with tartaric acid retarder, mediated by Ca2+ ions. Â© 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., J. Appl. Polym. Sci., 2012.

      35. 35
        Ahmed Khan, R.; Murtaza, M.; Abdulraheem, A.; Kamal, M. S.; Mahmoud, M. Imidazolium-based ionic liquids as clay swelling inhibitors: mechanism, performance evaluation, and effect of different anions. ACS omega 2020, 5 (41), 26682â 26696,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.0c03560
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Imidazolium-Based Ionic Liquids as Clay Swelling Inhibitors: Mechanism, Performance Evaluation, and Effect of Different Anions
        Ahmed Khan, Rizwan; Murtaza, Mobeen; Abdulraheem, Abdulazeez; Kamal, Muhammad Shahzad; Mahmoud, Mohamed
        ACS Omega (2020), 5 (41), 26682-26696CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        Clay swelling is one of the challenges faced by the oil industry. Water-based drilling fluids (WBDF) are commonly used in drilling operations. The selection of WBDF depends on its performance to improve rheol., hydration properties, and fluid loss control. However, WBDF may result in clay swelling in shale formations during drilling. In this work, the impact of imidazolium-based ionic liqs. on the clay swelling was investigated. The studied ionic liqs. have a common cation group, 1-allyl-3-methyllimidozium, but differ in anions (bromide, iodide, chloride, and dicyanamide). The inhibition behavior of ionic liqs. was assessed by linear swell test, inhibition test, capillary suction test, rheol., filtration, contact angle measurement, SEM, and X-ray diffraction (XRD). It was obsd. that the ionic liqs. with different anions reduced the clay swelling. Ionic liqs. having a dicyanamide anion showed slightly better swelling inhibition performance compared to other inhibitors. SEM images showed the water tendency to damage the clay structure, displaying asym. cavities and sharp edges. Nevertheless, the addn. of an ionic liq. to sodium bentonite (clay) exhibited fewer cavities and a smooth and dense surface. XRD results showed the increase in d-spacing, demonstrating the intercalation of ionic liqs. in interlayers of clay. The results showed that the clay swelling does not strongly depend on the type of anion in imidazolium-based ILs. However, the type of anion in imidazolium-based ILs influences the rheol. properties. The performance of ionic liqs. was compared with that of the commonly used clay inhibitor (sodium silicate) in the oil and gas industry. ILs showed improved performance compared to sodium silicate. The studied ionic liqs. can be an attractive alternative for com. clay inhibitors as their impact on the other properties of the drilling fluids was less compared to com. inhibitors.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhvFyiurfL&md5=5fd3351fc426c3df2454a969d57f890e
        open URL
      36. 36
        Rasool, M. H.; Zamir, A.; Elraies, K. A.; Ahmad, M.; Ayoub, M.; Abbas, M. A. Potassium carbonate based deep eutectic solvent (DES) as a potential drilling fluid additive in deep water drilling applications. Petroleum Science and Technology 2021, 39 (15â16), 612â 631,  DOI: 10.1080/10916466.2021.1928189
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Potassium carbonate based deep eutectic solvent (DES) as a potential drilling fluid additive in deep water drilling applications
        Rasool, Muhammad Hammad; Zamir, Asif; Elraies, Khaled A.; Ahmad, Maqsood; Ayoub, Muhammad; Abbas, Muhammad Adeem
        Petroleum Science and Technology (2021), 39 (15-16), 612-631CODEN: PSTEFV; ISSN:1091-6466. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
        Drilling fluid design is the most vital step in drilling phase. An ideal drilling fluid apart from exhibiting good thixotropic behavior should be efficient in inhibiting the hydrates formation, suppressing shale swelling and improving mud rheol. Lately, Ionic Liqs. are being used as drilling fluid additives to increase the efficiency of drilling mud. Recent research has given evidences that imidazolium based Ionic liqs. are toxic, not biodegradable and their prepn. require sophisticated techniques and equipment. Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES) are regarded as fourth generation ionic liqs. and are claimed to be the greener and cheaper alternative of traditional ionic liqs. This research utilizes potassium carbonate based DES to check its candidacy as a potential drilling fluid additive. DES based drilling mud showed optimum performance at 0.5% conc. (of DES) by delaying induction time of hydrates formation by 33.8% and decreasing mud cake thickness and filtrate vol. by 36% and 24% resp. Moreover, from a "free style" expt. DES proved to be an excellent shale inhibitor by inhibiting shale swelling upto 84%. The inhibiting traits of DES are mainly attributed to its hydrogen bond formation capability with hydrates and clay.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXhtFers7nN&md5=a120ad3f1a84f56564280f0f4a03567a
        open URL
      37. 37
        Smith, E. L.; Abbott, A. P.; Ryder, K. S. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) and their applications. Chem. Rev. 2014, 114 (21), 11060â 11082,  DOI: 10.1021/cr300162p
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs) and Their Applications
        Smith, Emma L.; Abbott, Andrew P.; Ryder, Karl S.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 114 (21), 11060-11082CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        This article describes the phys. and chem. properties of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) and ionic liq. (ILs), and how their applications differ. DESs are now widely acknowledged as a new class of IL analogs because they share many characteristics and properties with ILs. The terms DES and IL have been used interchangeably in the literature, though it is necessary to point out that these are actually two different types of solvent. DESs are systems formed from a eutectic mixt. of Lewis or Bronsted acids and bases which can contain a variety of anionic and/or cationic species; in contrast, ILs are formed from systems composed primarily of one type of discrete anion and cation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsleksrzM&md5=23e782e87410fb1014857dd350ee5146
        open URL
      38. 38
        Zhang, Q.; Vigier, K. D. O.; Royer, S.; JÃ©rÃ´me, F. Deep eutectic solvents: syntheses, properties and applications. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41 (21), 7108â 7146,  DOI: 10.1039/c2cs35178a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Deep eutectic solvents: Syntheses, properties and applications
        Zhang, Qinghua; De Oliveira Vigier, Karine; Royer, Sebastien; Jerome, Francois
        Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (21), 7108-7146CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Within the framework of green chem., solvents occupy a strategic place. To be qualified as a green medium, these solvents have to meet different criteria such as availability, non-toxicity, biodegradability, recyclability, flammability, and low price among others. Up to now, the no. of available green solvents are rather limited. Here we wish to discuss a new family of ionic fluids, so-called Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES), that are now rapidly emerging in the current literature. A DES is a fluid generally composed of two or three cheap and safe components that are capable of self-assocn., often through hydrogen bond interactions, to form a eutectic mixt. with a m.p. lower than that of each individual component. DESs are generally liq. at temps. lower than 100 Â°C. These DESs exhibit similar physico-chem. properties to the traditionally used ionic liqs., while being much cheaper and environmentally friendlier. Owing to these remarkable advantages, DESs are now of growing interest in many fields of research. In this review, we report the major contributions of DESs in catalysis, org. synthesis, dissoln. and extn. processes, electrochem. and material chem. All works discussed in this review aim at demonstrating that DESs not only allow the design of eco-efficient processes but also open a straightforward access to new chems. and materials.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsVOnurjF&md5=b2e43b5e7332276be1699afe9ddd561f
        open URL
      39. 39
        Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F.; Hashim, M.; AlNashef, I. Prediction of the surface tension of deep eutectic solvents. Fluid phase equilibria 2012, 319, 48â 54,  DOI: 10.1016/j.fluid.2012.01.025
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39
        Prediction of the surface tension of deep eutectic solvents
        Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M.
        Fluid Phase Equilibria (2012), 319 (), 48-54CODEN: FPEQDT; ISSN:0378-3812. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Surface tension is one of the important deep eutectic solvents (DESs) phys. properties which provides considerable information related to the mol. influence on the intensity of interactions in the mixt. Due to the absence of DESs surface tension exptl. data, prediction methods of this property become of high importance. In this work, two simple methods for the prediction of DESs surface tension are presented. The first method reports the use of the parachor to predict surface tension. In the second method, the effect of temp. variation on surface tension was predicted using the Othmer equation. The parachor of nine different DESs based on ammonium and phosphunium salts were detd. exptl. as well as calcd. from the mol. structure of their constituting components using available parachor contribution data for neutral compds. The results showed that calcd. and exptl. parachor of DESs were notably close and that the parachor contribution data developed for neutral compds. can be successfully utilized for deep eutectic solvents with an av. surface tension prediction percentage error of 6.4%. The av. prediction percentage error using the Othmer equation was 2.57%. This proves that surface tension of DESs can be predicted efficiently using either one of the two suggested methods.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XjtFOisrc%253D&md5=9de2bb5fe4590cb2f6fb6c8021cb84fa
        open URL
      40. 40
        Zhao, H.; Baker, G. A.; Holmes, S. New eutectic ionic liquids for lipase activation and enzymatic preparation of biodiesel. Organic & biomolecular chemistry 2011, 9 (6), 1908â 1916,  DOI: 10.1039/c0ob01011a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        40
        New eutectic ionic liquids for lipase activation and enzymatic preparation of biodiesel
        Zhao, Hua; Baker, Gary A.; Holmes, Shaletha
        Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2011), 9 (6), 1908-1916CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The enzymic prepn. of biodiesel was hampered by the lack of suitable solvents with desirable properties such as high lipase compatibility, low cost, low viscosity, high biodegradability, and ease of product sepn. Recent interest in using ionic liqs. (ILs) as advanced reaction media led to fast reaction rates and high yields in the enzymic synthesis of biodiesel. However, conventional (i.e., cation-anion paired) ILs based on imidazolium and other quaternary ammonium salts remain too expensive for wide application on an industrial scale. The authors report on newly-synthesized eutectic ILs derived from choline acetate or choline chloride coupled with bio-compatible H-bond donors, such as glycerol. These eutectic solvents have favorable properties including low viscosity, high biodegradability, and excellent compatibility with Novozym 435, a com. immobilized Candida antarctica lipase B. In a model biodiesel synthesis system, the authors demonstrate high reaction rates for the enzymic transesterification of Miglyol oil 812 with MeOH, catalyzed by Novozym 435 in choline acetate/glycerol (1:1.5 molar ratio). The high conversion (97%) of the triglyceride obtained within 3 h, under optimal conditions, suggests that these novel eutectic solvents warrant further exploration as potential media in the enzymic prodn. of biodiesel.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXislOmtbs%253D&md5=09e44c97665ac16d578781aaed31c10e
        open URL

        Carriazo, D.; Serrano, M. C.; GutiÃ©rrez, M. C.; Ferrer, M. L.; del Monte, F. Deep-eutectic solvents playing multiple roles in the synthesis of polymers and related materials. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2012, 41 (14), 4996â 5014,  DOI: 10.1039/c2cs15353j
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        Deep-eutectic solvents playing multiple roles in the synthesis of polymers and related materials
        Carriazo, Daniel; Serrano, Maria Concepcion; Gutierrez, Maria Concepcion; Ferrer, Maria Luisa; del Monte, Francisco
        Chemical Society Reviews (2012), 41 (14), 4996-5014CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The aim of this review is to provide an exposition of some of the most recent applications of deep-eutectic solvents (DESs) in the synthesis of polymers and related materials. The authors consider that there is plenty of room for the development of fundamental research in the field of DESs because their compositional flexibility makes the no. of DESs susceptible of prepn. unlimited and so do the range of properties that DESs can attain. Ultimately, these properties can be transferred into the resulting materials in terms of both tailored morphologies and compns. Thus, interesting applications can be easily envisaged, esp. in those fields in which the prepn. of high-tech products via low cost processes is crit. The authors hope that the preliminary work surveyed in this review will encourage scientists to explore the promising perspectives offered by DESs.

        Comparison of physicochemical properties of new ionic liquids based on imidazolium, quaternary ammonium, and guanidinium cations
        Kulkarni, Prashant S.; Branco, Luis C.; Crespo, Joao G.; Nunes, M. Cristiana; Raymundo, Anabela; Afonso, Carlos A. M.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (30), 8478-8488CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        More than 50 ionic liqs. were prepd. by using imidazolium, quaternary ammonium, and guanidinium cations and various anions. In these series, different cationic structures such as 1-benzyl-3-methylimidazolium [Bzmim]+, 1,3-dibenzylimidazolium [BzmiBz]+, 1-octyl-3-methylimidazolium [C8mim]+, 1-decyl-3-methylimidazolium [C10mim]+, tricaprylmethylammonium [Aliquat]+, benzyltriethylammonium [BzTEA]+, phenyltrimethylammonium [PhTMA]+, and dimethyldihexylguanidinium [DMG]+ were combined with anions, p-toluenesulfonate [TSA]-, dicyanoamide [DCA]-, saccharine (2-sulfobenzoic acid imide sodium salt) [SAC]-, trifluoroacetate [TFA]-, bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide [Tf2N]-, trifluoromethanesulfonate [TfO]-, and thiocyanate [SCN]-. Important phys. data for these ionic liqs. are collated, namely soly. in common solvents, viscosity, d., m.p. and water content. Apart from the viscosity, the Newtonian and non-Newtonian behavior of these ionic liqs. is also disclosed. Stability of these ionic liqs. under thermal, basic, acidic, nucleophilic, and oxidative conditions was also studied. The features of the solid-liq. phase transition were analyzed, namely the glass transition temp. and the heat capacity jump assocd. with the transition from the non-equil. glass to the metastable supercooled liq. A degrdn. temp. of each ionic liq. was also detd. Comparisons of the properties of various ionic liqs. were made.

        Potential applications of deep eutectic solvents in nanotechnology
        Abo-Hamad, Ali; Hayyan, Maan; AlSaadi, Mohammed AbdulHakim; Hashim, Mohd Ali
        Chemical Engineering Journal (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2015), 273 (), 551-567CODEN: CMEJAJ; ISSN:1385-8947. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have recently received a great interest in diverse fields including nanotechnol. due to their unique properties as new green solvents, efficient dispersants and as large-scale media for chem. and electrochem. synthesis of advanced functional nanomaterials. DESs have also an active role in improving the size and morphol. of nanomaterials during synthesis stage. Moreover, DESs confined in nano-size pores or tubes show distinct behavior from those in the same types but in larger scales. Therefore, a numerous studies sprung up to expose the importance of the synergy between DESs and nanomaterials. This review revealed the recent studies that devoted to the impact of involving DESs in nanotechnol. and potential applications.

        Murtaza, M.; Kamal, M. S.; Mahmoud, M. Application of a novel and sustainable silicate solution as an alternative to sodium silicate for clay swelling inhibition. ACS omega 2020, 5 (28), 17405â 17415,  DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.0c01777

        47
        Application of a Novel and Sustainable Silicate Solution as an Alternative to Sodium Silicate for Clay Swelling Inhibition
        Murtaza, Mobeen; Kamal, Muhammad Shahzad; Mahmoud, Mohamed
        ACS Omega (2020), 5 (28), 17405-17415CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        Shale swelling during drilling operations causes many problems mainly related to wellbore instability. The oil-based muds (OBMs) are very effective in controlling the swelling potential of clay-rich shale formation, but their environmental concerns and the economic aspects curtail their usage. In the application of water-based mud (WBM), it is mixed with various swelling inhibitors such as inorg. salts (KCl and NaCl), sodium silicate, polymers, and amines of various types. The above-mentioned materials are however afflicted by some limitations in terms of their toxicity, their effect on drilling mud rheol., and their limited tolerance toward temp. and oil contamination. In this study, we investigated a novel hybrid aq. alkali alumino silicate (AAAS) as a shale swelling inhibitor in WBM. The AAAS is a mixt. of sodium, aluminum, and silicon oxides. Exptl. investigations were carried out using a linear swell meter, hot rolling and capillary suction timer, Î¶-potential test, filtration test, and rheol. test. The application of hybrid silicate as a swelling inhibitor was studied in two phases. In the first phase, only silicate solns. were prepd. in deionized water at various ratios (1, 2, and 5%) and tested on sodium bentonite and shale samples contg. high contents of kaolinite clay. Further testing on commonly used inhibitors such as KCl and sodium silicate solns. was conducted for comparative purposes. In the second phase, different drilling mud formulations consisting of various percentages of AAAS were mixed and tested on original shale samples. It was obsd. that the novel silicate-based mix proved to be a strong shale swelling inhibitor. Its inhibition performance was better as compared to the sodium silicate soln. and KCl soln. It not only inhibits shale swelling but also acts as a shale stabilizer due to its high adsorption on the shale surface, which prevents the shale/water reactivity, makes the shale formation stronger, and prevents caving.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhtlans7vI&md5=a781930e01589148f2d4b8cd12286988

        Murtaza, M.; Ahmed Khan, R.; Kamal, M. S.; Hussain, S. S.; Mahmoud, M. Poly (Oxyethylene)-amidoamine based gemini cationic surfactants with hydrophilic spacers as clay stabilizers. Energy Fuels 2020, 34 (9), 10619â 10630,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.energyfuels.0c01010
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Poly(Oxyethylene)-amidoamine Based Gemini Cationic Surfactants with Hydrophilic Spacers as Clay Stabilizers
        Murtaza, Mobeen; Ahmed Khan, Rizwan; Kamal, Muhammad Shahzad; Hussain, S. M. Shakil; Mahmoud, Mohamed
        Energy & Fuels (2020), 34 (9), 10619-10630CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
        Water-based drilling fluids cause severe formation damage upon interaction with clay-based formations. Therefore, clay inhibitors are commonly used in the oil and gas industry to prevent clay swelling. The selection of a swelling inhibitor is crit. and requires careful understanding. This study reports the application of poly(oxyethylene)-amidoamine based cationic gemini surfactants (GSs) as clay swelling inhibitors. These surfactants are different due to the hydrophilicity of the spacer. The synthesized surfactants contain a di-Et ether spacer (GS-A), a secondary amine spacer (GS-B), or an iso-Pr alc. spacer (GS-C). The swelling inhibition was detd. with a linear swelling test, a capillary suction timer (CST), a wettability test, X-ray diffraction, particle size, rheol., and filtration expts. The synthesized surfactants decreased the clay swelling compared to the base mud. The surfactant with a secondary amine spacer (GS-B) showed the best performance compared to the other surfactants. Moreover, the surfactant showed comparable performances with a commonly used clay stabilizer (KCl) and the com. available cationic surfactant dodecyltrimethylammonium bromide (DTAB) used in the industry. It was obsd. that the synthesized surfactants reduced rheol. properties and increased the particle size of bentonite and the filtration vol. The proposed gemini cationic surfactants can be used as an alternative for com. clay swelling inhibitors.

        Murtaza, M.; Kamal, M. S.; Hussain, S. S.; Mahmoud, M.; Syed, N. A. Quaternary ammonium gemini surfactants having different spacer length as clay swelling inhibitors: Mechanism and performance evaluation. J. Mol. Liq. 2020, 308, 113054,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2020.113054
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        49
        Quaternary ammonium gemini surfactants having different spacer length as clay swelling inhibitors: Mechanism and performance evaluation
        Murtaza, Mobeen; Kamal, Muhammad Shahzad; Hussain, S. M. Shakil; Mahmoud, Mohamed; Syed, Nadeem Ahmed
        Journal of Molecular Liquids (2020), 308 (), 113054CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The swelling of shale formation upon exposure to water-based drilling fluids leads to several problems. Common shale (clay) inhibitors used in the industry have several shortcomings which adversely affect the drilling mud properties. This study involves the development, application, and mechanism of new quaternary ammonium gemini cationic surfactants as clay swelling inhibitors. These gemini surfactants are structurally similar but different in terms of the spacer lengths. The inhibition characteristics of gemini surfactants were evaluated using a linear swell tester, capillary suction timer, scanning electron microscope (SEM), rheol., filtration, wettability, and zeta potential anal. It was obsd. that the new gemini cationic surfactants with various lengths of spacers reduced the clay swelling. The GS12 surfactant, contg. flexible large spacer C12 proved to be a beneficial swelling inhibitor as compared to GS8 and GS10 due to increased hydrophobicity. It also showed acceptable performance compared to the common shale inhibitor used in the industry. SEM images revealed that water caused significant damage to clay structures showing irregular and sharp edges. However, the surfactant-treated clay showed a fine, dense, and smooth surface. An inhibition mechanism using synthesized surfactants was also proposed. Exptl. tests showed the synthesized surfactants adsorb and intercalate between layers of clay through hydrogen bonding and attractive electrostatic forces. The orientation of lipophilic tails inhibits the water adsorption in the clay which results in reduced clay swelling. The synthesized surfactants reduced the clay swelling without affecting the other mud properties such as rheol., stability, and filtration properties.
