        Moura, L.; Moufawad, T.; Ferreira, M.; Bricout, H.; Tilloy, S.; Monflier, E.; Costa Gomes, M. F.; Landy, D.; Fourmentin, S. Deep eutectic solvents as green absorbents of volatile organic pollutants. Environmental Chemistry Letters 2017, 15 (4), 747â 753,  DOI: 10.1007/s10311-017-0654-y
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        129
        Deep eutectic solvents as green absorbents of volatile organic pollutants
        Moura, Leila; Moufawad, Tarek; Ferreira, Michel; Bricout, Herve; Tilloy, Sebastien; Monflier, Eric; Costa Gomes, Margarida F.; Landy, David; Fourmentin, Sophie
        Environmental Chemistry Letters (2017), 15 (4), 747-753CODEN: ECLNBJ; ISSN:1610-3653. (Springer)
        Volatile org. compds. are a major source of air pollutants. Absorption is an effective soln. to treat polluted air loaded with volatile org. compds., but most actual absorbents are often toxic and non-biodegradable. Here, we tested eutectic solvent mixts. for the absorption of volatile org. compds. for the first time. The affinity of solvent mixts. for toluene, acetaldehyde and dichloromethane was detd. by measuring vapor-liq. partition coeffs. and liq. phase absorption capacities. Results show that the vapor-liq. partition coeffs. vary, at 30Â°C, from close to zero for acetaldehyde in the mixts. choline chloride:urea, choline chloride:glycerol and tetrabutylphosphonium bromide:glycerol to 0.124 for dichloromethane in the choline chloride:urea eutectic mixt. These values are similar or even superior to those published for ionic liqs. and org. solvents. Solvents based on choline chloride, a food additive, and urea, can solubilize up to 500 times more volatile org. compds. compare to water. Moreover, deep eutectic solvents are easier to prep. and more biodegradable than ionic liqs., which are also toxic. Deep eutectic solvents are more biodegradable than silicone oils, which are also expensive. Furthermore, in terms of recycling, the absorption capacities of the tested solvents remained unchanged during five absorption-desorption cycles. These findings are patented.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtlyntb3E&md5=fc10af715553abe836d36fe70206896f
        open URL

        Biodegradable ionic liquids. Part II. Effect of the anion and toxicology
        Garcia, M. Teresa; Gathergood, Nicholas; Scammells, Peter J.
        Green Chemistry (2005), 7 (1), 9-14CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Although ionic liqs. are generally referred to in a 'green' context, little is known about their degrdn. in the environment. Part I of this series focused on the biodegradability of the commonly used dialkylimidazolium ionic liqs. and the effect of the imidazolium cation on biodegradability. We now report the influence of the anion on biodegradability. Preliminary investigations into the toxicol. of ionic liqs. are also described.

        Design and preparation of room-temperature ionic liquids containing biodegradable side chains
        Gathergood, Nicholas; Scammells, Peter J.
        Australian Journal of Chemistry (2002), 55 (9), 557-560CODEN: AJCHAS; ISSN:0004-9425. (CSIRO Publishing)
        Novel room-temp. ionic liqs. with potential sites of enzymic hydrolysis have been prepd. and tested for biodegradable properties. Compds. thus prepd. included 1-(2-methoxy-2-oxoethyl)-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide, 1-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide (I), 1-methyl-3-(2-oxo-2-propoxyethyl)-1H-imidazolium bromide, 1-[2-(butylamino)-2-oxoethyl]-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide, 1-[2-(butylmethylamino)-2-oxoethyl]-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide, and 1-[2-(diethylamino)-2-oxoethyl]-3-methyl-1H-imidazolium bromide and the corresponding tetrafluoroborate, hexafluorophosphate congeners, 1,1,1-trifluoro-N-[(trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl]methanesulfonamide salts and cyanocyanamide salts. I and 1-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-3-methyl-1H-Imidazolium tetrafluoroborate (II) were evaluated in an aerobic aq. medium inoculated with wastewater microorganisms and the evolution of CO2 was measured (Sturm test). II was on the border of pass level for biodegradability, while I degraded more slowly.

        132
        Biodegradable ionic liquids: Part I. Concept, preliminary targets and evaluation
        Gathergood, Nicholas; Garcia, M. Teresa; Scammells, Peter J.
        Green Chemistry (2004), 6 (3), 166-175CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The design, prepn. and evaluation of biodegradable ionic liqs. contg. ester or amide groups in the alkyl side chain are presented. Factors improving the biodegrdn. of surfactants were successfully applied to ionic liqs. These novel ionic liqs. can be prepd. from readily available starting materials in high yield. The introduction of a group susceptible to enzymic hydrolysis greatly improves the biodegrdn. (OECD 301D 'Closed Bottle Test') compared with the commonly used dialkylimidazolium ionic liqs., bmimBF4 and bmimPF6. For the 3-methyl-1-(alkyloxycarbonylmethyl)imidazolium bromide series, the greatest biodegrdn. was obsd. for I (R = n-Bu, n-Pentyl, n-Hexyl, n-Octyl). The corresponding amide analogs proved to be poorly biodegradable.

        Biocompatible Deep Eutectic Solvents Based on Choline Chloride: Characterization and Application to the Extraction of Rutin from Sophora japonica
        Zhao, Bing-Yi; Xu, Pei; Yang, Fu-Xi; Wu, Hong; Zong, Min-Hua; Lou, Wen-Yong
        ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2015), 3 (11), 2746-2755CODEN: ASCECG; ISSN:2168-0485. (American Chemical Society)
        The development of novel green solvents has been one of the hottest subjects in green chem. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have logically and naturally emerged in the search for more biocompatible and biodegradable solvents. In this study, some basic phys. properties, including viscosity, cond., and d., of 20 DESs prepd. from choline chloride and various hydrogen-bond donors were investigated systematically. In addn., the biocompatibility of the tested DESs was qual. and quant. evaluated using two Gram-pos. (Staphylococcus aureus and Listeria monocytogenes) and two Gram-neg. (Escherichia coli and Salmonella enteritidis) bacteria. A closed bottle test was used to assess the biodegradability of these DESs. The results demonstrated that these choline chloride-based DESs were excellent solvents with extremely low toxicity and favorable biodegradability. Finally, DESs were used to ext. a flavonoid (rutin) from the flower buds of Sophora japonica. An extn. efficiency of 194.17 Â± 2.31 mgÂ·g-1 was achieved using choline chloride/triethylene glycol contg. 20% water. The excellent properties of DESs indicate their potential as promising green solvents for the extn. of rutin with favorable prospects for wide use in the field of green technol.

        Solubility of Metal Oxides in Deep Eutectic Solvents Based on Choline Chloride
        Abbott, Andrew P.; Capper, Glen; Davies, David L.; McKenzie, Katy J.; Obi, Stephen U.
        Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data (2006), 51 (4), 1280-1282CODEN: JCEAAX; ISSN:0021-9568. (American Chemical Society)
        The soly. of 17 commonly available metal oxides in the elemental mass series Ti through Zn have been detd. in three ionic liqs. based on choline chloride. The hydrogen bond donors used were urea, malonic acid, and ethylene glycol. The results obtained are compared with aq. solns. of HCl and NaCl. Some correlation is obsd. between the soly. in the deep eutectic solvents and that in aq. solns. but some significant exceptions offer an opportunity for novel extractive metallurgical processes.

      139. 139
        Martins, M. A.; Pinho, S. P.; Coutinho, J. A. Insights into the nature of eutectic and deep eutectic mixtures. J. Solution Chem. 2019, 48 (7), 962â 982,  DOI: 10.1007/s10953-018-0793-1
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        139
        Insights into the Nature of Eutectic and Deep Eutectic Mixtures
        Martins, Monia A. R.; Pinho, Simao P.; Coutinho, Joao A. P.
        Journal of Solution Chemistry (2019), 48 (7), 962-982CODEN: JSLCAG; ISSN:0095-9782. (Springer)
        A review. A stricter definition of a deep eutectic solvent (DES) is urgent, so that it may become a sound basis for further developments in this field. This communication aims at contributing to deepening the understanding of eutectic and deep eutectic mixts. concerning their definition, thermodn. nature and modeling. The glut of literature on DES applications should be followed by a similar effort to address the fundamental questions on their nature. This hopefully would contribute to correct some widespread misconceptions, and help to establish a stringent definition of what a DES is. DES are eutectic mixts. for which the eutectic point temp. should be lower to that of an ideal liq. mixt. To identify and characterize them, their phase diagrams should be known, in order to compare the real temp. depression to that predicted if ideality is assumed, and to define compn. ranges for which they are in the liq. state at operating temps. It is also shown that hydrogen bonding between the DES components should not be used to define or characterize a DES, since this would describe many ideal mixts. The future of deep eutectic solvents is quite promising, and we expect that this work will contribute to the efficient design and selection of the best DES for a given application, and to model properties and phase equil. without which the process design is impractical.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        open URL

        Florindo, C.; Branco, L. C.; Marrucho, I. M. Quest for green-solvent design: from hydrophilic to hydrophobic (deep) eutectic solvents. ChemSusChem 2019, 12 (8), 1549â 1559,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201900147
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        142
        Quest for Green-Solvent Design: From Hydrophilic to Hydrophobic (Deep) Eutectic Solvents
        Florindo, Catarina; Branco, Luis C.; Marrucho, Isabel M.
        ChemSusChem (2019), 12 (8), 1549-1559CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) consist of a mixt. of â¥2 solid components, which gives rise to a lower m.p. compared to the starting materials. Until recently only hydrophilic DESs were available, and despite their revolutionary role in the alternative-solvents field, important issues in chem., and chem. engineering (such as H2O-related problems and the replacement of toxic volatile org. compds.) could not be tackled. Hydrophobic (deep)-here in parenthesis due to the different depths of the eutectic m.ps.-eutectic solvents are a subclass of DESs where both components are hydrophobic. The low toxicity, high biodegradability, and straightforward prepn. without further purifn. steps of naturally occurring low-cost compds. are among the key advantages. Although research on hydrophobic DESs is scarce (the 1st report was only published in 2015), some interesting features and applications were reported and deserve to be evaluated and comparisons established. This Minireview is divided into 2 parts: The 1st part provides a brief general introduction to DESs and the 2nd part discusses the nomenclature using solid-liq. phase diagram anal., chem. stability, thermophys. properties comparison, and finally the most important emerging fields of application.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmvVCmu78%253D&md5=290aead0c8918010593b42628c359ef7
        open URL
      143. 143
        Shahbaz, K.; Baroutian, S.; Mjalli, F.; Hashim, M.; AlNashef, I. Densities of ammonium and phosphonium based deep eutectic solvents: Prediction using artificial intelligence and group contribution techniques. Thermochim. Acta 2012, 527, 59â 66,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tca.2011.10.010
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        143
        Densities of ammonium and phosphonium based deep eutectic solvents: Prediction using artificial intelligence and group contribution techniques
        Shahbaz, K.; Baroutian, S.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M.
        Thermochimica Acta (2012), 527 (), 59-66CODEN: THACAS; ISSN:0040-6031. (Elsevier B.V.)
        As applications of deep eutectic solvents are growing fast as green alternatives, prediction of phys. properties data for such systems becomes a necessity for engineering application designs and new process developments. In this study, densities of three classes of deep eutectic solvents, based on a phosphonium and two ammonium salts, were measured. Two predictive models based on artificial intelligence and group contribution methods were proposed for accurate estn. and evaluation of deep eutectic solvent densities. A feed forward back propagation neural network with 9 hidden neurons was successfully developed and trained with the measured d. data. The group contribution method applied the modified Lydersen-Joback-Reid, Lee-Kesler and the modified Rackett equations. The comparison of the predicted densities with those obtained by measurement confirmed the reliability of the neural network and the group contribution method with av. abs. errors of 0.14 and 2.03%, resp. Comparison of the model performances indicated a better predictability of the developed neural network over the group contribution method.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1Sls7vI&md5=755dbbc05ac199c4675ef418c0e03234
        open URL

        Abbott, A. P.; Barron, J. C.; Ryder, K. S.; Wilson, D. Eutectic-based ionic liquids with metal-containing anions and cations. ChemistryâA European Journal 2007, 13 (22), 6495â 6501,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200601738
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        144
        Eutectic-based ionic liquids with metal-containing anions and cations
        Abbott, Andrew P.; Barron, John C.; Ryder, Karl S.; Wilson, David
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (22), 6495-6501CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Eutectic mixts. of zinc chloride and donor mols. such as urea and acetamide are described and it is proposed that these constitute a new class of ionic liqs. FAB-MS anal. shows that the liqs. are made up of metal-contg. anions and cations in which the donor is coordinated to the cation. Data on the viscosity, cond., d., phase behavior and surface tension are presented and these are shown to be significantly different to other related ionic liqs. that incorporate quaternary ammonium salts. The cond. and viscosity are comparable with other ionic liqs. and the data fit well to the Hole theory model recently proposed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXptVWrsLk%253D&md5=106e5ede49a682ea0a51cd2494593c31
        open URL
      145. 145
        Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F.; Hashim, M.; AlNashef, I. Prediction of deep eutectic solvents densities at different temperatures. Thermochimica acta 2011, 515 (1â2), 67â 72,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tca.2010.12.022
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        145
        Prediction of deep eutectic solvents densities at different temperatures
        Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F. S.; Hashim, M. A.; AlNashef, I. M.
        Thermochimica Acta (2011), 515 (1-2), 67-72CODEN: THACAS; ISSN:0040-6031. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Predicting densities of nonconventional solvents like deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as a function of temp. is of considerable importance in the development and design of new processes utilizing these solvents. Because of the nature of bonding existing between the salt and the hydrogen bond donor, conventional methods result in very large deviations. In this study, the d. of DESs based on three different salts was estd. using empirical method. Nine different salts:hydrogen bond donor combinations were selected to test this method. The densities of all DESs were measured at a temp. range (298.15-368.1 K). The crit. properties of salt and hydrogen bond donor were estd. using the Modified Lydersen-Joback-Reid method, while that of the mixt. were calcd. using Lee-Kesler equation. The Rackett equation modified by Spencer and Danner was employed to predict the DES d. The values of measured and predicted densities were compared and the av. of abs. relative error percentage (ARPE) for all DESs was found to be 1.9%. The effect of salt to HBD molar ratio on ARPE in predicted DESs densities was also investigated.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXitFaqtLw%253D&md5=43da381f40b75fa9da8b11614d018d83
        open URL
      146. 146
        Delgado-Mellado, N.; Larriba, M.; Navarro, P.; Rigual, V.; Ayuso, M.; GarcÃ­a, J.; RodrÃ­guez, F. Thermal stability of choline chloride deep eutectic solvents by TGA/FTIR-ATR analysis. J. Mol. Liq. 2018, 260, 37â 43,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2018.03.076
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        146
        Thermal stability of choline chloride deep eutectic solvents by TGA/FTIR-ATR analysis
        Delgado-Mellado, Noemi; Larriba, Marcos; Navarro, Pablo; Rigual, Victoria; Ayuso, Miguel; Garcia, Julian; Rodriguez, Francisco
        Journal of Molecular Liquids (2018), 260 (), 37-43CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) based on the cation choline have been proposed to date for a variety of applications due to their remarkable physicochem. properties. The thermal stability is one of the first properties of DESs that needs to be known since it limits the max. operating temp. for which these solvents are useful in many applications. In this work, the thermal stability of eight different choline chloride-based DESs formed using levulinic acid, malonic acid, glycerol, ethylene glycol, phenylacetic acid, phenylpropionic acid, urea, and glucose as hydrogen bond donors (HBDs) has been studied using isothermal and dynamic thermogravimetric anal./Fourier transform IR-attenuated total reflectance spectroscopy (TGA/FTIR-ATR) techniques. Isothermal and dynamic FTIR-ATR were carried out to confirm the formation and to show the structural changes with temp. of the DESs, resp. The onset decompn. temps. of the DESs were obtained from dynamic TGA. However, the max. operating temps. detd. by isothermal TGA in long-term scenarios have demonstrated to be significantly lower than the onset decompn. temps. for every DES studied. The thermal stability and the b.p. of HBDs have a crucial impact on the max. operating temp. of DESs.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXlvFKru70%253D&md5=b040a3ee1600695eb8614c21ff42128a
        open URL

        Geiculescu, O.; DesMarteau, D.; Creager, S.; Haik, O.; Hirshberg, D.; Shilina, Y.; Zinigrad, E.; Levi, M.; Aurbach, D.; Halalay, I.         Novel binary deep eutectic electrolytes for rechargeable Li-ion batteries based on mixtures of alkyl sulfonamides and lithium perfluoroalkylsulfonimide salts
        Geiculescu, O. E.; Des Marteau, D. D.; Creager, S. E.; Haik, O.; Hirshberg, D.; Shilina, Y.; Zinigrad, E.; Levi, M. D.; Aurbach, D.; Halalay, I. C.
        Journal of Power Sources (2016), 307 (), 519-525CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Ionic liqs. (IL's) were proposed for use in Li-ion batteries (LIBs), in order to mitigate some of the well-known drawbacks of LiPF6/mixed org. carbonates solns. However, their large cations seriously decrease lithium transference nos. and block lithium insertion sites at electrode-electrolyte interfaces, leading to poor LIB rate performance. Deep eutectic electrolytes (DEEs) (which share some of the advantages of ILs but possess only one cation, Li+), were then proposed, in order to overcome the difficulties assocd. with ILs. We report herein on the prepn., thermal properties (melting, crystn., and glass transition temps.), transport properties (specific cond. and viscosity) and thermal stability of binary DEEs based on mixts. of lithium bis(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide or lithium bis(fluoro)sulfonimide salts with an alkyl sulfonamide solvent. Promise for LIB applications is demonstrated by chronoamperometry on Al current collectors, and cycling behavior of neg. and pos. electrodes. Residual current densities of 12 and 45 nA/cm2 were obsd. at 5 V vs. Li/Li+ on aluminum, 1.5 and 16 nA/cm2 at 4.5 V vs. Li/Li+, resp. for LiFSI and LiTFSI based DEEs. Capacities of 220, 130, and 175 mAh/g were obsd. at low (C/13 or C/10) rates, resp. for petroleum coke, LiMn1/3Ni1/3Co1/3O2 (a.k.a. NMC 111) and LiAl0.05Co0.15Ni0.8O2 (a.k.a. NCA).
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Bio-inspired choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents as electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries
        Millia, Luca; Dall'Asta, Valentina; Ferrara, Chiara; Berbenni, Vittorio; Quartarone, Eliana; Perna, Filippo Maria; Capriati, Vito; Mustarelli, Piercarlo
        Solid State Ionics (2018), 323 (), 44-48CODEN: SSIOD3; ISSN:0167-2738. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The safety issues of lithium-ion batteries require the substitution of volatile and flammable org. components of the electrolyte. In this context, deep eutectic solvents (DESs) represent an interesting alternative to conventional ionic liqs. as green solvents to dissolve common lithium salts. This paper explores two eutectics: i. ethylene glycol/choline chloride (EG/ChCl, 3:1 mol/mol), and ii. L-(+)-lactic acid/choline chloride (LA/ChCl, 2:1 mol/mol). The lithium salts added in both cases were LiN(CF3SO2)2 and LiPF6, both in concn. of either 0.5 M or 1 M. They still retain their liq. properties despite the addn. of relatively high molar contents (up to 1.0 M) of lithium salts. The 0.5 M LiPF6/EG:ChCl electrolyte, in particular, displays ionic cond. of 7.95 mS cm-1 at room temp., and is thus very promising as a green and cheap electrolyte.

        Tripathy, S. N.; Wojnarowska, Z.; Knapik, J.; Shirota, H.; Biswas, R.; Paluch, M. Glass transition dynamics and conductivity scaling in ionic deep eutectic solvents: The case of (acetamide+ lithium nitrate/sodium thiocyanate) melts. J. Chem. Phys. 2015, 142 (18), 184504,  DOI: 10.1063/1.4919946
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        149
        Glass transition dynamics and conductivity scaling in ionic deep eutectic solvents: The case of (acetamide + lithium nitrate/sodium thiocyanate) melts
        Tripathy, Satya N.; Wojnarowska, Zaneta; Knapik, Justyna; Shirota, Hideaki; Biswas, Ranjit; Paluch, Marian
        Journal of Chemical Physics (2015), 142 (18), 184504/1-184504/10CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
        A detailed study on the mol. dynamics of ionic deep eutectic solvents (acetamide + lithium nitrate/sodium thiocyanate) is reported. The study was carried out employing dielec. relaxation spectroscopy covering seven decades in frequency (10-1-106 Hz) and in a wide temp. range from 373 K down to 173 K, accessing the dynamic observables both in liq. and glassy state. The dielec. response of the ionic system was presented in the dynamic window of modulus formalism to understand the cond. relaxation and its possible connection to the origin of localized motion. Two secondary relaxation processes appear below glass transition temp. The findings provide suitable interpretation on the nature of secondary Johari-Goldstein process describing the ion translation and orientation of dipoles in a combined approach using Ngai's coupling model. A nearly const. loss feature is witnessed at shorter times/lower temps. The authors also discuss the a.c. cond. scaling behavior using Summerfield approach and random free energy barrier model which establish the time-temp. superposition principle. These exptl. observations have fundamental importance on theor. elucidation of the cond. relaxation and glass transition phenomena in molten ionic conductors. (c) 2015 American Institute of Physics.

        open URL

        Nunes, Ricardo J.; Saramago, Benilde; Marrucho, Isabel M.
        Journal of Chemical & Engineering Data (2019), 64 (11), 4915-4923CODEN: JCEAAX; ISSN:0021-9568. (American Chemical Society)
        Although they have been known since the early 2000s, it was not until recent years that deep eutectic solvents and eutectic mixts. began to be systematically studied as cheaper and more environmentally friendly alternative solvents. The introduction of hydrophobic, all-natural, neutral eutectic mixts. affords new applications, which need accurate measurements of thermophys. properties. In this work, the surface tension of DL-menthol:octanoic acid eutectic mixts. was studied over the whole range of compn. from 298.15 to 333.15 K.         Glycerol-based deep eutectic solvents: Physical properties
        AlOmar, Mohamed Khalid; Hayyan, Maan; Alsaadi, Mohammed Abdulhakim; Akib, Shatirah; Hayyan, Adeeb; Hashim, Mohd Ali
        Journal of Molecular Liquids (2016), 215 (), 98-103CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have been used in many industrial applications. DES is a mixt. of a salt and a hydrogen bond donor (HBD). In this study, 70 DESs were synthesized successfully based on glycerol (Gly) as the HBD with different phosphonium and ammonium salts, namely Me tri-Ph phosphonium bromide (MTPB), benzyl tri-Ph phosphonium chloride (BTPC), allyl tri-Ph phosphonium bromide (ATPB), choline chloride (ChCl), N,N-diethylethanolammonium chloride (DAC), and tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (TBAB). The DESs were prepd. using different molar ratios of the HBD to the salts. The f.p. of each DES was detd. using Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC). The phys. properties of these DESs, including d., viscosity, cond., and surface tension, were investigated as functions of temp. In addn., the functional groups were analyzed utilizing Fourier transform IR (FTIR) spectroscopy. It is worth noting that these systems have a wide variety of phys. properties, which implies that these DESs would be suitable for diverse applications.

        Abbott, A. P.; Barron, J. C.; Frisch, G.; Gurman, S.; Ryder, K. S.; Silva, A. F. Double layer effects on metal nucleation in deep eutectic solvents. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2011, 13 (21), 10224â 10231,  DOI: 10.1039/c0cp02244f
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        152
        Double layer effects on metal nucleation in deep eutectic solvents
        Abbott, Andrew P.; Barron, John C.; Frisch, Gero; Gurman, Stephen; Ryder, Karl S.; Fernando Silva, A.
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2011), 13 (21), 10224-10231CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The electrodeposition of Zn was studied in two deep eutectic solvents. Unlike the metals studied to date in these liqs., Zn electrodeposition is not mass transport limited and the morphol. of the deposit differs in the two liqs. Changing the concn. of solute affects the phys. properties of the liq. to different extents although this is found to not effect the morphol. of the metal deposited. EXAFS was used to show that the speciation of Zn was the same in both liqs. Double layer capacitance studies showed differences between the two liqs. and these probably are due to the adsorption of a species on the electrode which probably is chloride. The differences in Zn morphol. is attributed to blocking of certain crystal faces leading to deposition of small platelet shaped crystals in the glycol based liq.

        Chen, W.; Bai, X.; Xue, Z.; Mou, H.; Chen, J.; Liu, Z.; Mu, T. The formation and physicochemical properties of PEGylated deep eutectic solvents. New J. Chem. 2019, 43 (22), 8804â 8810,  DOI: 10.1039/C9NJ02196E

        The formation and physicochemical properties of PEGylated deep eutectic solvents
        Chen, Wenjun; Bai, Xiyue; Xue, Zhimin; Mou, Hongyu; Chen, Jiangang; Liu, Zhaotie; Mu, Tiancheng
        New Journal of Chemistry (2019), 43 (22), 8804-8810CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have attracted considerable attention due to their unique properties. In recent years, novel deep eutectic solvents based on polyethylene glycol (PEG) have been proposed, which are called PEGylated DESs. Owing to their excellent properties, PEGylated DESs have been applied in many fields, such as extn., biomass dissoln. and material prepn. For better application of PEGylated DESs in various fields, the solid understanding of their fundamental properties is indispensable. In this work, nine PEGylated DESs based on carboxylic acids, amides and ammonium salts were prepd. and characterized by FTIR, 1H NMR and DSC anal. The physicochem. properties including pH values, polarity, d., viscosity, cond., and thermal stability were investigated. Walden plot anal. was also conducted in order to evaluate the ionicity of the PEGylated DESs. The nature of the components plays a vital role in the properties of the PEG based DESs. There is a neg. correlation between the pH values and polarity of the PEGylated DESs, which can be applied to infer the polarity via pH measurement. The d. and viscosity gradually decrease with increasing temp. due to thermal expansion. Except for the ammonium salt based DESs, the PEGylated DESs exhibit a "poor ionic" nature and have a negligible cond. owing to the lack of ionic species. According to the above research, PEGylated DESs with specific properties could be elaborately designed via choosing appropriate components, thus facilitating their application.

        Abbott, A. P.; Harris, R. C.; Ryder, K. S.; DâAgostino, C.; Gladden, L. F.; Mantle, M. D. Glycerol eutectics as sustainable solvent systems. Green Chem. 2011, 13 (1), 82â 90,  DOI: 10.1039/C0GC00395F

        154
        Glycerol eutectics as sustainable solvent systems
        Abbott, Andrew P.; Harris, Robert C.; Ryder, Karl S.; D'Agostino, Carmine; Gladden, Lynn F.; Mantle, Mick D.
        Green Chemistry (2011), 13 (1), 82-90CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        In this work the use of glycerol as a hydrogen bond donor in Deep Eutectic Solvents is studied. The phys. properties of choline chloride mixts. with glycerol are quantified and it is shown that eutectic mixts. can circumvent some of the difficulties of using glycerol as a solvent viz. high viscosity and high m.p. The solvent properties are characterized using polarity parameters and the values are similar to other ionic liqs. although it is shown that this procedure is a poor method of characterizing Lewis basicity. The application of these liqs. to the esterification of glycerol is used as a demonstration of the ability to tune a reaction with the quaternary ammonium halide acting as a quasi-protecting group. The liqs. represent a sustainable way of prepg. non-toxic, tuneable solvent systems.

        GarcÃ­a, G.; Aparicio, S.; Ullah, R.; Atilhan, M. Deep eutectic solvents: physicochemical properties and gas separation applications. Energy Fuels 2015, 29 (4), 2616â 2644,  DOI: 10.1021/ef5028873
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        155
        Deep Eutectic Solvents: Physicochemical Properties and Gas Separation Applications
        Garcia, Gregorio; Aparicio, Santiago; Ullah, Ruh; Atilhan, Mert
        Energy & Fuels (2015), 29 (4), 2616-2644CODEN: ENFUEM; ISSN:0887-0624. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Sustainable technologies applied to energy-related applications should develop a pivotal role in the next decades. In particular, carbon dioxide capture from flue gases emitted by fossil-fueled power plants should play a pivotal role in controlling and reducing the greenhouse effect. Therefore, the development of new materials for carbon capture purposes has merged as central research line, for which many alternatives were proposed. Ionic liqs. (ILs) have emerged as one of the most promising choices for carbon capture, but in spite of their promising properties, some serious drawbacks have also appeared. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have recently been considered as alternatives to ILs that maintain most of their relevant properties, such as task-specific character, and at the same time avoid some of their problems, mainly from economic and environmental viewpoints. DES prodn. from low-cost and natural sources, together with their almost null toxicity and total biodegradability, makes these solvents a suitable platform for developing gas sepn. agents within the green chem. framework. Therefore, because of the promising characteristics of DESs as CO2 absorbents and in general as gas sepg. agents, the state of the art on physicochem. properties of DESs in relation to their influence on gas sepn. mechanisms and on the studies of gas soly. in DESs are discussed. The objective of this review work is to analyze the current knowledge on gas sepn. using DESs, comparing the capturing abilities and properties of DESs with those of ILs, inferring the weaknesses and strengths of DESs, and proposing future research directions on this subject.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjsVWrs74%253D&md5=895a9e93f09fb4d88b2294a1817a5909
        open URL

        Fruit sugar-based deep eutectic solvents and their physical properties

        In this study, a novel fructose-based DES of choline chloride (2-hydroxyethyl-trimethylammonium) has been synthesized at different molar ratios. The suggested DESs have many desirable characteristics, e.g. they have low vapor pressure, inflammable, biodegradable, and made from renewable resources.         Solvatochromic Dyes as Solvent Polarity Indicators
        Reichardt, Christian
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (1994), 94 (8), 2319-58CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665.
        This review with 345 refs. compiles pos. and neg. solvatochromic compds. which have been used to establish empirical scales of solvent polarity by means of UV/visible/near-IR spectroscopic measurements in soln. with particular emphasis on the ET(30) scale derived from neg. solvatochromic pyridinium N-phenolate betaine dyes. A discussion is presented on the concept of solvent polarity and how empirical parameters of solvent polarity can be derived and understood in the framework of linear free-energy relationships.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXntV2gtrY%253D&md5=8fd8a3f562211929e30191207fe97e33

      158. 158
        Pandey, A.; Rai, R.; Pal, M.; Pandey, S. How polar are choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents?. Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2014, 16 (4), 1559â 1568,  DOI: 10.1039/C3CP53456A
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        158
        How polar are choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents?
        Pandey, Ashish; Rai, Rewa; Pal, Mahi; Pandey, Siddharth
        Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2014), 16 (4), 1559-1568CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Developing and characterizing green solvents with low toxicity and cost is one of the most important issues in chem. Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs), in this regard, have shown tremendous promise. Compared to popular org. solvents, DESs possess negligible VOCs and are non-flammable. Compared to ionic liqs., which share many characteristics but are ionic compds. and not ionic mixts., DESs are cheaper to make, much less toxic and mostly biodegradable. An est. of the polarity assocd. with DESs is essential if they are to be used as green alternatives to common org. solvents in industries and academia. As no one phys. parameter can satisfactorily represent solute-solvent interactions within a medium, polarity of DESs is assessed through solvatochromic optical spectroscopic responses of several UV-vis absorbance and mol. fluorescence probes. Information on the local microenvironment (i.e., the cybotactic region) that surrounds several solvatochromic probes [betaine dye, pyrene, pyrene-1-carboxaldehyde, 1-anilino-8-naphthalene sulfonate (ANS), p-toluidinyl-6-naphthalene sulfonate (TNS), 6-propionyl-2-(dimethylaminonaphthalene) (PRODAN), coumarin-153, and Nile Red] for four common and popular DESs formed from choline chloride combined with 1,2-ethanediol, glycerol, urea, and malonic acid, resp., in 1 : 2 molar ratios termed ethaline, glyceline, reline, and maline is obtained and used to assess the effective polarity afforded by each of these DESs. The four DESs as indicated by these probe responses are found to be fairly dipolar in nature. Absorbance probe betaine dye and fluorescence probes ANS, TNS, PRODAN, coumarin-153, and Nile Red, whose solvatochromic responses are based on photoinduced charge-transfer, imply ethaline and glyceline, DESs formed using alc.-based H-bond donors, to be relatively more dipolar in nature as compared to reline and maline. The pyrene polarity scale, which is based on polarity-induced changes in vibronic bands, indicates reline, the DES composed of urea as the hydrogen bond donor, to be significantly more dipolar than the other three DESs. Response of pyrene-1-carboxaldehyde, a polarity probe based on inversion of n-Ï* and Ï-Ï* states, hints at maline to be the most dipolar of the four DESs. The mol. structure of the H-bond donor in a DES clearly controls the dipolarity afforded by the DES. H-bonding and other specific solute-solvent interactions are found to play an important role in solvatochromic probe behavior for the four DESs. The cybotactic region of a probe dissolved in a DES affords information on the polarity of the DES towards solutes of similar nature and functionality.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFCrtr7I&md5=aa15792e0d3b62c0102c1dc52bbfc9de
        open URL
      159. 159
        Pandey, A.; Pandey, S. Solvatochromic probe behavior within choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents: effect of temperature and water. J. Phys. Chem. B 2014, 118 (50), 14652â 14661,  DOI: 10.1021/jp510420h
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        159
        Solvatochromic Probe Behavior within Choline Chloride-Based Deep Eutectic Solvents: Effect of Temperature and Water
        Pandey, Ashish; Pandey, Siddharth
        Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2014), 118 (50), 14652-14661CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have shown potential as promising environmentally friendly alternatives to conventional solvents. Many common and popular DESs are obtained by simply mixing a salt and a H-bond donor. Properties of such a DES depend on its constituents. Change in temp. and addn. of water, a benign cosolvent, can change the physicochem. properties of DESs. The effect of changing temp. and addn. of water on solvatochromic probe behavior within three DESs formed from choline chloride combined with 1,2-ethanediol, glycerol, and urea, resp., in 1:2 mol ratios termed ethaline, glyceline, and reline is presented. Increase in temp. results in reduced H-bond donating acidity of the DESs. Dipolarity/polarizability and H-bond accepting basicity do not change with changing temp. of the DESs. The response of the fluorescence probe pyrene also indicates a decrease in the polarity of the DESs as temp. is increased. Addn. of water to DES results in increased dipolarity/polarizability and a decrease in H-bond accepting basicity. Except for pyrene, solvatochromic probes exhibit responses close to those predicted from ideal-additive behavior with slight preferential solvation by DES within the aq. mixts. Pyrene response reveals significant preferential solvation by DES and/or the presence of solvent-solvent interactions, esp. within aq. mixts. of ethaline and glyceline, the DESs constituted of H-bond donors with hydroxyl functionalities. FTIR absorbance and Raman spectroscopic measurements of aq. DES mixts. support the outcomes from solvatochromic probe responses. Aq. mixts. of ethaline and glyceline possess relatively more interspecies H-bonds as compared to aq. mixts. of reline, where interstitial accommodation of water within the reline mol. network appears to dominate.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFOjsrrP&md5=1b1f2cfd49c97d6c6f5332e970ae28ca
        open URL
      160. 160
        Ma, Y.; Wang, Q.; Zhu, T. Comparison of hydrophilic and hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for pretreatment determination of sulfonamides from aqueous environments. Analytical Methods 2019, 11 (46), 5901â 5909,  DOI: 10.1039/C9AY02244A
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        160
        Comparison of hydrophilic and hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for pretreatment determination of sulfonamides from aqueous environments
        Ma, Yuxin; Wang, Qi; Zhu, Tao
        Analytical Methods (2019), 11 (46), 5901-5909CODEN: AMNEGX; ISSN:1759-9679. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Seven hydrophilic and hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (DESs) were prepd. The phys. properties, water soly., viscosity, d. and f.p. of DESs were detd. The characterization of DESs was performed by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The extn. efficiencies accomplished by two distinct approaches, namely, dispersive liq.-liq. microextn. (DLLM) with hydrophobic DESs and the aq. two-phase system (ATPSs) with hydrophilic DESs were compared. ATPSs based on hydrophilic DES were used to ext. sulfonamides, revealing good extn. efficiency. The optimum extn. conditions were the concn. of K2HPO4 being 0.2 g mL-1 and the vol. of DES being 200Î¼L. Under these conditions, the satisfactory recoveries of the proposed method investigated ranged from 87.7 to 95.6% with the relative std. deviation (RSD) of 0.9-3.1% (n = 3). The linear range was 0.10-50.0Î¼g mL-1 for the four sulfonamides. The limits of detection were in the range from 0.003 to 0.006Î¼g mL-1 and the limits of quantification were in the range from 0.010 to 0.020Î¼g mL-1. The results indicated that the proposed method was successfully applied for monitoring sulfonamides in water samples.

        Shahbaz, K.; Mjalli, F. S.; Vakili-Nezhaad, G.; AlNashef, I. M.; Asadov, A.; Farid, M. M. Thermogravimetric measurement of deep eutectic solvents vapor pressure. J. Mol. Liq. 2016, 222, 61â 66,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2016.06.106

        Thermogravimetric measurement of deep eutectic solvents vapor pressure
        Shahbaz, Kaveh; Mjalli, Farouq S.; Vakili-Nezhaad, Gholamreza; AlNashef, Inas M.; Asadov, Alec; Farid, Mohammed M.
        Journal of Molecular Liquids (2016), 222 (), 61-66CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Knowledge of volatility of solvents in general and ionic liqs. analogs in particular is crucial for thermodn. modeling and proper solvent selection. In this study, the vapor pressure of a selected set of ionic liqs. analogs known as deep eutectic solvents (DES) was investigated by thermogravimetric anal. (TGA). The exptl. measurements were conducted for the practical temp. range of 343.15 to 393.15 K. In general, measurements revealed that DESs have low but detectable vapor pressure. Compared to some common ionic liqs., DESs have higher vapor pressure. It is interesting to know that the vapor pressure-temp. relationship of DESs is more complex than that of mol. liqs. as well as that of most ionic liqs. The conventional Antoine model was not able to explain the variation of vapor pressure with temp. However, the vapor pressure was found to exhibit a noticeable trend with the DES crit. temp. which was estd. theor. The Wagner vapor pressure model was able to predict the vapor pressure with an av. %AAD of 2.89%.

        Vapor pressure of aqueous choline chloride-based deep eutectic solvents (ethaline, glyceline, maline and reline) at 30-70 Â°C
        Wu, Sheng-Hong; Caparanga, Alvin R.; Leron, Rhoda B.; Li, Meng-Hui

        A new set of vapor pressure data for the aq. solns. of ethaline, glyceline, maline, and reline at different temps. (30, 40, 50, 60, and 70 Â°C) and concns. (20, 40, 60, and 80 wt%) are presented. The data successfully fit the classic Antoine equation, for the temp.-dependence of the vapor pressure, and a Volger-Tamman-Fulcher-type equation, for the concn.-dependence of the vapor pressure. The % AADs for the exptl. and calcd. data were all less than 0.5%.

        Dwamena, A. K. Recent advances in hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for extraction. Separations 2019, 6 (1), 9,  DOI: 10.3390/separations6010009

        163
        Recent advances in hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for extraction
        Dwamena, Amos K.
        Separations (2019), 6 (1), 9CODEN: SEPAF2 ISSN:. (MDPI AG)
        A review. In the over 1,800 articles published since their inception in 2001, most deep eutectic solvents (DES) synthesized have been hydrophilic. The low cost, low toxicity, and bioavailability of DES make the solvent 'green' and sustainable for diverse applications. Conversely, the hydrophilicity of DES limits their practical application to only polar compds., which is a major drawback of the solvent. For the past three years, hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (HDES) have emerged as an alternative extractive media capable of extg. non-polar org. and inorg. mols. from aq. environments. Due to the infancy of HDES, for the first time, this mini-review summarizes the recent developmental advances in HDES synthesis, applications, challenges, and future perspectives of the solvent. In the future, it is believed HDES will replace the majority of toxic org. solvents used for anal. purposes.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsFOjsL%252FN&md5=37655ef4b5ecd16eabc1622a9dcce1df
        open URL
      164. 164
        Passos, H.; Tavares, D. J.; Ferreira, A. M.; Freire, M. G.; Coutinho, J. A. Are aqueous biphasic systems composed of deep eutectic solvents ternary or quaternary systems?. ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng. 2016, 4 (5), 2881â 2886,  DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.6b00485
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        164
        Are Aqueous Biphasic Systems Composed of Deep Eutectic Solvents Ternary or Quaternary Systems?
        Passos, Helena; Tavares, Daniel J. P.; Ferreira, Ana M.; Freire, Mara G.; Coutinho, Joao A. P.
        ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2016), 4 (5), 2881-2886CODEN: ASCECG; ISSN:2168-0485. (American Chemical Society)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DES) have emerged in the past few years as a new class of solvents with promising applications in several fields. In the present work, the application of DES (formed by binary mixts. of cholinium chloride and carboxylic acids or urea) as phase-forming components of aq. biphasic systems (ABS) is investigated. The mechanisms assocd. with the phases demixing of ABS composed of DES, as well as the DES stability in aq. solns., are investigated to address the crit. question whether DES-based ABS are in fact ternary or quaternary mixts. The DES integrity is destroyed in ABS by the disruption of the hydrogen-bonding interactions of the complex (a result of the isolated components preferential solvation by water), and as confirmed by a nonstoichiometric partition of the DES components between the coexisting phases. As a result, there are no "real" DES-based ABS; instead, there is the formation of ABS composed of four components, where the carboxylic acid used as the hydrogen-bond donor species seems to act as an additive. Finally, these ABS have an outstanding potential to be used in extn. processes, as it is here demonstrated with the complete sepn. of two dyes. However, the volatile nature of short chain carboxylic acids and the nonstoichiometric partition of the DES components in ABS make the development of recovery and recycling steps more difficult to accomplish.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xls1KisbY%253D&md5=6a1c4e540c1c2ca0053cd3b4b0c19a78
        open URL

        Development of hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents for extraction of pesticides from aqueous environments
        Florindo, C.; Branco, L. C.; Marrucho, I. M.
        Fluid Phase Equilibria (2017), 448 (), 135-142CODEN: FPEQDT; ISSN:0378-3812. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Wastewater treatment plants do not properly address the removal of emerging micropollutants, such as pesticides, and thus these compds. contaminate water sources of public drinking water systems. In this context, this work focuses on the development of hydrophobic deep eutectic solvents (DESs), as cheap extractants for the removal of four neonicotinoids, Imidacloprid, Acetamiprid, Nitenpyram and Thiamethoxam, from dild. aq. solns. In particular, two different families of DESs, one based on natural neutral ingredients (DL-Menthol and natural org. acids) and the other based on quaternary ammonium salts and org. acids were prepd. and their water stability carefully studied through 1H NMR. Only the chem. stable DESs were selected to be used as solvents in the extn. of the four neonicotinoids so that no contamination of the water cycle is attained, while reuse of the DES is possible. The final results were compared with those obtained for liq.-liq. extn. using hydrophobic imidazolium-based ionic liqs. as solvents.

        Development of deep eutectic solvents applied in extraction and separation
        Li, Xiaoxia; Row, Kyung Ho
        Journal of Separation Science (2016), 39 (18), 3505-3520CODEN: JSSCCJ; ISSN:1615-9314. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Deep eutectic solvents, as a substitute of ionic liqs., have greener credentials than ionic liqs., and have attracted considerable attention in related chem. research. Deep eutectic solvents have attracted increasing attention in chem. for the extn. and sepn. of various target compds. from natural products. This review highlights the prepn. of deep eutectic solvents, unique properties of deep eutectic solvents, and synthesis of deep-eutectic-solvent-based materials. On the other hand, application in the extn. and sepn. of deep eutectic solvents is also included in this report. In this paper, the available data and refs. in this field are reviewed to summarize the applications and developments of deep eutectic solvents. Based on the development of deep eutectic solvents, an exploitation of new deep eutectic solvents and deep eutectic solvents-based materials is expected to diversify into extn. and sepn. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

        Deep eutectic solvent-based extraction coupled with green two-dimensional HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS/MS for the determination of anthocyanins from Lycium ruthenicum Murr. fruit
        Sang, Jun; Li, Bing; Huang, Ya-ya; Ma, Qun; Liu, Kang; Li, Cui-qin
        Analytical Methods (2018), 10 (10), 1247-1257CODEN: AMNEGX; ISSN:1759-9679. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This study aimed to ext. and sep. total anthocyanins from Lycium ruthenicum Murr. by combining deep eutectic solvents (DES) with macroporous resin chromatog. and to develop green anal. methods for the detn. of anthocyanins. Choline chloride/1,2-propanediol (1 : 2, mol mol-1) contg. 10% water (vol./vol.) was screened as the optimal extn. solvent, and extn. at 52 Â°C for 45 min using a liq./solid ratio of 20 : 1 gave the max. extn. yield of total anthocyanins (4.45 Â± 0.07 mg g-1). According to the static/dynamic adsorption and desorption tests, LS-32 macroporous resin has the ability to sep. anthocyanins from DES with a recovery ratio above 95%. An off-line heart-cutting two-dimensional HPLC-DAD/ESI-MS method was developed for the qual. and quant. anal. of L. ruthenicum anthocyanins using environmentally friendly mobile phases. Ethanol and a tartaric acid soln. (0.3 mol L-1) were used as the mobile phases of the first-dimensional HPLC-DAD method, and 15 anthocyanin peaks were detected within 17 min. The second-dimensional HPLC-MS method was used to identify the main anthocyanin peaks in the first dimension. Method validation showed that the developed method was accurate, stable and reliable for the anal. of L. ruthenicum anthocyanins. The present study provides an excellent alternative green method for the prepn. and detn. of anthocyanins from plant material.

        Towards a sulfur clean fuel: Deep extraction of thiophene and dibenzothiophene using polyethylene glycol-based deep eutectic solvents
        Lima, Filipa; Gouvenaux, Justine; Branco, Luis C.; Silvestre, Armando J. D.; Marrucho, Isabel M.
        Fuel (2018), 234 (), 414-421CODEN: FUELAC; ISSN:0016-2361. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        In this work, extractive desulfurization of model fuel contg. dibenzothiophene (DBT) and thiophene (Th) as sulfur compds. was carried out using 16 different Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES) based on polyethylene glycol (PEG) and its precursors. The aim of this study is the redn. of the sulfur content of fuels below the environmental regulation (10 ppm), using PEG-based DES as low-cost extn. media under mild conditions and to compare their extractive performance with that of PEG alone, which by itself is a green solvent. For that purpose, 7 different quaternary ammonium and phosphonium salts were combined with four different mol. wt. grades of PEG and PEG precursors such as ethylene glycol and triethylene glycol. The best results were obtained for the DES composed of tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBAC) and PEG400, which showed that it is possible to achieve, in single extn. step, 85% and 68% of extn. efficiency, and deep desulfurization in 2 and 3 cycles, for DBT and Th, resp. In addn., this DES is not sol. in the model fuel and its extn. capacity is independent on the starting sulfur concn. Finally, after being reused six times, TBAC:PEG400 DES still maintained 53% and 17% of its capacity, for DBT and Th removal, resp., and after a regeneration step the performance of the DES was fully recovered.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtlalsL3O&md5=d4a82a986ee9cbd253335a337c941332

      172. 172
        Warrag, S. E.; Fetisov, E. O.; Van Osch, D. J.; Harwood, D. B.; Kroon, M. C.; Siepmann, J. I.; Peters, C. J. Mercury capture from petroleum using deep eutectic solvents. Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2018, 57 (28), 9222â 9230,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.iecr.8b00967
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        172
        Mercury Capture from Petroleum Using Deep Eutectic Solvents
        Warrag, Samah E. E.; Fetisov, Evgenii O.; van Osch, Dannie J. G. P.; Harwood, David B.; Kroon, Maaike C.; Siepmann, J. Ilja; Peters, Cor J.
        Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2018), 57 (28), 9222-9230CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
        Mercury capture is a major challenge in petroleum and natural gas processing. Recently, ionic liqs. (ILs) have been introduced as mercury extractants from oil and gas. ILs yield very high mercury extn. efficiencies (>95%) from hydrocarbons, but their drawbacks include complex synthesis, toxicity, and difficult regeneration after mercury capture. In this work, a new technol. using deep eutectic solvents (DESs) for elemental mercury (Hg0) extn. from hydrocarbons is demonstrated. DESs are an innovative class of designer solvents exhibiting similar properties as ILs, such as low vapor pressure and low flammability, but DESs are formed from inexpensive hydrogen-bond donor and acceptor compds. that are often biodegradable. In this work, four DESs were investigated including choline chloride:urea, choline chloride:ethylene glycol, choline chloride:levulinic acid, and betaine:levulinic acid, where the molar ratio is 1:2 in all cases. The DESs were tested for their thermal stability, d., and viscosity. Their performance for mercury extn. was assessed using satd. solns. in n-dodecane as the model oil. It was found that solvent to feed ratios of 1:1 and 2:1 at temps. of 303.15 and 333.15 K and atm. pressure yield extn. efficiencies greater than 80% for all four DESs. First-principles mol. dynamics simulations probing the solvation in choline chloride:urea indicate a tight first coordination shell for mercury. Calcn. of the Hg-Hg potential of mean force supports formation of a mercury-mercury polycation for a pair of Hg1+ ions, but not for pairs of Hg0 and Hg2+ species. Geometric anal. of the speciation and Mulliken population anal. support a redox reaction involving Hg2+ + 2Cl-.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1eit7bK&md5=dcf57679cef35c8140a82d18ace11abc
        open URL
      173. 173
        Li, G.; Jiang, Y.; Liu, X.; Deng, D. New levulinic acid-based deep eutectic solvents: synthesis and physicochemical property determination. J. Mol. Liq. 2016, 222, 201â 207,  DOI: 10.1016/j.molliq.2016.07.039
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        173
        New levulinic acid-based deep eutectic solvents: Synthesis and physicochemical property determination
        Li, Guobing; Jiang, Yaotai; Liu, Xiaobang; Deng, Dongshun
        Journal of Molecular Liquids (2016), 222 (), 201-207CODEN: JMLIDT; ISSN:0167-7322. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Recently, deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have emerged as new and inexpensive ionic liqs. (ILs) analogs. They possess attractive and similar solvent properties with traditional ILs. In present work a serials of DESs were prepd. by pairing renewable levulinic acid (LA) as hydrogen donor with seven quaternary ammonium salts as hydrogen acceptor. The samples were further characterized in the temp. ranging from 293.15 to 333.15 K at atm. pressure with the results of d. (0.99891-1.17735 g cm- 3), dynamic viscosity (12.70-376.50 mPa s), elec. cond. (0.35-8.27 mS cm- 1), and refractive index data (1.44384-1.47273). The temp. dependence of these properties was explored and correlated with simple linear or Vogel-Fulcher-Tamman (VFT) models. The vol. expansivities (Î²), molar volumes (Vm), molar refractions (Rm), and free vols. (fm) values have been calcd. on the basis of d. and refractive index data. The active energy of viscosity (EÎ·), molar elec. cond. (Î), and ionicity were also detd. Partial structure-property relationship for DESs was also investigated. The tunable properties make DESs as a potential reaction medium, electrochem. process medium, solvent and absorbent. Therefore, the detn. and correlation can provide relevant information for the engineering and industrial applications of DESs.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

      176. 176
        Mohsenzadeh, A.; Al-Wahaibi, Y.; Al-Hajri, R.; Jibril, B.; Mosavat, N. Sequential deep eutectic solvent and steam injection for enhanced heavy oil recovery and in-situ upgrading. Fuel 2017, 187, 417â 428,  DOI: 10.1016/j.fuel.2016.09.077
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        176
        Sequential deep eutectic solvent and steam injection for enhanced heavy oil recovery and in-situ upgrading
        Mohsenzadeh, A.; Al-Wahaibi, Y.; Al-Hajri, R.; Jibril, B.; Mosavat, N.
        Fuel (2017), 187 (), 417-428CODEN: FUELAC; ISSN:0016-2361. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Recently, Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs) were introduced and investigated as new EOR agents for heavy oil recovery enhancement. In this study, sequential DES and steam flooding was proposed and exptl. investigated as a new scenario for heavy oil recovery enhancement and having potentials for in-situ heavy oil upgrading. DESs used in this study are Choline Chloride:Glycerol (DES1) and Choline Chloride:Urea (DES2). Primary and secondary DES flooding at different concn. followed by high-temp. steam flooding were conducted using 16.5 Â°API heavy oil and Berea sandstone core plugs. DES thermogravimetric anal. (TGA) performed and results verified the relatively high thermal stability of the selected DESs. Maximum decompn. temp. was 320 and 370Â° for DES1 and DES2, resp. This improves their potential for use as chem. additives or pre-flooding agents in thermal EOR methods. Sequential steam flooding after undiluted and 2-fold dild. DES injection recovered an addnl. heavy oil of 12% IOIP compared to steam flooding alone. However, using more dild. solns. (i.e., 20-fold dild. DESs) caused the same and in some cases lower total recovery factor by secondary steam flooding. When followed by steam flooding, DES2 exhibited superior heavy oil recovery enhancement (8-12%) compared with DES1 (1.5-6%) at the same concns. Anal. of physicochem. properties of produced oil for different cases revealed the favorable role of DES in upgrading the in-situ heavy oil. Heavy oil upgrading were quantified through various measurements including increase in API gravity up to 3.5 Â°API, 16.6% redn. in sulfur content or desulphurization and increase in the yields of sat. hydrocarbons. Comparatively, DES1 exhibited better overall performance than DES2 in terms of in-situ heavy oil upgrading.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1Slu7rN&md5=47a0fcca10b96176a80eedf3e0eca9c5

        Khan, M. S.; Lal, B.; Partoon, B.; Keong, L. K.; Bustam, A. B.; Mellon, N. B. Experimental evaluation of a novel thermodynamic inhibitor for CH4 and CO2 hydrates. Procedia engineering 2016, 148, 932â 940,  DOI: 10.1016/j.proeng.2016.06.433
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        177
        Experimental Evaluation of a Novel Thermodynamic Inhibitor for CH4 and CO2 Hydrates
        Khan, Muhammad Saad; Lal, Bhajan; Partoon, Behzad; Keong, Lau Kok; Bustam, Azmi B.; Mellon, Nurhayati Bt
        Procedia Engineering (2016), 148 (), 932-940CODEN: PERNBE; ISSN:1877-7058. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        In natural gas transmission and processing, gas hydrate formation is a major flow assurance challenge which led scientists towards conducting new and more detailed studies on different aspects of gas hydrates inhibitors. Ionic liqs. (IL) recently revealed as novel hydrate inhibitors due to their unique properties like electrostatic charges together with ability to form hydrogen bonding with water mol. lead them viable research area in the field of gas hydrate mitigation. This paper highlighted the exptl. evaluation of thermodn. measurements of tetra Me ammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) for Methane (CH4) and Carbon Dioxide (CO2) gas hydrates. TMAOH belongs to ammonium based ionic liqs. (AILs) which is comparatively economical ILs among the other ILs families. Traditional T-cycle technique with isochoric step heating method was adopted for detg. thermodn. inhibition in this work. Results reveal that TMAOH effectively shift the hydrate equil. curve to upper pressure and lesser temp. regions for CH4 + TMAOH + water system and CO2 + TMAOH + water system. The av. reduced temp. obtained for CH4 + TMAOH + water system is around 1.06 oC while for CO2 + TMAOH + water system, the inhibition effect found to be around 2.09 oC. Therefore, this study provides roadmap for superior alternative for the development of novel thermodn. hydrate inhibitor, which can efficiently control the gas hydrate formation.

        Ramesh, S.; Shanti, R.; Morris, E. Studies on the plasticization efficiency of deep eutectic solvent in suppressing the crystallinity of corn starch based polymer electrolytes. Carbohydr. Polym. 2012, 87 (1), 701â 706,  DOI: 10.1016/j.carbpol.2011.08.047

        179
        Studies on the plasticization efficiency of deep eutectic solvent in suppressing the crystallinity of corn starch based polymer electrolytes
        Ramesh, S.; Shanti, R.; Morris, Ezra
        Carbohydrate Polymers (2012), 87 (1), 701-706CODEN: CAPOD8; ISSN:0144-8617. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A series of polymer electrolytes composed of corn starch (CS), lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) and deep eutectic solvent (DES) were fabricated by soln. casting technique. The DES was synthesized from a mixt. of choline chloride and urea at a molar ratio of 1:2. The addn. of DES is crucial in enhancing the room temp. ionic cond. by increasing the amorphous elastomeric phase in CS:LiTFSI matrix. The ionic transport mechanism is improved, and appreciable amt. of ion conducting polymer electrolytes is produced. The highest ionic cond. achieved for the polymer electrolyte compn. CS:LiTFSI:DES (14:6:80%) is 1.04 Ã 10-3 S/cm. The anomalies that were obsd. with addn. of DES upon formation of neutral ion multiples were visually revealed by the SEM micrographs. The possible dipole-dipole interaction between the constituents was visualized using FTIR upon change in cage peaks.

        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as low-cost and green electrolytes for electrochromic devices
        Cruz, Hugo; Jordao, Noemi; Branco, Luis C.

        The application of deep eutectic solvents based on choline chloride or lithium chloride with ethylene glycol and glycerol as low-cost, recyclable and green electrolytes for electrochromic devices is reported. Reversible electrochromic devices incorporating DESs as alternative electrolytes and bipyridinium electrochromic probes have been tested and compared to conventional systems.

      186. 186
        Juneidi, I.; Hayyan, M.; Hashim, M. Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability for cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents. Rsc Adv. 2015, 5, 83636â 83647,  DOI: 10.1039/C5RA12425E
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        186
        Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability for cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents
        Juneidi, Ibrahim; Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali
        RSC Advances (2015), 5 (102), 83636-83647CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This study presented the toxicol. and biodegradable assessment of different cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs). They were formed from choline chloride (ChCl) and N,N-di-Et ethanol ammonium chloride (EAC) as salts and four hydrogen bond donors, namely ethylene glycol (EG), glycerol (Gly), urea (U), malonic acid (MA), in addn. to a metal salt, i.e. zinc chloride (ZnCl2), and a hydrated metal salt, i.e. zinc nitrate hexahydrate (ZnN). The toxicity towards Aspergillus niger of pure and aq. DESs was evaluated by observing the inhibition zone using an agar well diffusion assay, and the min. inhibition concn. (MIC) using a broth diln. assay, resp. The MIC values of the DESs varied from 1 to 650 mg mL-1, whereas the inhibition zones changed according to the DES dose amt. Another test for acute toxicity was performed by evaluating the lethal concn. at 50% (LC50) of the same DESs on Cyprinus carpio fish. The LC50 of DESs ranged from practically harmless (e.g. ChCl : EG-DESaq) to highly toxic (e.g. EAC : ZnCl2-DESaq). The toxicity profile of the DESs depended on their concn., type of individual components, and interaction with living organisms. Moreover, the DESs recorded higher toxicity compared to their individual components on fungi. However, lower toxicity was found for the DESs tested on Cyprinus carpio. Types I (org. salts and metal salt) and II (org. salt and hydrate metal salt) eutectics exhibited significantly higher toxicity than type III (org. salts and HBD). This was due to the presence of the innate toxicity of the metal salts. The biodegradability was appraised by a closed bottle test in which all the DESs were found to be readily biodegradable. To the best of our knowledge, there are no previous studies reported regarding the toxicity of cholinium-based DESs on freshwater fish or fungi and the biodegradability of EAC-based DESs. Therefore, this investigation can be used as a benchmark for future development of DESs.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFGkurbM&md5=8bbeafa30ad9e4b1096df73eff95f7a8
        open URL
      187. 187
        RadoÅ¡eviÄ, K.; Bubalo, M. C.; SrÄek, V. G.; Grgas, D.; DragiÄeviÄ, T. L.; RedovnikoviÄ, I. R. Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability of choline chloride based deep eutectic solvents. Ecotoxicology and environmental safety 2015, 112, 46â 53,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ecoenv.2014.09.034
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        187
        Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability of choline chloride based deep eutectic solvents
        Radosevic, Kristina; Cvjetko Bubalo, Marina; Gaurina Srcek, Visnje; Grgas, Dijana; Landeka Dragicevic, Tibela; Radojcic Redovnikovic, Ivana
        Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety (2015), 112 (), 46-53CODEN: EESADV; ISSN:0147-6513. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have been dramatically expanding in popularity as a new generation of environmentally friendly solvents with possible applications in various industrial fields, but their ecol. footprint has not yet been thoroughly investigated. In the present study, three choline chloride-based DESs with glucose, glycerol and oxalic acid as hydrogen bond donors were evaluated for in vitro toxicity using fish and human cell line, phytotoxicity using wheat and biodegradability using wastewater microorganisms through closed bottle test. Obtained in vitro toxicity data on cell lines indicate that choline chloride: glucose and choline chloride:glycerol possess low cytotoxicity (EC50>10 mM for both cell lines) while choline chloride:oxalic acid possess moderate cytotoxicity (EC50 value 1.64 mM and 4.19 mM for fish and human cell line, resp.). Results on phytotoxicity imply that tested DESs are non-toxic with seed germination EC50 values higher than 5000 mg L-1. All tested DESs were classified as'readily biodegradable' based on their high levels of mineralization (68-96%). These findings indicate that DESs have a green profile and a good prospect for a wider use in the field of green technologies.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvVGitrbE&md5=8d768400367b3c378f845636e00da992
        open URL

        Evaluation of toxicity and biodegradability for cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents
        Juneidi, Ibrahim; Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali
        RSC Advances (2015), 5 (102), 83636-83647CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        This study presented the toxicol. and biodegradable assessment of different cholinium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs). They were formed from choline chloride (ChCl) and N,N-di-Et ethanol ammonium chloride (EAC) as salts and four hydrogen bond donors, namely ethylene glycol (EG), glycerol (Gly), urea (U), malonic acid (MA), in addn. to a metal salt, i.e. zinc chloride (ZnCl2), and a hydrated metal salt, i.e. zinc nitrate hexahydrate (ZnN). (MIC) using a broth diln. assay, resp. The MIC values of the DESs varied from 1 to 650 mg mL-1, whereas the inhibition zones changed according to the DES dose amt.         Hayyan, M.; Hashim, M. A.; Al-Saadi, M. A.; Hayyan, A.; AlNashef, I. M.; Mirghani, M. E. Assessment of cytotoxicity and toxicity for phosphonium-based deep eutectic solvents. Chemosphere 2013, 93 (2), 455â 459,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemosphere.2013.05.013
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        189
        Assessment of cytotoxicity and toxicity for phosphonium-based deep eutectic solvents
        Hayyan, Maan; Hashim, Mohd Ali; Al-Saadi, Mohammed A.; Hayyan, Adeeb; AlNashef, Inas M.; Mirghani, Mohamed E. S.
        Chemosphere (2013), 93 (2), 455-459CODEN: CMSHAF; ISSN:0045-6535. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        In this work, the cytotoxicity and toxicity of phosphonium-based deep eutectic solvents (DESs) with three hydrogen bond donors, namely glycerin, ethylene glycol, and triethylene glycol were investigated. The cytotoxicity effect was tested using brine shrimp (Artemia salina). The toxicity was investigated using the two Gram pos. bacteria Bacillus subtilis and Staphylococcus aureus, and two Gram neg. bacteria Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The cytotoxicity of tested DESs was much higher than that of their individual components, indicating their toxicol. behavior was different. It was also found that there was toxic effect on the studied bacteria, indicating their potential application as anti-bacterial agents. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time the cytotoxicity and toxicity of phosphonium-based DESs were studied.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtVCgsbbL&md5=ab835834e7316863ae2de5d7ca3da4e5

      190. 190
        Wen, Q.; Chen, J.-X.; Tang, Y.-L.; Wang, J.; Yang, Z. Assessing the toxicity and biodegradability of deep eutectic solvents. Chemosphere 2015, 132, 63â 69,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chemosphere.2015.02.061
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        190
        Assessing the toxicity and biodegradability of deep eutectic solvents
        Wen, Qing; Chen, Jing-Xin; Tang, Yu-Lin; Wang, Juan; Yang, Zhen
        Chemosphere (2015), 132 (), 63-69CODEN: CMSHAF; ISSN:0045-6535. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have emerged as a new type of promising ionic solvents with a broad range of potential applications. Although their ecotoxicol. profile is still poorly known, DESs are generally regarded as "green" because they are composed of ammonium salts and H-bond donors (HBDs) which are considered to be eco-friendly. In this work, cholinium-based DESs comprised of choline chloride (ChCl) and choline acetate (ChAc) as the salt and urea (U), acetamide (A), glycerol (G) and ethylene glycol (EG) as the HBD were evaluated for their toxic effects on different living organisms such as Escherichia coli (a bacterium), Allium sativum (garlic, a plant) and hydra (an invertebrate), and their biodegradabilities were assessed by means of closed bottle tests. These DESs possessed an anti-bacterial property and exhibited inhibitory effects on the test organisms adopted, depending on the compn. and concn. of the DES. The mechanism for the impact of DESs and their components on different living organisms can be assocd. to their interactions with the cellular membranes. Not all DESs can be considered readily biodegradable. By extending the limited knowledge about the toxicity and biodegrdn. of this particular solvent family, this investigation on DESs provides insight into our structure-based understanding of their ecotoxicol. behavior.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXktFOms7c%253D&md5=2832cdda99e954605021d0d3ef18efc7
        open URL
      191. 191
        Modica-Napolitano, J. S.; Aprille, J. R. Delocalized lipophilic cations selectively target the mitochondria of carcinoma cells. Advanced drug delivery reviews 2001, 49 (1â2), 63â 70,  DOI: 10.1016/S0169-409X(01)00125-9
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        191
        Delocalized lipophilic cations selectively target the mitochondria of carcinoma cells
        Modica-Napolitano, J. S.; Aprille, J. R.
        Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews (2001), 49 (1-2), 63-70CODEN: ADDREP; ISSN:0169-409X. (Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.)
        A review with 65 refs. Traditional chemotherapies, aimed at DNA replication in rapidly dividing cells, have achieved only limited success in the treatment of carcinomas due largely to their lack of specificity for cells of tumorigenic origin. It is important, therefore, to investigate treatment strategies aimed at novel cellular targets that are sufficiently different between normal cells and cancer cells so as to provide a basis for selective tumor cell killing. Delocalized lipophilic cations (DLCs) are concd. by cells and into mitochondria in response to neg. inside transmembrane potentials. The higher plasma and/or mitochondrial membrane potentials of carcinoma cells compared to normal epithelial cells account for the selective accumulation of DLCs in carcinoma mitochondria. Since most DLCs are toxic to mitochondria at high concns., their selective accumulation in carcinoma mitochondria and consequent mitochondrial toxicity provide a basis for selective carcinoma cell killing. Several of these compds. have already displayed some degree of efficacy as chemotherapeutic agents in vitro and in vivo. The effectiveness of DLCs can also be enhanced by their use in photochemotherapy or combination drug therapy. Discovery of the biochem. differences that account for the higher membrane potentials in carcinoma cells is expected to lead to the design of new DLCs targeted specifically to those differences, resulting in even greater selectivity and efficacy for tumor cell killing.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjslSmtLk%253D&md5=47f1fea1d9ede2b916903e36e9bbff66
        open URL
      192. 192
        Gu, T.; Zhang, M.; Tan, T.; Chen, J.; Li, Z.; Zhang, Q.; Qiu, H. Deep eutectic solvents as novel extraction media for phenolic compounds from model oil. Chem. Commun. 2014, 50 (79), 11749â 11752,  DOI: 10.1039/C4CC04661G
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        192
        Deep eutectic solvents as novel extraction media for phenolic compounds from model oil
        Gu, Tongnian; Zhang, Mingliang; Tan, Ting; Chen, Jia; Li, Zhan; Zhang, Qinghua; Qiu, Hongdeng
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (79), 11749-11752CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Deep eutectic solvents (DES) as a new kind of green solvent were used for the first time to excellently ext. phenolic compds. from model oil. It was also proved that DES could be used to ext. other polar compds. from non-polar or weakly-polar solvents by liq.-phase microextn.

        Oliveira, F. S.; Pereiro, A. B.; Rebelo, L. P.; Marrucho, I. M. Deep eutectic solvents as extraction media for azeotropic mixtures. Green Chem. 2013, 15 (5), 1326â 1330,  DOI: 10.1039/c3gc37030e
